Americans' trust in information sources such as the World Health Organization (WHO) varies across different demographics.  Older Americans, particularly those aged 65 and above, show a notable level of distrust in information from the WHO, with 49% expressing that they do not trust WHO information either "not at all" or "not too much" ![Bar chart showing trust levels in WHO by age and education](image2). In contrast, highly educated individuals, such as those with postgraduate degrees, exhibit greater confidence in international bodies like the European Union (EU).  A significant majority, 78%, of postgraduates trust information from the EU [6], implying that only 22% of this group does not trust EU information.  Therefore, there are 27% more people over 65 years old who do not trust information from the World Health Organization compared to postgraduates who do not trust information from the European Union.
In conclusion, older adults are significantly more likely to distrust the WHO compared to the level of distrust in the EU among postgraduates.

Furthermore, a promotional aspect of the Lufthansa website is also visible, advertising European destinations [5]. ![Lufthansa website promotes flights to Europe](image5).

Views on defense spending in Europe differ across political lines, as indicated by the trends among Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019, where both groups show a decline in the share who believe European allies should increase their defense budgets, with a more pronounced decrease among Republicans [5].  ![Trends in opinions on defense spending among Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019](image1).  Political party alignment in both the U.S. and Germany reveals further divisions, with varying levels of support among Republicans and Democrats in the U.S., and CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens in Germany [6].  ![Political party alignment percentages in the U.S. and Germany](image4). Preferences for foreign policy partners also diverge along political lines; for instance, Republicans show a stronger inclination towards Israel compared to Democrats, while Democrats emphasize cooperation with Canada and Mexico [8, 10].  ![Country preferences by political affiliation in the U.S.](image3).  Numerical values associated with different German political parties such as CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens highlight the political landscape within Germany [1]. ![Numerical values for different German political parties](image2).  Opinions on international bodies like the UN and EU, as well as towards Russia, are also shaped by political ideology in both America and Germany, showcasing a spectrum of views from conservatives to liberals and right to left, respectively [5, 9].  ![Opinions on international entities by political ideology in the U.S. and Germany](image5).  Political affiliation significantly shapes the results presented in these charts.

While most Latino voters lean towards the Democratic candidate, preferences vary among different Hispanic origin groups, with Mexican voters being more inclined to vote Democratic [2, 5]. In contrast, Cuban voters show a different pattern as they are more inclined to vote for the Republican candidate in the upcoming U.S. House of Representatives elections, standing out as the only group with a Republican preference [5, ![The Democratic candidate has a higher percentage in most groups except among Cuban voters, where the Republican candidate leads.](image3)].  This preference is further reflected in their opinions on Donald Trump's political future.  Although overall a clear majority of Hispanic registered voters do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [10], Cuban voters are more inclined to favor Trump's continued presence in national politics and consider his potential run for president in 2024 [7, 3].  Indeed, when looking at the percentage of Latino registered voters who think Trump should run for president, Cuban voters show the highest rate among all Hispanic origin groups [![Cuban voters have the highest percentage at 29.](image4)].

Cuban voters are the Hispanic origin group most likely to vote for a Republican candidate and to support Trump running for president.

Republican voters consistently leaned towards a more conservative direction for their party from 2008 to 2016 [7].  Even in 2008, a period marked by a greater willingness among Republicans to collaborate with Barack Obama, the dominant preference within the GOP base remained conservative [8].  ![The image shows that around 60% of Republican voters favored a conservative direction for their party from 2008 to 2016, with a slightly decreasing moderate preference.](image5)  Conversely, Democratic voters displayed a noticeable shift towards a more liberal stance during this timeframe [9, 10].  Following Obama's victories, a moderate approach was initially more appealing to Democrats [4, 9], but by 2016, the desire for a more liberal direction had significantly increased within the Democratic voter base [9, 10]. ![The image shows that the preference for a more liberal direction among Democratic voters increased from 2008 to 2016, narrowing the gap with moderate preference.](image3) In conclusion, Republican voters remained largely conservative, while Democratic voters became increasingly liberal from 2008 to 2016.

Voter opinions on appointing opposition party members differed significantly between the Trump and Obama presidencies.  Specifically, only 26% of Trump voters believed he should appoint Democrats to his administration, while a larger portion, 52%, thought it didn't matter [6].  ![This bar chart shows that among Trump voters, only 26% think Trump should appoint Democrats, while 52% think it doesn't matter.](image2) In contrast, in 2008, a majority of Obama voters, 52%, were in favor of him appointing Republicans to his cabinet [8].  ![This bar chart indicates that 52% of Obama voters thought Obama should appoint Republicans to his cabinet.](image4) This highlights a notable decrease in support for cross-party appointments from Obama's to Trump's election, as evidenced by the different opinions of their respective voters.  Voter opinions on appointing opposition party members showed a significant difference between the elections of Trump in 2016 and Obama in 2008, with less support for cross-party appointments during Trump's election.

In December 2015, there was a notable increase in optimism regarding the U.S. military campaign against ISIS compared to July of the same year [7].  Specifically, the percentage of people who believed that the U.S. and its allies would succeed in their military campaign against ISIS rose from 55% in July to 66% in December [7]. This shift is visually represented in the increased height of the "Definitely/Probably succeed" bar from July to December. ![Comparison of success perceptions in July and December 2015](image3).  This indicates a significant positive change in public perception over these months.

While overall ratings of the U.S. military effort against ISIS remained negative, there was still an improvement in the perception of its effectiveness between July and December.  As shown, the percentage of people rating the campaign as "Not too/at all well" decreased slightly from 62% in July to 58% in December. ![Trend of ratings on how well the U.S. military effort against ISIS is going](image4).  Despite this slight improvement in perceived effectiveness, views on using ground forces remained fairly consistent during this period [4].  The level of support for using U.S. ground forces against ISIS was 44% in July and 47% in December, showing little change [4].  Public opinion on ground forces is divided, as almost equal percentages favor (47%) and oppose (47%) the use of U.S. ground forces against ISIS. Republicans are more likely to favor (66%) than Democrats (33%) or Independents (48%). ![Public opinion on the use of U.S. ground forces against ISIS, broken down by political affiliation](image1).

Overall, from July to December 2015, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS became more positive, with increased belief in its ultimate success, although views on the current effectiveness and the use of ground forces remained relatively stable.

Public perception is divided on whether Islam is more prone to encourage violence compared to other religions, with approximately equal portions of the population holding each view [1, 4]. While there has been a slight decrease from a high point in 2014, overall opinions on this matter have remained quite stable over the past decade [4, 5].

![Line graph illustrating the fluctuating opinions on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions from 2002 to 2015.](image4)

However, significant differences emerge when considering political affiliations [1].  A notable partisan divide exists and is actually growing [7, 8].  A large majority of Republicans, around two-thirds, consistently believe that Islam is more likely to encourage violence, a viewpoint that has remained largely unchanged since 2014 and is at its highest point since 2002 [6, 8].  This perspective is particularly pronounced among conservative Republicans [7].

![Line graph displaying the diverging trends in perceptions of Islam and violence among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents from 2002 to 2015, highlighting the widening partisan gap.](image5)

Conversely, Democrats are considerably less inclined to associate Islam with violence, and this viewpoint has become even less prevalent since 2014 [6, 8].  Specifically, liberal Democrats overwhelmingly do not consider Islam to be more violence-prone than other religions [7]. This increasing divergence in opinion between political parties underscores a significant polarization in perceptions regarding Islam and violence [8].

![Table summarizing survey results across demographics and political groups in July 2014, September 2014, and December 2015, showing the percentage of respondents who believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions and the change over time.](image1)

In conclusion, perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have shown limited overall change over time, but exhibit a stark and increasing divergence across political affiliations, especially between Republicans and Democrats.

Most Americans are familiar with the idea of machines taking over human jobs, with a large majority having heard or read about it [7].  A considerable portion of the public, $77\%$, considers this concept at least somewhat realistic, and $20\%$ believe it is extremely realistic ![A stacked bar chart shows that 20% of people think the concept is extremely realistic, 57% somewhat realistic, 17% not too realistic and 5% not at all realistic](image1).  This perception of realism is stronger among those who are more informed about automation; nearly half of those with high awareness find it extremely realistic [6].  The level of familiarity varies, as illustrated in survey data showing different degrees of exposure to the concept ![A bar chart shows that 24% of people heard a lot about the concept, 61% a little, and 14% nothing at all](image2).  Despite acknowledging the plausibility, Americans express more worry than enthusiasm about this future [4, 9].  Specifically, $72\%$ express worry compared to only $33\%$ who feel enthusiastic about robots and computers performing many human jobs [9].  This sentiment is further reflected in concerns about potential negative outcomes, with a significant majority anticipating increased inequality and difficulty finding purpose in life, while being less optimistic about positive outcomes like economic efficiency or more meaningful jobs ![A bar graph showing that most people think negative outcomes like inequality and difficulty finding purpose are likely, while positive outcomes like economic efficiency and more meaningful jobs are not](image3).  These feelings of worry and enthusiasm are further broken down, illustrating that worry significantly outweighs enthusiasm across different levels of intensity ![A bar chart comparing levels of enthusiasm and worry, showing worry is significantly higher across 'very' and 'somewhat' categories](image4).  Interestingly, those who have already experienced automation in their careers are more likely to perceive the concept as realistic and express greater support for measures like universal basic income [5].  However, for the general population, worry outweighs enthusiasm, especially concerning algorithms in hiring processes, where worry is three times higher than enthusiasm [9].  Those with greater awareness tend to find the concept more realistic and express higher enthusiasm, but worry remains the dominant emotion even among this group ![A bar chart showing that across different levels of familiarity ('Heard a lot', 'Heard a little', 'Heard nothing'), worry consistently outweighs enthusiasm, though realism and enthusiasm increase with familiarity](image5).  In conclusion, Americans generally perceive the automation of human jobs as a realistic possibility, but they predominantly approach this prospect with worry rather than enthusiasm, anticipating more negative than positive societal impacts.

While there is not a complete consensus, a significant portion of the public expresses a desire to place boundaries on the extent to which businesses can substitute human roles with machines, with approximately 58% advocating for such limitations [7]. This sentiment is further illustrated by survey data indicating that 58% of people believe there should be limits on job replacement by machines, even if machines are more efficient and cost-effective ![This pie chart indicates that a majority of people believe limits should be placed on businesses replacing human workers with machines.](image2).  This suggests a prevailing public unease about the unrestricted automation of jobs. A notable point of agreement across different demographics is the preference for confining robots and computers to roles that are inherently hazardous or unhealthy for humans; a policy strongly favored by 85% of Americans [9, 10].  This widespread support is visually represented in data showing that limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs is favored by a large majority of the public ![This bar graph displays the strong public support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.](image4).  Despite some division on who should support displaced workers [4], the desire to strategically limit the scope of machine automation, especially in sensitive areas like job displacement, is a recurring theme in public opinion.  In conclusion, public opinion leans towards strategically limiting machine use in the workforce, particularly advocating for restricting machines to dangerous jobs and expressing concern about the widespread replacement of human roles.

Americans' perceptions regarding job availability have significantly improved recently [4, 6].  Notably, positive views on job availability are currently high among both Republicans and Democrats [10].  However, a partisan gap exists in these perceptions, with Republicans expressing more optimism than Democrats [3, 8].  As depicted in survey results, a substantial majority of Republicans, 71%, believe there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats who share this view ![Survey data highlights partisan differences in perceptions of job availability, showing Republicans are more likely to believe jobs are plentiful compared to Democrats.](image1).  Despite this difference, majorities within both parties perceive jobs as readily available in their communities [7].  Overall, while both Republicans and Democrats perceive jobs to be widely available, Republicans hold a more optimistic view compared to Democrats.

In January 2019, 70% of Democrats preferred their leaders to stand up to Trump, a rise from 63% in January 2018 [6]. This is visually represented with corresponding bar segments showing the increase in Democrats favoring a confrontational stance ![The bar chart visually represents the increase in Democrats wanting leaders to stand up to Trump from 2018 to 2019](image3).  Conversely, the percentage of Democrats who wanted party leaders to work with Trump decreased from 30% in January 2018 to 26% in January 2019, as also depicted in the same chart ![The bar chart visually represents the decrease in Democrats wanting leaders to work with Trump from 2018 to 2019](image3).

For Republicans, there was also an increase in the preference for leaders to stand up to the opposition. In January 2019, 51% of Republicans wanted Trump to stand up to Democrats, compared to 40% in January 2018 [6]. This shift is also shown visually with bars depicting the change over the year ![The bar chart visually represents the increase in Republicans wanting leaders to stand up to Democrats from 2018 to 2019](image5).  Simultaneously, the percentage of Republicans desiring their leaders to work with Democrats decreased from 49% in January 2018 to 42% in January 2019, as shown in the same image ![The bar chart visually represents the decrease in Republicans wanting leaders to work with Democrats from 2018 to 2019](image5).

Overall, both Democrats and Republicans showed an increased preference for their leaders to stand up to the opposing party from January 2018 to January 2019, with a corresponding decrease in the desire for cross-party cooperation.

Latinos hold diverse perspectives regarding racial discrimination [8]. A key difference emerges in their views on whether the larger issue is the lack of recognition of racial discrimination or its over-perception.  Nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and those leaning Democratic consider it a bigger problem when people fail to see racial discrimination where it truly exists. Conversely, around six in ten Republicans and Republican leaners believe it is a greater problem when people perceive racial discrimination where it is absent [6].  ![This bar graph illustrates that a larger percentage of Latino Democrats and leaners believe that the bigger problem is people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists, compared to Latino Republicans and leaners.](image3).  Latino Democrats are considerably more likely than Latino Republicans to identify the lack of acknowledgement of racial discrimination as a major national concern [10].  Specifically, 75% of Latino Democrats hold this belief, in stark contrast to only 36% of Latino Republicans [10].  Furthermore, a larger proportion of Democrats and independents report personal experiences of racial discrimination compared to Republicans [9].  Consequently, Latino Democrats and Republicans exhibit substantial differences in their perceptions of racial discrimination, with Democrats more inclined to view it as a significant and often underestimated problem, and Republicans more likely to believe it is overstated.

Americans perceive various reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM fields [2, 3]. Many believe a significant factor is the lack of encouragement for girls, blacks, and Hispanics to pursue STEM from an early age [5].  For women in STEM, key challenges include discrimination in recruitment and balancing work with family, while for blacks and Hispanics, limited access to quality education is a major barrier, alongside lack of early encouragement as depicted in the following chart. ![Bar chart showing major reasons for underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs](image5).  Indeed, limited access to quality education is considered a primary reason for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics, a view particularly strong among those working in STEM [6, 9].  Furthermore, within STEM, perceptions diverge, with some attributing underrepresentation to a lack of belief in ability and insufficient role models within these groups, while others point to racial and ethnic discrimination in hiring and advancement [4].  Notably, those employed in STEM jobs are more inclined to cite lack of access to quality education, lack of early encouragement, and a scarcity of Black and Hispanic role models as significant factors compared to individuals in non-STEM roles [1].  Black STEM workers especially emphasize limited access to quality education, discrimination in recruitment and promotions, and lack of early encouragement as major reasons for underrepresentation [8].

The Pew Research Center identifies lack of access to quality education, lack of early encouragement, and discrimination as major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs.

Generally, Americans hold a critical view of the quality of STEM education in K-12 schools within the U.S., with a significant portion, specifically 43%, rating it as merely average when juxtaposed with other developed nations [4].  In fact, a considerable percentage,  30%, even consider it to be below average in comparison to global standards [7].  This sentiment is visually supported by public opinion data. ![The bar chart shows that only 25% of U.S. adults believe K-12 public schools are best in the world or above average.](image5).

Interestingly, this critical perspective is even more pronounced among those with expertise in STEM fields.  While a quarter of all Americans believe K-12 STEM education is above average, this positive view is notably less common among STEM postgraduate degree holders [4].  In stark contrast, only a small fraction, 13%, of individuals holding postgraduate degrees in STEM consider K-12 STEM education in the U.S. to be above average [1].  This group is considerably more critical, with approximately half, 51%, judging the U.S. to be below average in K-12 STEM education [9].

In conclusion, STEM postgraduate degree holders are notably more critical of K-12 public school education compared to the general U.S. adult population.

Social media's role in shaping perspectives is noteworthy, particularly among younger demographics [2, 5].  It is important to understand which sources exert the most influence on individuals.

![The bar chart indicates that 'Social media/bloggers' influence increased from 28% in 2013 to 35% in 2014.](image4)

The influence of 'Social media/bloggers' saw an increase from 2013 to 2014.

Median investments in both the U.S. and Europe experienced fluctuations from 2004 to 2009, with a notable peak around 2007-2008, particularly in later-stage investments.  However, the trends exhibit some key differences.  In the U.S., as shown in the investment amounts across seed, first, second, and later stages generally peaked around 2006-2007 before declining by 2009 ![The chart captures a peak in investment activities around 2006-2007 and a subsequent decline across all categories by 2009.](image2). European investments, depicted in the second graph, show a similar peak in later-stage investments around 2007-2008, but the seed, first, and second stages appear more stable throughout the period, without the same pronounced peak and decline seen in the U.S. ![The graph shows that "Later" stage investments peaked around 2007-2008, while the other stages show less variation over the years.](image5). This difference could be related to the scarcity of VC money in Europe, which has driven higher capital efficiency compared to the U.S. [1].  Furthermore, despite an entrepreneurial boom and a maturing venture ecosystem in Europe [10], average entry valuations have remained lower than in the U.S., as illustrated in the comparison of average valuations where European entry valuations are significantly lower than those in the USA ![For Europe, the average entry valuation is $5.5 million. For the USA, the average entry valuation is $16.1 million](image4).

In summary, while both the U.S. and Europe saw investment peaks in the mid-2000s, the U.S. experienced more pronounced fluctuations across all investment stages compared to the more stable early-stage investments in Europe during the same period.

The expansion of digital advertising in India is notable, especially when considering the overall advertising expenditure [4, 7].  The digital sector has emerged as the fastest-growing area, showcasing a remarkable compound annual growth rate. This rapid growth is visually represented, highlighting the significant 30% CAGR in the digital sector, underscoring its leading position in expansion ![Digital sector is experiencing rapid growth with a 30% CAGR](image1). Looking at the comparative growth rates across different media platforms from 2012 to 2016, we can see the specific figures for each category.  The table clearly indicates the compound annual growth rate for digital media against other media types during this period.  The data reveals that digital media outpaces all others with a CAGR of 29.9% ![Digital media demonstrates the highest CAGR compared to other media categories between 2012 and 2016](image5).

Digital media experienced the highest growth rate in digital ad spend in India from 2012 to 2016.

Online retail in India showcases category-specific transaction and gross margin contributions.  Looking at transaction distribution, Fashion, Footwear & Accessories lead with 35% of transactions ![Fashion, Footwear & Accessories constitute the largest portion of online retail transactions.](image4). However, when considering gross margin contribution, Mobile, Tablets & Accessories emerge as the dominant category, accounting for 35% of the gross margin ![Mobile, Tablets & Accessories contribute most significantly to the gross margin.](image1).  This indicates that while Fashion drives transaction volume, Mobile and related accessories are more profitable in terms of gross margin.  The online marketplace offers a wide array of products, from everyday items to specialized goods [2, 9], and these category-specific performances are crucial for understanding the dynamics of e-commerce [6].

Fashion, Footwear & Accessories category contributes the most to the number of transactions, while Mobile, Tablets & Accessories category contributes the most to the gross margin value in online retail.

To ensure the reliability of the assessment, the document employs both confidence and likelihood evaluations [4]. These evaluations are grounded in expert assessment and consensus among chapter authors, considering the available literature, the quality and quantity of evidence, and the level of agreement across different studies [5].  Confidence in a finding's validity is determined by the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, as well as the degree of expert agreement, ranging from low to very high confidence as shown in the evidence chart ![The image is a text-based chart that describes different levels of confidence regarding evidence or claims, from Very High to Low.](image2).  Where scientifically justified, likelihood designations are also included, describing the probability of particular impacts using terms that are associated with specific probability ranges, from very unlikely to very likely, which are defined in the probability terms diagram ![The image is a visual representation of probability terms and their corresponding numerical ranges, from Very Likely to Very Unlikely.](image3) [7].  Ultimately, the levels of confidence and likelihood are evaluated through a detailed assessment of literature, expert consensus, and the quality of evidence.

Public views on the ethical standards of both political parties are quite similar, with roughly equal percentages considering both the Democratic and Republican parties to have high ethical standards [8].  Partisan affiliation strongly influences these perceptions, as individuals from both Republican and Democratic leaning groups are inclined to view their own party favorably regarding policy ideas and less likely to see them as extreme [4]. Independents, however, tend to hold a more critical view, with a larger proportion believing that neither party possesses high ethical standards, compared to those affiliated with either party [7].

![Bar chart comparing perceptions of parties on policy, ethics and extremism](image2)

Looking at educational backgrounds, opinions diverge; for instance, among those with a college degree, a notable percentage express the view that "high ethical standards" are not characteristic of either the Republican or Democratic party [3].  This suggests that higher education may correlate with a more critical or nuanced perspective on party ethics.

![Bar chart showing percentage of groups who think attributes describe neither party](image4)

Even though similar proportions of the public find both parties ethically questionable, there is a slight inclination to view the Republican Party as "too extreme" compared to the Democratic Party, although this perception of Republican extremism has seen a slight decrease recently [9]. Ultimately, perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism are notably differentiated when considering political affiliation and educational attainment.

Public perception indicates a nuanced view on the ethical standards of both Republican and Democratic parties, with a notable segment of the population expressing skepticism towards both.  A quarter of the public believes that "high ethical standards" describe neither the Republican nor the Democratic party [6].  Interestingly, independents are more inclined than partisans to think that neither party possesses high ethical standards [1]. This perspective is particularly pronounced among independents, with about a third holding this view [1].  In contrast, partisans are more likely to view their own party favorably in terms of ethical conduct, although fewer are completely positive about their own party's ethical standards compared to their general partisan loyalty [4].

![This bar chart illustrates the distribution of opinions on whether both, one, or neither political party possesses certain attributes, broken down by education and political affiliation.](image1)

Despite these critiques, comparable portions of the public attribute high ethical standards to each individual party, with about four-in-ten holding this view for both the Democratic and Republican parties [2, 9]. This suggests a somewhat balanced, albeit not overwhelmingly positive, view of each party's ethical conduct.  Education level also plays a role, as those with at least a college degree are more likely than those with less education to say neither party has high ethical standards [5, 8].

![This bar chart compares the public perception of policy ideas, ethical standards, and extremism between the Republican and Democratic parties, showing a close rating for ethical standards and a higher 'too extreme' rating for Republicans.](image3)

When it comes to being perceived as "too extreme," the Republican Party is somewhat more likely to be viewed as such compared to the Democratic Party [3, 10]. However, partisan divisions significantly shape these opinions, with each party largely viewing the opposing party as "too extreme" [7].  While views of the Democratic Party as too extreme have remained relatively stable, perceptions of the Republican Party as excessively extreme have seen a slight decrease recently [3].

In summary, public opinion reveals a skeptical outlook on the ethical standards of both parties, especially among independents and more educated individuals, while perceptions of extremism are more pronounced for the Republican Party, heavily influenced by partisan alignment.

Americans' views on the ethical standards of political parties are quite varied depending on their education level.  Notably, individuals with higher education are more likely to express cynicism towards both parties, with nearly a third of college graduates believing that neither the Republican nor Democratic party possesses 'high ethical standards' [9].  This contrasts with those with less education, where only 20% of individuals with a high school degree or less share this view [1].

![Individuals with higher education are more inclined to believe that neither party has high ethical standards.](image3)

Interestingly, even within their own political spectrum, partisans express some reservations about their party's ethical standards, although majorities in both Republican (66%) and Democratic (64%) camps still consider their party to have high ethical standards [5].  Independents, especially, are significantly more skeptical, with about a third stating that neither party meets ethical standards [10].  When considering political preferences alongside education, a notable trend emerges: those with postgraduate degrees heavily favor the Democratic candidate, by a two-to-one margin over Republicans, and this preference remains strong among those with a four-year college degree [2].

![Voters with postgraduate degrees show a strong preference for Democratic candidates.](image5)

It's also worth noting that attentiveness to election news is consistent across party lines, with identical shares of Republicans and Democrats following election news closely [3]. However, educational background does create a divergence in ethical perceptions; a substantial 31% of those with at least a college degree believe that neither party has high ethical standards [7].  Overall, when assessing ethical standards, the public is split: a quarter believes neither party is ethical, 47% think only one party is, and 17% think both are ethical [4].  The Republican Party is perceived as more extreme by the public compared to the Democratic Party, yet both parties receive similar ratings for having good policy ideas and ethical standards [image2].

![Public perceptions of party attributes, showing similar ethical ratings but differing views on extremism.](image2)

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences are significantly influenced by education level and political affiliation, with higher education correlating with increased skepticism towards party ethics and stronger Democratic preferences at the postgraduate level.

Public perception of Trump's ethical standards and his handling of economic policy reveals significant partisan divides.  Evaluations of Trump administration officials' ethical standards are heavily influenced by political affiliation, as illustrated in the bar chart, where Republicans generally rate them positively while Democrats hold strongly negative views. ![Ethical standards are viewed very differently across party lines](image1).  Indeed, three-quarters of Republicans give the administration high marks for ethical standards, while a large majority of Democrats rate them negatively [5]. Even within the Republican party, there's a spectrum of opinion; conservative Republicans are overwhelmingly positive, but a notable portion of moderate and liberal Republicans express concerns about ethical standards [8]. Shifting to economic policy, public confidence in Trump's ability to make good decisions is mixed, with just over half expressing some confidence [3]. However, this confidence in economic policy has seen an increase since January [10].  Similar to ethical standards, partisan lines are sharply drawn in views on Trump’s capabilities across various domains, including the economy, with strong Republican confidence and equally strong Democratic lack of confidence [4].

In conclusion, public views on both Trump's handling of economic policy and his ethical standards are deeply polarized along partisan lines, with Republicans generally more supportive than Democrats.

Public confidence in Trump's capacity to navigate critical issues has shown some interesting shifts.  Notably, there's been an uptick in optimism regarding his handling of economic matters and international crises since the beginning of the year [2, 3].  This increase is visually represented, showing a rise in public confidence for both "handling international crises" and "making good decisions about economic policy" from January to May 2018, although the confidence level for international crises experienced a dip before this rise ![Trends in public confidence for handling international crises and economic policy, showing recent increases](image1).

Specifically focusing on economic policy, about half of the public expresses some degree of confidence in Trump's decision-making in this area, marking an improvement from earlier in the year [6, 7].  When evaluating various aspects of Trump's performance, negotiating favorable trade agreements stands out as an area where a narrow majority expresses confidence, contrasting with areas like immigration and working with Congress where confidence is lower ![Effectiveness ratings across different tasks, showing varied levels of public confidence](image4).  Regarding international crises, while there's been an increase in confidence since January, it's important to note that narrow majorities still express limited confidence in this domain [9, 10].  Partisan lines are sharply drawn, with Republicans demonstrating a significant surge in confidence in Trump's ability to handle international crises and expressing strong agreement with him on most issues [4, 5]. Public opinion on Trump's abilities in handling economic policy and international crises has generally improved since January, though partisan divides remain significant.

Public confidence in President Trump's ability to manage critical areas has seen some shifts.  There's been an uptick in confidence regarding his handling of both the economy and international crises since January [4, 8].  Specifically, confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis has risen to 43% in May, a notable increase from 35% in January, though still below the 48% recorded in April of the previous year [10]. This trend of increased confidence in handling international crises and economic policy since the beginning of the year is visually represented, showing a clear upward trajectory in public sentiment over a few months ![Line graphs depicting public confidence in handling international crises and economic policy, showing recent increases](image2).

However, this confidence isn't uniform across all areas.  When considering broader performance aspects, public opinion is varied.  For instance, evaluations of Trump's effectiveness in areas like negotiating trade agreements, making economic policy decisions, and handling international crises reveal a spectrum of opinions, with significant portions of respondents feeling he is "not at all" or "not too" effective in these domains ![Bar chart showing public opinion on Trump's effectiveness across various tasks, indicating mixed views](image1).

Diverging along party lines, opinions on President Trump's conduct are sharply divided.  An overwhelming majority of Democrats, 85%, express dislike for the way Trump conducts himself, a sentiment that has remained consistent [1].  In stark contrast, Republicans exhibit more nuanced views on his conduct. While a considerable portion, 38%, like his conduct, a larger segment, 45%, have mixed feelings, and a smaller group of 16% express dislike [6].  This partisan split in sentiment regarding Trump's behavior is clearly visualized, highlighting the deep divisions in public perception based on political affiliation ![Horizontal bar chart illustrating partisan opinions on Trump's conduct, showing stark differences between Republicans and Democrats](image5).

In conclusion, while public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has increased since the beginning of the year, particularly among Republicans, strong partisan divisions persist regarding his conduct as president.

Public confidence in President Trump's ability to navigate international crises has seen some changes. Initially, 48% of the public expressed confidence in his crisis management skills in April, but this figure decreased to 35% by January before rebounding to 43% in May [5]. This fluctuation in public opinion is visually represented in the graph charting confidence in handling international crises, displaying a dip and subsequent rise over time ![The graph illustrates the public's fluctuating confidence in Trump's ability to handle international crises](image3). In contrast, public confidence in Trump's economic policy decisions has shown a positive trend, climbing from 46% in January to 53% by May [3]. The upward trajectory of confidence in economic policy is depicted in the graph showcasing opinions on economic decisions since January ![The graph demonstrates the increasing public confidence in Trump's economic policy decisions](image3).  Overall, public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has generally increased, whereas confidence in his ability to manage international crises has fluctuated and remains slightly below its initial level.

Democrats have consistently shown strong disapproval of President Trump's conduct, with a significant majority expressing dislike [2, 5].  Even within the Republican party, opinions are divided; while a segment expresses approval, a larger portion conveys mixed feelings about his behavior [3, 5]. There's a notable divergence in views even within the Republican base, where conservative Republicans are more inclined to approve of Trump's conduct compared to their moderate or liberal counterparts [6].  ![Bar chart showing opinions on Trump's conduct by political affiliation, highlighting the differences between Republicans and Democrats](image1).  Examining the shifts in sentiment over time reveals that while disapproval remains high among Democrats, there have been some changes within Republican opinions between August 2017 and May 2018 ![Bar chart comparing Republican and Democrat opinions on Trump's conduct between August 2017 and May 2018](image3).  Despite these fluctuations, Democrats' negative views have remained a constant factor in the evaluation of Trump’s conduct and the ethical standards of his administration.  In summary, Democrats' disapproval of Trump's conduct has remained consistently high, while Republican opinions have shown some internal division and slight shifts over time.

Public perception suggests that ethical standards within the Trump administration are notably lower when compared to previous administrations [1, 8].  This perspective is further highlighted when examining presidential approval ratings across different administrations, noting how approval for President Trump in May 2018 stood at 39% ![Trump's approval rating is lower than Obama's and some of Bush, Clinton, Bush and Reagan's approval ratings at comparable points in their presidencies.](image1).  Specifically, a significant portion of the public, 58%, rates the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as either not good or poor [9].  Despite these ethical concerns, public evaluation of Donald Trump's job performance has remained relatively consistent throughout his term, mirroring initial ratings [2].  It's also important to consider the nuances within these ratings, as disapproval is often more intensely felt, with 42% of the public strongly disapproving of Trump's handling of his presidential duties [4], and these opinions vary across demographics, illustrating a complex landscape of public sentiment ![Approval and disapproval ratings differ significantly across gender, race, age, education, political affiliation, and religious affiliation.](image2).  In conclusion, ethical approval for the Trump administration is lower than that of previous administrations, yet this has not drastically altered overall public approval of his job performance, which remains largely consistent.

Individuals with higher education are more inclined to perceive neither the Republican nor Democratic parties as having high ethical standards [6].  Interestingly, while a notable portion of those with college degrees believe that ethical standards are not applicable to either party, a larger segment thinks this description fits only one party, not both, suggesting a more nuanced view among the educated regarding partisan ethics [6]. In contrast, those with less education, such as a high school degree or some college experience, are less likely to believe that neither party possesses high ethical standards [1].

![This bar chart shows that among those with college degrees, a larger percentage believes that ethical standards describe one party but not the other, compared to those with less education, who are more inclined to say ethical standards describe neither party.](image4)

Furthermore, disapproval of Donald Trump's performance is notably higher among individuals with greater educational attainment [8]. This indicates a correlation between higher education levels and a more critical view of the Trump administration.

![This bar graph visually breaks down approval and disapproval ratings across different education levels, reinforcing the trend that higher education correlates with increased disapproval.](image2)

Examining political affiliations, independents generally hold a more negative view of the ethical standards within the Trump administration compared to a positive one [2].  This negative sentiment is particularly pronounced among independents who lean towards the Democratic Party [2].  While partisans tend to view their own party more favorably regarding ethical standards, there's still a considerable portion who do not consider their party to have high ethical standards [3].  Overall, when considering both parties, a significant portion of the public does not believe that either the Republican or Democratic party is characterized by high ethical standards [9]. Independents are more likely than those affiliated with a party to express this view that neither party holds high ethical standards [10].

![This bar chart highlights the opinions of different political groups, showing variations in perceptions that can be related to ethical standards and party image.](image3)

In summary, higher education is associated with increased skepticism towards the ethical standards of both political parties and a higher disapproval rate of Donald Trump, while political independents, particularly those leaning Democratic, are notably critical of the ethical standards within the Trump administration.

Voter reactions in 2016 presented a nuanced landscape compared to prior elections. While approximately half of voters expressed happiness about Donald Trump's victory, mirroring the sentiment after Obama's reelection in 2012, the overall positivity was diminished in contrast to the 2008 election [5, 6].  Many voters experienced a blend of emotions following the 2016 election, as illustrated by the varied feelings expressed. ![Bar chart depicting emotions such as hope, pride, unease, sadness, fear, and anger with their respective percentages](image2).  Notably, a significant portion of voters found the 2016 presidential campaign to be considerably more negative and less focused on substantive issues compared to previous election cycles [7]. Post-election assessments of the campaign conduct by candidates, parties, media, and pollsters were notably more unfavorable than in any election since 1988 [9].

Reactions were significantly polarized along voter lines; a large majority of Trump voters reported happiness with his win, while an even larger majority of Clinton voters expressed unhappiness [1]. This division in satisfaction was more pronounced than observed in the 2008 election outcome [1].  The emotional responses were distinct between voter groups.  ![Bar chart contrasting emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters, showing divergent feelings of hope vs. unease/sadness](image5).  Adding to the complexity of the reactions, surprise was a prevalent emotion across the electorate, with a substantial majority of all voters, including both Trump and Clinton supporters, expressing surprise at Trump's victory [10]. ![Bar chart comparing surprise levels among all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters, highlighting widespread surprise](image4).

In conclusion, voter reactions in the 2016 U.S. presidential election were characterized by a mix of hope and unease, notable polarization, and widespread surprise, differing in intensity and direction from previous elections, particularly the more positive reactions seen in 2008.

Immediately following the 2016 election, the emotional responses from Trump and Clinton voters were sharply divided, with overwhelming hope and pride expressed by Trump's supporters [1, 3].  For instance, nearly all Trump voters felt hopeful about his election ![A bar chart illustrating the percentage of Trump voters feeling hopeful and proud, alongside Clinton voters feeling uneasy, sad, and scared](image1), and a large majority also felt proud [3]. In stark contrast, Clinton voters predominantly experienced negative emotions such as unease, sadness, and fear [1, 8].  Notably, while negative feelings were widespread among Clinton supporters across different demographics, those with college degrees reported feeling sadness and anger more intensely than those without degrees [2, 6].

While Clinton voters largely held negative feelings, a segment expressed a willingness to observe Trump's governance, though a significant portion remained fundamentally opposed due to their perception of his character [7].  Trump voters, conversely, showed little apprehension, exhibiting strong confidence in the kind of president he would be [9]. This emotional divergence extended to their expectations for Trump's first term.  Overall, voters leaned towards optimism about Trump's initial term, although less so than they had for Obama in 2008 [4].  However, this optimism was not shared by Clinton voters, the vast majority of whom anticipated an unsuccessful first term for Trump, a view considerably more negative than McCain voters' expectations for Obama in 2008 [10].

In conclusion, emotional reactions to Trump's election strongly differed between voter groups, with Trump voters expressing positive emotions and optimism, while Clinton voters reported negative emotions and pessimistic expectations for his presidency.

Views on the likely success of Trump's first term are significantly divided between Clinton and Trump voters.  An overwhelming majority of Trump voters, 97%, anticipate a successful first term for him, mirroring the optimism Obama voters held for their candidate in 2008 [6].  This contrasts sharply with Clinton voters, among whom only a small fraction, 15%, believe Trump's term will be successful, and a large majority, 76%, expect it to be unsuccessful [4].  This negative outlook is more pronounced than the pessimism McCain supporters felt towards Obama's first term in 2008 [4].  ![The image is a bar chart comparing the percentage of voters' satisfaction for winning and losing candidates from the U.S. elections in 2016 and 2008.](image5) Overall, while a majority of voters were optimistic about Trump's first term [9], this optimism is not shared by Clinton's supporters.  ![The image is a bar chart comparing perceived success between Trump 2016 and Obama 2008.](image4)

Despite the low expectations for Trump's administration among Clinton voters, a majority, 58%, express a willingness to "give Trump a chance and see how he governs" [1, 10]. However, a substantial portion of Clinton voters, 39%, remain unwilling to give him a chance, primarily due to "the kind of person he has shown himself to be" [1, 10].  ![The image is a graphic showing the results of a survey or poll regarding people's willingness to give Donald Trump a chance as president.](image3) This sentiment is less prevalent among older Clinton voters (age 50 and older), with 64% willing to give Trump a chance, compared to 52% of younger Clinton voters (age 18-49) [2].

In summary, Trump voters are largely confident and optimistic about his first term, whereas Clinton voters hold significantly negative expectations, though a slight majority are willing to observe his governance.

Trump voters prioritize health care significantly more than Clinton voters, with nearly three-in-ten Trump voters citing it as Trump's top priority compared to only 12% of Clinton voters [1]. This is further illustrated in the provided data where 29% of Trump voters prioritize health care, markedly higher than the 12% of Clinton voters who feel the same way, as shown in the table ![The table shows that health care is a higher priority for Trump voters (29%) than for Clinton voters (12%).](image1).  While both groups consider the economy and immigration important, Trump voters are more likely to prioritize these issues compared to Clinton voters [6].  Interestingly, unifying the country and addressing Trump's divisive behavior are higher priorities for Clinton voters than for Trump voters [8], [10], with 12% of Clinton voters prioritizing unifying the country and 11% wanting Trump to change his behavior, compared to 5% and 1% of Trump voters respectively, as visualized in ![The table shows that unifying the country and changing personal behavior are higher priorities for Clinton voters than for Trump voters.](image1).

Despite these differing priorities, a large majority (87%) of Trump voters believe they understand where Trump wants to lead the country, contrasting sharply with Clinton voters, where 84% feel Trump's goals are unclear [5].  This divergence is visually represented in the bar chart ![The bar chart highlights that a large majority of Trump voters (87%) believe Trump's goals are clear, while most Clinton voters (84%) find them unclear.](image2), highlighting a significant gap in perception of Trump's vision.  This suggests that Trump voters are more aligned with and confident in his direction, while Clinton voters are largely uncertain and potentially concerned about his leadership.

The differing priorities and perceptions of vision indicate a fundamental divergence in how Trump and Clinton voters view his leadership; Trump voters are more focused on specific policy areas like healthcare, economy, and immigration, believing in his vision, whereas Clinton voters prioritize unity and behavioral change, expressing uncertainty and concern about his direction.  This reflects contrasting expectations and anxieties regarding Trump's presidency based on their political affiliations.

Following Trump's election, starkly contrasting viewpoints emerged regarding race relations. While half of Trump's voters anticipated improvements, a mere 2% of Clinton's voters shared this optimism, with the vast majority, 84%, fearing a decline [1, 5].  ![Clinton voters overwhelmingly believe race relations will worsen, while Trump voters are more optimistic](image3).  This divergence highlights a profound split in post-election expectations concerning racial dynamics in the country.

Turning to confidence in Trump's handling of foreign policy, both Trump and Clinton voters expressed less assurance compared to other issues such as the economy [3].  Specifically, a significant 63% of Clinton supporters reported having no confidence in Trump’s foreign policy decisions [4].  Conversely, among Trump's own voters, only about half, 47%, expressed a great deal of confidence in his foreign policy approach, although a large majority still showed at least fair confidence [7]. ![Trump voters express greater confidence across all issues compared to Clinton voters, but confidence in foreign policy is relatively lower for both groups](image1).

In conclusion, Clinton voters were significantly more pessimistic about race relations and expressed considerably less confidence in Trump's foreign policy abilities compared to Trump voters.

Following Donald Trump's election, a notable divergence in expectations emerged between Trump and Clinton voters, particularly concerning race relations. A significant majority of Clinton voters, specifically 84%, anticipated a decline in race relations under the Trump administration [1].  This stark pessimism is visually represented in survey data, highlighting that 84% of Clinton voters believed race relations would worsen following Trump's election ![84% of Clinton voters believed race relations would worsen](image1).  Conversely, Trump voters exhibited considerable optimism, with half expecting race relations to improve [9], a sentiment mirrored in the data showing 50% of Trump voters anticipating better race relations ![50% of Trump voters believed race relations would improve](image1).

When considering partisan relations, a similar confidence gap is apparent.  Nearly half of Trump voters, 47%, expressed hope for improved partisan dynamics, whereas Clinton voters were considerably less optimistic [8].  In fact, Clinton voters displayed a greater likelihood of anticipating worsening partisan relations compared to McCain voters in 2008, suggesting a heightened concern about political cooperation [4].  Broadly, voters were generally skeptical about the prospect of improved partisan relations in Washington post-Trump's election [6].

In conclusion, Trump voters showed significantly higher confidence in Trump's ability to improve both race relations and political cooperation compared to Clinton voters, who largely anticipated a worsening of both.

Voter expectations for race relations following the 2016 election were largely pessimistic, with a significant portion, $46\%$, anticipating a decline, while only $25\%$ expected improvement [1, 3]. This contrasts with opinions on partisan relations, where expectations were more divided;  $27\%$ of voters believed relations between parties would worsen, mirroring the $27\%$ who thought they would improve, and $45\%$ predicted no significant change [8].  Notably, opinions on race relations were heavily influenced by voter preference, as half of Trump voters were optimistic about race relations improving, whereas a large majority of Clinton voters, $84\%$, foresaw a worsening [1, 5].  ![Voter opinions on whether presidential elections made things better or worse for race relations, showing pessimistic views on Trump's election compared to Obama's and stark partisan divides in 2016.](image4)  In comparison to the optimism surrounding Obama's 2008 election where $37\%$ anticipated better partisan relations, the outlook for partisan cooperation after Trump's election was less hopeful [10].  Even among Trump's own supporters, only $47\%$ expected partisan relations to improve, a figure lower than the $55\%$ of Obama voters who held similar hopes in 2008 [6, 9].  ![Voter expectations for changes in partisan relations in Washington, comparing views after the 2016 and 2008 elections, and highlighting differences between voter groups.](image5)  Despite these divided expectations, a significant majority of voters, across party lines, disagreed with the notion that having highly enthusiastic supporters for a president would lead to less being accomplished [image3]. ![Voter opinions on whether enthusiastic supporters of a president lead to less being accomplished, indicating widespread disagreement with this idea across all voter groups.](image3)  Overall, voters were more pessimistic about race relations than partisan relations following the 2016 election, and they generally did not believe that enthusiastic presidential support would hinder progress.

Republican voters have consistently shown a preference for their party to become more conservative, with a significant $60\%$ desiring a more conservative direction, a trend that has remained stable over recent years [4]. This preference for a conservative direction among Republicans is visually represented, showing a consistent majority favoring 'more conservative' over 'more moderate' since 2008 ![Republican voters consistently prefer a conservative direction](image2). In contrast, Democratic voters are increasingly leaning towards a more liberal direction for their party [9].  Currently, $49\%$ of Democratic voters prefer a more liberal direction, marking a significant increase from previous years and surpassing the proportion favoring a moderate approach [9]. This shift in Democratic preference towards a more liberal stance is evident when comparing current figures to those from past elections, particularly showing the narrowing gap between 'more moderate' and 'more liberal' preferences over time ![Democratic voters are increasingly leaning liberal](image3).  The differing political orientations are mirrored in voter reactions to the 2016 election outcomes.  While $52\%$ of voters overall expressed happiness that the Republican Party retained control of Congress [10], this sentiment is heavily influenced by party affiliation.  A striking $94\%$ of Trump voters were happy with this outcome, whereas $87\%$ of Clinton voters were unhappy [8].  This stark contrast in happiness levels between Trump and Clinton voters underscores the deep partisan divide in reactions to the election results ![Vastly different happiness levels between Trump and Clinton voters](image5).

In summary, Republican voters have consistently favored a conservative party direction, while Democratic voters have increasingly leaned liberal, and these differing orientations are sharply reflected in their opposing reactions to the 2016 election outcomes.

In 2008, a significant majority of voters, across party lines, expressed a desire for political cooperation following Barack Obama's election.  Specifically, nearly eight-in-ten Obama voters and a similar proportion of McCain voters believed that Democratic leaders should collaborate with Republicans, even if it meant disappointing some supporters [9].  This sentiment was also echoed by Republican leaners, with nearly six-in-ten favoring GOP leaders working with Obama [10].  However, in 2016, after Donald Trump's election, this inclination towards cooperation had notably diminished, particularly among Democrats.  Democratic support for their leaders cooperating with the newly elected president was considerably lower than Republican support for cooperation with Obama eight years prior [8]. In fact, a substantial majority of Democrats preferred their leaders to challenge Donald Trump on issues important to them, even if it hindered progress in Washington [4].  This marked a clear shift from the widespread bipartisan desire for cooperation seen in 2008 to a more polarized and confrontational stance in 2016, especially from the Democratic base.  Voter expectations shifted from hoping for bipartisan collaboration in 2008 to anticipating partisan resistance from at least one side in 2016.

Voters perceived the 2016 election as extraordinarily negative, with a staggering $92\%$ reporting more mudslinging compared to previous elections [7, 9]. This sentiment is visually reinforced by data indicating a sharp increase in perceived mudslinging in 2016 compared to prior election years, reaching a high point in voter perception of negativity ![The graph shows that in 2016, 92% of voters believed there was more mudslinging, a significant increase from previous election years.](image1). This widespread negativity during the campaign seems to have influenced how voters evaluated various political entities involved [8].  Reflecting this critical view, only a small fraction of voters awarded the press and pollsters grades of A or B, with many assigning failing grades [3].  Similarly, both the Republican and Democratic parties received low grades from voters for their campaign conduct [5].  These low evaluations are clearly presented in a table format, showing that entities like the press, pollsters, and political parties received notably low percentages of A or B grades from voters, along with poor average grades ![The table displays that the press, pollsters, Republican Party and Democratic Party received low percentages of A or B grades and poor average grades.](image4).  Interestingly, even voters themselves were not spared from this critical assessment, receiving the lowest percentage of A or B grades since 1996 [4]. In summary, the widespread perception of a negative campaign in 2016 corresponded with broadly critical evaluations of political actors and institutions, including the voters themselves.

The unexpected victory of Donald Trump in the election was a significant surprise to a majority of voters, with 73% expressing their astonishment [1]. This surprise is mirrored in the immediate emotional reactions of voters, particularly supporters of both candidates.  For Trump's voters, the dominant feeling was happiness, closely followed by surprise at the outcome, as many described their reaction to his win [4].

![The table shows the emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters, with the number of voters who felt each emotion listed. For Trump voters, the top responses include "Happy" and "Surprised," while for Clinton voters, the top responses include "Shocked" and "Disappointed." The numbers indicate the frequency of each response among 533 Trump voters and 587 Clinton voters.](image3)

In stark contrast, Clinton voters predominantly felt "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" by Trump's victory, highlighting a deep sense of disbelief and negativity [8]. This divergence is further illustrated by the specific emotions felt by each group.  A significant 96% of Trump voters reported feeling hopeful, and 74% felt proud, while a minuscule 7% of Clinton voters felt hopeful and only 1% proud. Conversely, substantial majorities of Clinton voters expressed negative emotions: 90% felt uneasy, 77% sad, and 76% scared [6]. Overall, about half of all voters reported feeling "uneasy" (53%) about Trump's election, while nearly as many (51%) felt "hopeful," showcasing a divided emotional landscape across the electorate [10].

![The image is a bar chart with six emotions: Hopeful, Proud, Uneasy, Sad, Scared, and Angry. Each emotion is paired with a numerical value, probably representing a percentage or score:

- Hopeful: 51
- Proud: 36
- Uneasy: 53
- Sad: 41
- Scared: 41
- Angry: 31

The bars visually represent these values, showing the relative magnitude of each emotion.](image5)

This charged emotional atmosphere was set against a backdrop of what voters perceived as an exceptionally negative campaign. A staggering 92% of voters believed there was more "mudslinging" compared to previous elections, a perception that has dramatically increased since 1992, reaching a peak in 2016 [7].

![The image is a line graph showing the percentage of voters who say there was "more mudslinging" or "less mudslinging" in various election years compared to past elections. The x-axis represents the years (1992, 1996, 2000, 2004, 2008, 2012, and 2016), while the y-axis shows percentages from 0 to 100. The graph has two lines: one for "More mudslinging" and one for "Less mudslinging."

Here are the key points from the graph:

- In 1992, 68% of voters said there was more mudslinging, while 16% said there was less.
- In 1996, the percentages were 49% for more mudslinging and 36% for less.
- In 2000, the figures were 46% for more and 34% for less.
- In 2004, 72% of voters perceived more mudslinging, with only 14% saying there was less.
- In 2008, 54% said more and 27% said less.
- In 2012, the percentages were 68% for more mudslinging and 19% for less.
- By 2016, the percentage of voters who said there was more mudslinging rose to 92%, while those saying there was less fell to 4%.

The graph indicates an increasing trend in the perception that there is more mudslinging in recent elections.](image1)

Interestingly, despite the intense emotions and negative campaigning, voter grades for campaign actors, including Trump himself, were notably harsh, with only 30% giving Trump an A or B and an average grade of C- [3, image4].

![The table presents survey data on public perception and grading of various entities related to a political context. It lists several entities: Trump, Clinton, the Republican (Rep) Party, the Democratic (Dem) Party, the press, the pollsters, and the voters. For each entity, it shows two columns of data:

1. "% who give each A or B": This column represents the percentage of people who rated each entity with an "A" or "B" grade.
2. "Average grade": This column provides the average grade each entity received. Grades range from C+, C, C-, and D+.

Here are the specific percentages and average grades:

- Trump received an A or B from 30% of people, with an average grade of C-.
- Clinton received an A or B from 43% of people, with an average grade of C.
- The Republican Party received an A or B from 22% of people, with an average grade of D+.
- The Democratic Party received an A or B from 26% of people, with an average grade of C-.
- The press received an A or B from 22% of people, with an average grade of D+.
- The pollsters received an A or B from 21% of people, with an average grade of D+.
- The voters received an A or B from 40% of people, with an average grade of C+.

Additionally, there is a note indicating that the data is based on voters and references a specific question (Q24) from a voter callback survey.](image4)

In conclusion, following the 2016 election, Trump voters primarily experienced positive emotions like happiness and hope, while Clinton voters largely felt negative emotions such as shock, disappointment, and unease, reflecting a deeply polarized electorate reacting to a campaign widely perceived as exceptionally negative and harshly grading the involved parties.

The reactions to Donald Trump's victory were markedly different between Trump and Clinton voters, highlighting the deep divisions and perhaps misaligned expectations leading up to the election.  A significant majority of voters across the board expressed surprise at the outcome [3, 5].  This sense of surprise was particularly acute among Clinton supporters, with  $87\%$  reporting they were surprised compared to a smaller but still substantial $60\%$ of Trump voters who felt the same way, as visually depicted in ![A bar chart comparing surprise levels among all, Trump, and Clinton voters, showing higher surprise among Clinton voters](image2).  This widespread surprise suggests that many, regardless of their preferred candidate, did not anticipate a Trump victory.

Looking at the emotional responses, the contrast becomes even sharper.  While half of all voters expressed happiness about Trump's win, and nearly as many were unhappy [10], these feelings were heavily partisan.  An overwhelming  $97\%$  of Trump voters reported feeling happy, while $93\%$ of Clinton voters expressed unhappiness [1].  When asked to describe their feelings in a single word, "happy" was the most frequent response among Trump supporters, whereas Clinton voters frequently used words like "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" [7, 8]. This is further illustrated in ![A table showing the number of Trump and Clinton voters who selected different emotional responses, highlighting 'Happy' for Trump voters and 'Shocked'/'Disappointed' for Clinton voters](image3), which underscores the vastly different emotional landscapes experienced by each group following the election results.

These divergent emotional reactions, particularly the widespread surprise, suggest that pre-election expectations were not aligned with the eventual outcome for a significant portion of the electorate, especially Clinton's supporters. The intensity of negative emotions among Clinton voters, like shock and disgust, coupled with their higher level of surprise, indicates a considerable gap between their anticipated and actual election results. Conversely, while Trump voters also experienced surprise, their dominant emotion of happiness suggests that for them, the unexpected outcome was a welcome one.

In conclusion, emotional reactions to Trump's victory were highly polarized, with Trump voters predominantly happy and Clinton voters largely unhappy, shocked, and disappointed; this emotional divergence, underscored by widespread surprise, reveals a significant misalignment of pre-election expectations, particularly among Clinton supporters who were less prepared for a Trump victory.

Following Donald Trump's unexpected win, a significant majority of voters, including both Trump and Clinton supporters, expressed surprise at the election outcome [5, 9].  Notably, a larger percentage of Clinton voters (87%) were surprised compared to Trump voters (60%), reflecting the unexpected nature of the victory for many [9].  This difference in surprise levels is visually represented, showing that while a majority of both groups were surprised, Clinton voters experienced a higher degree of surprise ![Bar chart showing surprise levels among all, Trump, and Clinton voters, with Clinton voters being the most surprised.](image1).

When voters were asked to describe their feelings about Trump's victory in a single word, "happy" was frequently mentioned by Trump supporters, highlighting their positive sentiment towards the outcome [2]. In contrast, Clinton voters often expressed "shock" or "disappointment," as shown in the emotional reactions of both voter groups ![Table showing emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters, with 'Happy' and 'Surprised' prominent for Trump voters and 'Shocked' and 'Disappointed' for Clinton voters.](image4).  While half of all voters reported happiness about Trump's election, a near equal proportion expressed unhappiness [3].  Unsurprisingly, the vast majority of Trump voters (97%) were happy with his victory, whereas a large majority of Clinton voters (93%) were unhappy, demonstrating a clear partisan divide in emotional response [7].

Despite the division in reactions to Trump's victory, there is a shared expectation for a female president in the future.  An overwhelming majority of voters (79%) anticipate a female president within their lifetime, with no significant difference in this expectation between men and women, or even between Clinton and Trump voters [1].  This widespread expectation is clearly illustrated, with similar high percentages across all demographics, including both Trump and Clinton voters, believing a female president is likely in their lifetime ![Bar chart showing high percentages of all voters, men, women, Trump voters, and Clinton voters expecting a female president in their lifetime.](image2).

In conclusion, while Trump and Clinton voters experienced different immediate reactions to Trump's victory, marked by happiness among Trump supporters and surprise and disappointment among Clinton supporters, both groups largely share the expectation of seeing a female president in their lifetime.

Public perception regarding governmental efforts to combat terrorism has undergone a notable shift, with current ratings reaching their lowest point since the aftermath of the September 11th attacks [2].  This decline signifies a considerable change in sentiment over time.  Initially, concerns about government overreach and the restriction of civil liberties were more prominent [8]. However, there's been a significant transition, and now a greater proportion of Americans express apprehension that anti-terrorism policies "have not gone far enough to protect the country" [10]. This evolving viewpoint is visually represented, illustrating the public's shifting priorities from concerns about civil liberties to anxieties about insufficient protection against terrorism ![a graph showing the change from more concern about civil liberties to more concern about insufficient protection](image3).

This shift in perspective is not uniform across political affiliations. While negative evaluations of government efforts have become more widespread across the political spectrum, partisan divides persist [3].  Republicans, in particular, have demonstrated a heightened concern that anti-terrorism policies are inadequate, a trend that has become more pronounced since 2013 [4]. This partisan divergence is further emphasized in ![a line graph depicting the trends of concern that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough across Republicans, Democrats, and Independents from 2004 to 2015](image1), highlighting the distinct trajectories of concern among different political groups over time.  Notably, liberal Democrats stand out as the only group where opinions are equally divided between concerns of excessive policy reach and insufficient protection of civil liberties [1].

Age also emerges as a significant factor influencing perceptions of government anti-terrorism efforts. Older Americans are more inclined to express negative ratings of the government's performance in this area [9], with a majority of individuals aged 50 and above voicing dissatisfaction [6].  This age-related difference is further elaborated upon in ![a table displaying the opinions on civil liberties vs national protection across different age groups, showing older groups are more concerned about insufficient protection](image2), revealing a clear pattern of increasing concern about inadequate protection with advancing age.  These age-based disparities align with broader survey findings, indicating that older and less educated demographics tend to hold more critical views regarding government initiatives against terrorism ![a table showing survey results about perceptions of government performance in combating terrorism across different demographics like age, education, political affiliation and ideology](image5).

In conclusion, public perception of government efforts to combat terrorism has become more negative over time, with significant variations observed across political affiliations and age groups.

Concerns about government strategies to counter terrorism are notably shaped by both age and political ideology. Younger adults, specifically those under 30, tend to express greater apprehension about the U.S. potentially overstepping boundaries in its involvement in regions like Iraq and Syria [1]. In contrast, older demographics are more inclined to worry about the government not taking sufficient action to stop threats [1].  This divergence is further highlighted in views on civil liberties versus national security, where younger adults are more evenly split, while older individuals are significantly more concerned about ensuring national protection, as illustrated in survey data showing that older age groups are more worried about insufficient protective measures [3, image2].

![Older individuals are more concerned that not enough is being done to protect the U.S., while younger individuals are more concerned about excessive restrictions on civil liberties.](image2)

Moreover, older and less educated Americans often hold more negative opinions regarding the government's effectiveness in reducing terrorist threats [2, 6]. Conversely, positive evaluations are more common among younger individuals and those with higher educational attainment [9, 10].  However, it's important to note a recent trend: negative assessments of government anti-terrorism efforts have become more widespread across the political spectrum [7].  Political affiliations strongly correlate with these perceptions; Republicans and conservatives are more likely to disapprove of governmental efforts, while Democrats and liberals tend to view them more favorably [image3]. Independent voters often hold views somewhere in the middle. Historical data reveals fluctuating approval ratings influenced by political affiliation and presidential terms, as seen in the contrasting approval trends for Presidents Bush and Obama among different political groups [image1].
