![Approval ratings for Presidents Bush and Obama varied significantly among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents over time.](image1)

Over time, public sentiment has evolved. Initially, following events like the Snowden revelations, concerns about government overreach and civil liberties restrictions were prominent [8].  However, more recently, there has been a growing sentiment that government anti-terrorism policies may not be sufficiently robust to protect the nation [5, image5]. This shift is evident across different political affiliations, although the intensity of these concerns varies among groups [image4].

![Public concern has shifted from worrying about government overreach on civil liberties to worrying about insufficient protection against terrorism from 2004 to 2015.](image5)

In summary, perceptions of government efforts to reduce terrorism are significantly influenced by age and political ideology, with older, more conservative individuals generally expressing greater concern about insufficient action, and public sentiment has shifted over time toward prioritizing national protection over civil liberties.

Public sentiment reveals a notable concern regarding the government's approach to anti-terrorism policies, with a significant portion of Americans expressing worry that these measures may not be sufficiently robust to ensure national protection [7].  This apprehension is further illustrated when examining perceptions across different age demographics regarding the government's effectiveness in mitigating terrorist threats, as visualized in survey data.

![This table shows that older age groups are generally more critical of the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats compared to younger age groups.](image4)

As indicated in the survey results, older individuals tend to hold a more critical view of the government's anti-terrorism efforts, with a majority of those aged 50 and above expressing dissatisfaction with the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats [4]. Conversely, younger adults, particularly those aged 18-29, are more inclined to view the government's efforts positively in this regard [4].  Furthermore, when considering the balance between national security and civil liberties, opinions diverge across age groups.

![This table demonstrates that younger adults are more concerned about civil liberties being overly restricted, while older adults prioritize stronger national protection measures.](image5)

Younger adults are notably more divided in their concerns, showing considerable worry that anti-terrorism policies might be excessively restrictive of civil liberties, almost equally as much as they worry about insufficient protection [10]. In contrast, older demographics overwhelmingly prioritize national security, expressing greater concern that policies do not go far enough to protect the country rather than infringing on civil liberties [10].

In conclusion, older age groups are more critical of the government's anti-terrorism performance and prioritize stronger national security measures, while younger age groups are more concerned about potential civil liberty infringements and are less critical of the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats.

Americans' views on government anti-terrorism policies have shifted notably over time and differ across age groups and political affiliations.  Initially, in 2013, more Americans were concerned that anti-terrorism policies went too far in restricting civil liberties [2]. However, this sentiment has decreased significantly, with concerns about policies not going far enough to protect the country now being more prevalent [1, 5]. This shift is visualized in the increasing light yellow line representing concern that policies "Not gone far enough to protect country" and the decreasing dark yellow line representing concern that policies "Gone too far restricting civil liberties" over time. ![This graph illustrates the shifting public opinion on the balance between anti-terrorism policies and civil liberties from 2004 to 2015, showing a trend towards greater concern that policies are not sufficiently protective.](image2)

Notably, this change is more pronounced among Republicans [4].  As depicted in the trend lines, Republican concern that policies do not go far enough has increased more sharply than among Democrats or Independents. ![This line graph displays the trends in concern that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents from 2004 to 2015, highlighting the differing trajectories of these political groups.](image3) Currently, majorities across all age groups except the youngest (18-29) are more concerned about underreach than overreach of anti-terrorism policies, though this concern is most pronounced among older adults [8].  Specifically, as shown in the table, older age groups express greater concern that policies do not go far enough, with 71% of those 65 and older holding this view, compared to only 44% of 18-29 year olds. ![This table summarizes survey data showing the distribution of opinions across different age groups on whether anti-terrorism policies go too far in restricting civil liberties or not far enough to protect the U.S., revealing age-based differences in these concerns.](image4)

In conclusion, public opinion has shifted towards greater concern that anti-terrorism policies are insufficient rather than overly restrictive, with this trend being more pronounced among Republicans and older age groups compared to Democrats, Independents, and younger adults.

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has been largely negative in its assessment of current progress, with a majority consistently viewing the campaign as "not too well" or "not at all well" over the past year [4].  Despite these persistent negative ratings on the campaign's current state, there's a growing sentiment that the U.S. and its allies will eventually achieve success [1]. This positive shift is evident when comparing views from July to December 2015, where the percentage of people believing in ultimate success increased significantly [9].

![Public views on the campaign against ISIS being not too or at all well over time.](image4)

Even though current assessments remain largely unchanged, approval for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has remained steady throughout 2015, with a majority consistently supporting it [6, 8].  The view on ultimate success has become more optimistic recently, as indicated by a notable rise in the belief that the campaign will succeed from July to December 2015 [9].

![Trend of public approval and disapproval ratings for the US military campaign against ISIS over time.](image2)

However, partisan divides are evident in how the campaign against ISIS is perceived. Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to view the campaign as going at least fairly well currently, but majorities across party lines anticipate ultimate success [2]. Republicans, more so than Democrats and Independents, express greater concern that the U.S. military action will not go far enough to stop ISIS [10].  Furthermore, when considering ISIS as a major threat, Republicans perceive it as such more intensely compared to Democrats, although it remains a high concern across all political affiliations [image1].

![Comparison of public opinion on whether the US policy against ISIS will go far enough to stop militants, broken down by political affiliation.](image3)

The public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS reveals a nuanced picture of consistent current disapproval alongside growing optimism for ultimate success, with notable partisan differences in threat perception and the desired extent of US action, but a general consensus on the likelihood of eventual success.

There is a significant partisan divide in how Americans perceive the relationship between Islam and violence, a gap that has widened over time [7, 10].  Notably, Republicans are far more inclined to associate Islam with a higher propensity for violence compared to other religions.  A substantial majority of Republicans, around 68%, hold this view, a figure that has remained consistently high since 2014 and marks a historical peak [5, 9].

![Republican affiliation has increased significantly from 2002 to 2015](image1)

Conversely, Democrats are considerably less likely to share this perspective. While in 2014, 42% of Democrats associated Islam with violence, this figure has decreased to approximately 30% [5, 9]. This decline reflects a growing divergence in opinion between the two major parties [9].  Despite these partisan differences, overall public opinion is closely divided, with 46% of Americans believing Islam is more likely to encourage violence, and 45% disagreeing [3].

![Perception that Islam encourages violence has become nearly equal to the perception that it does not.](image4)

This partisan polarization extends to views on the government's effectiveness in combating terrorism.  Assessments of government efforts have become more negative across the political spectrum since early 2015 [6].  Democrats, who were largely positive in their assessment earlier, have become less so, although they remain the only partisan group where a majority (64%) still believes the government is doing at least fairly well [6]. Independents and Republicans have shown even sharper declines in their positive ratings [6].

![Positive view on government handling of terrorism has decreased from 2001 to 2015.](image3)

Interestingly, despite the declining confidence in government efforts across all groups, Republicans are still more likely to believe their party can handle the terrorist threat better [5].

![Republicans are seen as better at handling terrorist threat than Democrats.](image5)

In conclusion, perceptions of Islam's encouragement of violence are strongly divided along political lines, with Republicans significantly more likely than Democrats to associate Islam with violence, and these differing perceptions align with partisan views on the government's handling of terrorism.

Public perception on whether Islam is more inclined to encourage violence than other religions is divided, with $46\%$ of Americans believing it is more likely, and $45\%$ thinking it is not [5].  These views are not uniform across political affiliations, as demonstrated by the diverging opinions among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents, which have been tracked over time.  The partisan divide is quite pronounced, especially when comparing Republicans and Democrats [8].  Notably, a large majority of Republicans, around $68\%$, believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a view that has remained consistently high [8].  Conversely, only about $30\%$ of Democrats share this belief, a figure that has actually decreased from $42\%$ in 2014 [8].  Independents are more divided, with $45\%$ associating Islam with violence and another $45\%$ not doing so [9].  These trends over time, broken down by political affiliation, are visually represented, showing the widening gap between Republican and Democrat perceptions from 2002 to 2015. ![Line graph depicting trends in perception of Islam and violence among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents from 2002 to 2015.](image1)  Despite these varying perceptions regarding Islam and violence, when it comes to which political party is better suited to handle terrorism, the Republican Party is perceived to have an advantage [6].  Specifically, $46\%$ of the public believes the Republican Party can better address terrorist threats at home, compared to $34\%$ who favor the Democrats [6].  This perspective on party capabilities is further illustrated in a comparison across different issues. ![Chart comparing public opinion on which party is better at handling issues like terrorism, gun control, and climate change.](image3)  In summary, perceptions of Islam encouraging violence are significantly influenced by political affiliation, with a notable partisan divide, and despite these perceptions, the Republican party is generally seen as more capable of handling terrorism.

Partisan divisions are evident in views on the scrutiny of Muslims in the U.S., particularly when examining conservative Republicans, who stand out as the only ideological group where a majority, $57\%$, supports greater scrutiny of Muslims due to their religion [3]. This contrasts sharply with moderate and liberal Republicans, where $59\%$ believe Muslims should not face additional scrutiny [3].  ![This bar chart illustrates the varying opinions across political groups on whether individuals should face additional scrutiny based on their religion.](image3)  This partisan divide is further highlighted when considering the importance of national issues. For instance, Republicans are significantly more likely to prioritize terrorism, defense, and national security, with $41\%$ citing these as top concerns, compared to fewer independents ($28\%$) and Democrats ($23\%$) [4].  ![This table compares the priority of issues across Republicans, Democrats, and Independents, highlighting the Republican emphasis on defense, national security, and terrorism.](image4)

Age also plays a role in these perceptions. Younger adults, aged 18-29, overwhelmingly believe ($80\%$) that scrutiny of U.S. Muslims based solely on religion should not be part of federal counter-terrorism efforts [8].  ![This bar chart shows the percentage of different demographic groups who perceive scrutiny based on religion.](image2)  Moreover, racial differences are notable, with non-whites being more inclined than whites to reject religion-based scrutiny of Muslims; $74\%$ of blacks and $66\%$ of Hispanics oppose such scrutiny, compared to $57\%$ of whites [10].  These varying perceptions underscore a complex interplay between political ideology, demographic factors, and views on national security and religious scrutiny.

In conclusion, perceptions of scrutiny towards Muslims differ significantly across political and demographic groups, with conservative Republicans and older demographics being more inclined to support additional scrutiny, while younger individuals, non-whites, and Democrats are more likely to oppose it, reflecting the partisan divide in prioritizing terrorism as a national issue.

Public concern regarding terrorism as a critical national issue has surged recently [7], marked by a significant increase between December 2014 and December 2015, where it jumped from 1% to 18% among top concerns ![Terrorism concern increased dramatically from 2014 to 2015, becoming a leading public concern.](image1). Despite this heightened worry, evaluations of the government's effectiveness in reducing terrorist threats have declined notably [3, 5], reaching levels unseen since the aftermath of the September 11th attacks [3].  This negative trend spans the political spectrum, though Democrats still hold a somewhat more positive view compared to Republicans and Independents [4]. It's also observed that Republicans are more inclined to identify terrorism as a paramount national problem [1], a sentiment underscored by survey data showcasing partisan variations in prioritizing national issues, with terrorism and national security receiving greater emphasis from Republicans relative to Democrats ![Republicans prioritize defense, national security, and terrorism significantly more than Democrats.](image3).  Moreover, age and educational attainment play a role in these perceptions, as older and less educated Americans are more likely to give lower ratings to government anti-terrorism efforts than their younger and more educated counterparts [2, 6, 8, 10].  This demographic trend is further illustrated in survey results that detail perceptions of government performance across different age and education groups, revealing variations in positive and negative assessments [image4].  Interestingly, a prevailing sentiment among Americans is that anti-terrorism policies may not be sufficiently robust to adequately protect the nation [9].

Overall, perceptions of terrorism have intensified, government anti-terrorism efforts are viewed more negatively, and these perceptions vary across political and demographic lines.

Views on terrorism and economic issues diverge significantly between Republicans and Democrats, as highlighted in recent surveys.  Republicans are notably more inclined to consider terrorism a critical issue facing the nation, with a substantial 41% citing it as a top problem [5]. This contrasts with Democrats, among whom only 23% prioritize terrorism to the same extent [5].  This disparity is visually represented, showing that Republicans prioritize issues like Terrorism, Defense/National Security, and Immigration more than Democrats, while Democrats tend to focus on issues like the Economy and Political Gridlock/Division. ![The table shows that Republicans prioritize Defense/National Security, Immigration, Terrorism, and ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria more than Democrats, while Democrats focus more on Economy and Political gridlock/Division.](image1).

Furthermore, there's a partisan divide in assessing the government's effectiveness in addressing terrorism.  A larger percentage of Democrats (64%) believe the government is performing at least fairly well in reducing terrorist threats, while only 27% of Republicans share this positive assessment [6].  This difference in perception extends to evaluations of government performance across various demographics, with Republicans consistently expressing more negative views compared to Democrats on how well the government is handling the threat of terrorism. ![The table indicates that Republicans are more likely to view the government's efforts in reducing terrorism as "Not too/Not at all well" compared to Democrats and Independents.](image5). Despite these differing opinions, the Republican party is generally perceived as more capable of handling the threat of terrorism [8].

In conclusion, Republicans prioritize terrorism as a national issue more than Democrats, and they are also more critical of the government's efforts to combat terrorism, while Democrats tend to focus more on economic issues and express greater satisfaction with governmental actions against terrorism.

Americans show significant partisan divisions concerning the importance of terrorism as a national issue [6].  Republicans are notably more inclined to consider terrorism, defense, national security, or ISIS as critical problems compared to both independents and Democrats [6]. For instance, a survey indicates that 41% of Republicans prioritize these issues, while only 23% of Democrats share this concern [6].

![This image illustrates the varying importance of issues across political affiliations, highlighting terrorism as more significant for Republicans compared to Democrats and Independents.](image3)

This partisan divergence in the perceived importance of terrorism is mirrored in their evaluations of the government's actions to reduce terrorist threats. Assessments of government efforts against terrorism have declined across the political spectrum since early 2015 [4].  Although overall ratings have dropped, Democrats are still more likely than Republicans and independents to rate the government's efforts positively [4].  This difference in perception is evident in the detailed breakdown of how various political groups evaluate performance, presumably including governmental efforts to counter terrorism.

![This image displays survey results on how different political groups evaluate performance, which can be interpreted as government efforts against terrorism in the context of the question.](image2)

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly shapes both the perceived importance of terrorism and the evaluation of government efforts to combat it.

Independent voters present a nuanced perspective on government regulation. While they are largely divided on the necessity of government regulation to protect public interest versus its potential harm to business, with 48% seeing it as necessary and 43% viewing it as harmful ![Independents are almost evenly split on government regulation.](image1), this contrasts with the viewpoints of both Democrats and Republicans.  A notable 65% of Democrats believe government regulation is necessary, while a significant 61% of Republicans consider it more harmful than beneficial ![Democrats favor government regulation more than Republicans.](image1).

On the issue of economic fairness, a substantial majority of independents, around 70%, perceive the U.S. economic system as unfairly favoring powerful interests [3]. This view is strongly aligned with that of Democrats, with an even larger majority of 85% sharing this sentiment [3].  In stark contrast, Republicans are more inclined to believe that the economic system is generally fair to most Americans, with 63% holding this view ![Republicans are more likely to see the economic system as fair compared to Democrats and Independents.](image4).  Even when considering Republican leaners, nearly half, 46%, acknowledge that the system unfairly favors powerful interests, highlighting a divergence within the Republican demographic itself [6].

In summary, independent voters are divided on government regulation but predominantly align with Democrats in believing the economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, differing markedly from the prevailing Republican view on both matters.

Public sentiment towards both major political parties, particularly among independents, has undergone notable shifts.  Independents who do not lean towards either party are more inclined to hold unfavorable views of both Democrats and Republicans [8].  Interestingly, in 2015, over a third of independents expressed negative opinions about both parties, though this figure has since seen a decrease [9].  ![This graph illustrates the trend of public sentiment, showing that the percentage of people unfavorable to both parties has increased slightly from 1994 to 2018](image1).  Despite this recent decline, those independents without a party preference are still the most likely to dislike both parties, with 37% holding unfavorable views currently [2].

However, it's crucial to distinguish between different segments within the independent voter group.  Independents who lean towards a party exhibit strong partisan characteristics [10].  This is evident in their opinions, where leaners often mirror the views of those who identify directly with the party they lean towards, particularly in their negative views of the opposing party [10, 7].  ![This chart details the opinions of different political affiliations, showing that 'no lean' independents are most likely to be unfavorable to both parties](image3).  In fact, the intensity of dislike for the opposing party has grown among these partisan leaners, mirroring the trend observed among strong party identifiers [7, 6, 1].

In conclusion, while unfavorable views of both parties exist among all independents, they are most pronounced among independents with no partisan lean, whereas leaners exhibit partisan animosity towards the opposing party similar to party identifiers.

Over the past two decades, negative views of the opposing party have significantly increased among both Republicans and Democrats, as well as independents who lean towards either party [8].  This trend is visualized in the growing percentages of unfavorable opinions towards opposing parties across different affiliations from 1994 to 2018, particularly among Democrats and Republicans and their leaners, as shown by the upward trends in the graph ![The graph shows the percentage of Democrats, Lean Democrats, Republicans, and Lean Republicans with an unfavorable view of the opposing party from 1994 to 2018, indicating a clear increasing trend of negative partisanship over time.](image4).  For instance, the proportion of Democratic-leaning independents with very unfavorable views of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled between 1994 and 2018 [2].  Currently, high percentages of both Democrats and Republicans, along with their respective leaners, hold unfavorable views of the opposing party, reaching near all-time highs [3].

Despite the overall rise in negative partisanship, there's a nuance among independents.  While a considerable portion of independents view both parties unfavorably, this share has actually decreased recently [9].  However, independents without a party preference are still more likely to have negative views of both parties compared to those who lean towards a party [10].  Looking at the current landscape, independents exhibit varied opinions: a notable percentage holds unfavorable views towards both parties, while others lean towards one party or view both favorably. This is clearly illustrated in the data visualization showing the distribution of favorability among different political groups ![This image shows the percentage breakdown of favorable and unfavorable views towards Republican and Democratic parties across different political affiliations, highlighting the diverse opinions within the independent category.](image1).

In conclusion, unfavorable views towards the opposing party have risen considerably across all partisan groups over time, while independents present a more complex picture with a mix of negative and positive views towards both parties, depending on their leaning status.

Americans across the political spectrum hold negative views regarding China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, yet this sentiment is notably stronger among Republicans [4]. For example, a significant 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals believe China performed poorly in managing the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and those leaning Democratic, with Republicans being about twice as likely to think China did a very bad job [10].  ![Bar chart showing Republicans more likely to say China did a bad job than Democrats](image1). This partisan divide extends to the perceived impact of China's initial response on the pandemic's global spread, as a substantial 73% of Republicans attribute "a great deal" of blame to China's early actions in Wuhan, whereas only 38% of Democrats share this view [5].  ![Line graph showing negative views on China increased more among Republicans than Democrats over time](image3).  Furthermore, Republicans are approximately twice as inclined as Democrats to advocate for holding China accountable for its role in the outbreak, even if it strains economic relations between the U.S. and China [9].

In summary, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and more inclined to prioritize holding China accountable than Democrats, impacting perspectives on U.S.-China relations.

Views on China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats.  Notably, Republicans are considerably more critical of China's response [1].  A survey conducted in June-July 2020 reveals that a large majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, approximately $82\%$, believe China has performed poorly in managing the coronavirus, compared to $54\%$ of Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party [10].  This disparity is further emphasized by the fact that Republicans are about twice as likely to think China has done a *very* bad job, with $61\%$ holding this view compared to $30\%$ of Democrats [10].  This partisan divide is visually represented, showing that 82% of Republicans/leaning Republicans perceive China's handling as "Bad," while only 54% of Democrats/leaning Democrats share this view ![Republicans are more likely to view China's COVID-19 response as "Bad" compared to Democrats.](image4).

Furthermore, this partisan divergence extends to the question of holding China accountable. A substantial $71\%$ of Republicans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the coronavirus outbreak, even if it damages economic relations. In contrast, only $37\%$ of Democrats share this sentiment [3].  This indicates a stronger inclination among Republicans to prioritize accountability over maintaining positive economic ties with China, as depicted in survey data ![Survey data on prioritizing holding China responsible vs. maintaining strong U.S.-China relations.](image1).  Looking at the trend over time, while both Republican and Democratic unfavorable views of China have increased, the rate of increase appears more pronounced among Republicans, particularly from 2005 to 2020, indicating a widening gap in sentiment over the years ![Trend of unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020.](image2).

In conclusion, Republicans hold a significantly more critical view of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to Democrats, and this divergence has been amplified over time.

Americans are largely critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with a significant majority, around two-thirds, expressing negative views [10].  This sentiment is further illustrated in survey data, where a substantial 64% of respondents rate China's handling of the outbreak as "bad," as shown in the bar chart that breaks down these perceptions across different demographics ![The bar chart indicates that 64% of total respondents rate China's handling as "bad".](image3).  A considerable portion of Americans, approximately three-quarters, believe that the Chinese government's initial response in Wuhan significantly contributed to the global spread of the virus [4]. This is visualized in the bar graph, highlighting that 51% believe China's initial handling contributed "a great deal" and 27% "a fair amount" to the global spread ![This bar graph shows that the majority of respondents believe China's initial handling contributed "a great deal" or "a fair amount" to the global spread.](image2).

This critical view extends to the question of accountability, as half of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it strains economic relations [5, 7].  Conversely, a notable percentage prioritizes maintaining strong U.S.-China relations, even at the cost of overlooking China's role [7].  These diverging perspectives are captured in survey data, where 51% favor holding China responsible, while 38% prioritize strong relations, as depicted in the pie chart ![The pie chart illustrates that 51% of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible even if relations worsen, compared to 38% who prioritize strong relations.](image1).

Political affiliation significantly influences these views. Republicans are notably more critical of China compared to Democrats [4, 7, 8].  A large majority of Republicans, 82%, consider China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak as "bad," whereas this view is shared by 54% of Democrats.  This partisan divide is also evident in the bar chart, showing a stark contrast in "bad" ratings between Republican/leaning Republicans (82%) and Democrat/leaning Democrats (54%) ![The bar chart shows a significant difference in "bad" ratings of China's handling between Republicans (82%) and Democrats (54%).](image3).  Older Americans also tend to be more critical of China's handling of the outbreak compared to younger demographics [4, 8].

In summary, American views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak are largely critical, with a majority blaming China for the virus's spread and supporting holding them accountable, although opinions diverge on prioritizing economic relations versus accountability, and these views are significantly shaped by political affiliation and age.

American views of China have become increasingly negative, particularly concerning China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic [5]. A significant majority of Americans hold unfavorable views of China, with this sentiment rising sharply in recent years [5, 4].  ![Trend of unfavorable views towards China over time.](image4) This negative perception is strongly tied to how Americans perceive China's response to the coronavirus outbreak.  Most Americans believe China dealt poorly with COVID-19 [1] and attribute blame to the Chinese government for the global spread of the virus [7]. ![Bar graph showing percentage of respondents who think China's handling of COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan is bad.](image3)  In fact, a large majority place considerable blame on China’s initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan for the global spread of the coronavirus [7, 5]. ![Bar chart showing proportion of responses indicating blame on China for global spread of coronavirus.](image5)

Despite the souring views and the desire to hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic outbreak [2], Americans are somewhat divided when it comes to economic relations. While a considerable portion supports holding China responsible even at the cost of economic ties [10], there is a slight preference for maintaining a strong economic relationship with China over getting tough on them economically [2]. However, it's noteworthy that a substantial percentage are willing to prioritize human rights in China even if it harms economic relations [6]. ![Chart comparing opinions on China based on political affiliation, highlighting views on COVID-19, US relationship, economic ties and human rights.](image1)  Furthermore, a considerable majority perceive current economic ties between the two nations as being in poor condition [8].

In conclusion, American perceptions of China have evolved to become increasingly negative, largely fueled by the perception of China's mishandling of the COVID-19 pandemic, and while there's a desire to hold China accountable, views on economic engagement remain somewhat nuanced but generally leaning towards a tougher stance.

Americans' negative perceptions of China have significantly worsened over time [9], reaching historic highs recently [2, 7].  This increase is evident across all demographics, but older Americans consistently express more unfavorable views.  For example, while majorities across all age groups hold negative views, those aged 50 and older are notably more negative at 81% compared to younger demographics [3].

![This image summarizes the percentage of unfavorable and favorable views of something across different age groups and political affiliations.](image4)

This trend is also visualized, showing that older age groups consistently perceive it more negatively than younger age groups across "Bad" and "Good" categories, with the 50+ age group showing the highest percentage of "Bad" perception [image1].  Furthermore, unfavorable views among older Americans have increased significantly in recent months [10], and they are considerably more likely to view China as an enemy compared to younger adults [8].

![This graph illustrates the trend of unfavorable views of something over time for three age groups, showing a consistent increase across all groups, particularly for the 50 and older group.](image3)

Examining political affiliations reveals that Republicans consistently hold more negative views of China than Democrats [6].  This partisan gap has re-emerged, with Republicans being more likely to express no confidence in Chinese leadership compared to Democrats [1].  This difference in sentiment is also visually represented, showing a clear divergence in unfavorable views between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans consistently displaying more negative opinions [image5].

![This chart compares the opinions of Democrats and Republicans on various aspects of US-China relations, highlighting the partisan divide in perceptions of China.](image2)

In conclusion, negative perceptions of China have increased substantially over time across all age groups and political affiliations, with older Americans and Republicans consistently holding the most unfavorable views.

Over the past 15 years, negative sentiment towards China has seen a significant surge among Americans, reaching its highest point in recent surveys [2].  This negative shift is a broad trend across the US population [4], and has become even more pronounced recently [10].  Notably, this increase in unfavorable views is evident across both Democrats and Republicans, though Republicans consistently express more negative opinions [1, 7]. As depicted in the trend line, both Republican and Democrat leanings have contributed to rising unfavorable views since 2005, with Republicans showing a steeper increase and consistently higher levels of negativity towards China ![Line graph of Republican and Democrat views of China from 2005 to 2020](image1).  In fact, the gap between the two parties has widened in recent months, with Republican negativity increasing at a faster rate [3].

Examining age demographics, while all age groups show majority unfavorable views, older Americans, particularly those 50 and above, hold substantially more negative opinions compared to younger demographics [9].  As visualized, the 50 and older age group exhibits the highest percentage of unfavorable views, followed by the 30-49 age group, and then the 18-29 age group, showcasing an age-related gradient in negative perceptions of China ![Bar chart showing unfavorable views of China by age and political affiliation](image2). This trend over time also reveals that older Americans consistently hold more negative views, and the increase in negative sentiment since 2005 is most dramatic among this demographic ![Line graph of unfavorable views of China by age groups from 2005 to 2020](image4).  Despite these demographic and political differences, negative views of China are generally consistent across education levels and between genders [8].

In conclusion, unfavorable views of China in the United States have increased dramatically across all demographics and political affiliations, with older Americans and Republicans consistently expressing the most negative sentiments, and these negative views have reached historic highs in recent years.

Public opinion towards China is notably unfavorable, reaching historic highs recently [4]. This negative sentiment has seen a sharp increase in the past few months [2, 10].  Older Americans express considerably more negative views towards China compared to younger demographics [6]. For example, a significantly higher percentage of individuals aged 50 and above hold unfavorable views compared to those under 30 [6].

![Older individuals are more likely to have negative perceptions compared to younger individuals.](image1)

This trend is further illustrated when considering the perception of China's role in relation to the U.S. While younger adults are more inclined to see China as a partner, older adults are much more likely to view China as an enemy [7].  Views on China differ significantly across political lines, with Republicans consistently holding more unfavorable opinions than Democrats [1].

![Republicans have more negative views towards China than Democrats.](image3)

This partisan gap has widened recently, with negative views increasing more sharply among Republicans [2].  The percentage of Republicans who view China as an enemy has substantially increased since 2012, far outpacing the increase among Democrats [9].  Over time, unfavorable views have trended upwards across all demographics, but the increase is particularly pronounced among older age groups and Republicans, as shown in the historical trends [4, image2, image4].

![Unfavorable views towards China have increased for both Republicans and Democrats over time.](image2)

In summary, unfavorable views on China are widespread and have been increasing, with older individuals and Republicans holding more negative views, and these perspectives have become increasingly negative over time.

Negative opinions of China in the United States have surged to historic highs in recent years, with approximately three-quarters of Americans now holding unfavorable views [8]. This negative sentiment has dramatically increased since 2018 [8]. Currently, a substantial majority of Americans harbor unfavorable views, as visualized in a bar chart depicting 73% unfavorable views among the total population ![Bar chart displaying percentage of favorable and unfavorable views of China among different age groups and political affiliations.](image2).

Recent survey data indicates that 81% of Americans aged 50 and older hold unfavorable views, compared to 71% of those aged 30 to 49 and 56% of younger adults [5].

Political affiliation also significantly influences these perceptions. Republicans consistently hold more negative views than Democrats [6], and this partisan gap has widened recently [1]. Although both Republicans and Democrats are increasingly critical of China, the rise in negative sentiment is more pronounced among Republicans [1, 9].  The trend over time for both political groups is evident in a line graph, demonstrating the growing negative sentiment, particularly among Republicans ![Line graph showing trends in views of China among Republicans/leaning Republicans and Democrats/leaning Democrats from 2005 to 2020.](image5).  Currently, a significant 83% of Republicans express unfavorable views, compared to 68% of Democrats [6].

In summary, negative opinions of China have increased significantly over time across different age groups and political affiliations in the United States, with older Americans and Republicans consistently exhibiting the most negative views and the most pronounced increases.

Americans generally hold unfavorable views of China [1], a sentiment particularly pronounced among Republicans compared to Democrats [5]. This partisan divide has widened over time, as seen in the increasing gap in unfavorable views between Republican and Democrat leaning individuals ![This image displays the trend of unfavorable views toward China among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020, showing a widening gap between the two groups with Republicans consistently more unfavorable.](image1).  Similarly, older Americans express more negative opinions of China compared to younger demographics [7], a trend visualized by the increasing divergence in unfavorable views across age groups over the years ![This image presents the trend of unfavorable views across different age groups from 2005 to 2020, indicating that older age groups have consistently more unfavorable views and the gap between age groups has widened.](image2).  Regarding China's management of the coronavirus outbreak, American opinions are largely critical [3]. Republicans are notably more critical of China's pandemic response than Democrats [9], a difference also apparent across age groups, with older individuals expressing stronger criticism [10].  This is visually represented by the higher percentages of "bad" perception among Republicans and older age groups concerning China's COVID-19 handling ![This image shows the percentage of people who perceive China's handling of COVID-19 as "Bad" across different demographics, highlighting higher percentages among Republicans and older age groups compared to Democrats and younger age groups.](image3).  Overall, negative views of China are common in the US, especially among Republicans and older Americans, and this negative sentiment extends to the critical perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic across these demographics.

Americans express significant criticism towards China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with a notable portion believing China's initial response in Wuhan greatly contributed to the global spread of the virus [3].  This sentiment is further illustrated by the survey results, where a considerable percentage of the total population views China's handling as "Bad" rather than "Good" ![This image displays the percentage of people who perceive China's handling of an issue as "Bad" or "Good" across different demographics, showing that overall, 64% view it as "Bad".](image5).

Political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping these perceptions. Republicans and those leaning Republican are considerably more critical of China's COVID-19 response compared to Democrats [1]. A substantial 82% of Republicans perceive China's handling as "bad," a stark contrast to the 54% of Democrats holding the same view [1]. This partisan divide is also reflected in the view of whether China's initial actions in Wuhan were to blame, with 73% of Republicans believing it contributed a great deal to the global spread, compared to only 38% of Democrats [3].  The difference in unfavorable views between Republicans and Democrats is visually represented, highlighting the partisan gap ![This image shows a bar chart that compares favorable and unfavorable views of China across age groups and political affiliations, with Republicans displaying a significantly higher percentage of unfavorable views (83%) compared to Democrats (68%).](image2).

Age also influences opinions on this matter. Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, are more inclined to view China's pandemic response negatively [1, 4].  A notable 73% of individuals aged 50 and older find fault with China’s response, whereas this figure is lower among younger age groups [1].  Specifically, unfavorable views are at 81% for those 50+, 71% for those 30-49, and 56% for those 18-29, demonstrating a clear trend with age ![This image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups, illustrating a clear increase in unfavorable views with age, reaching 81% in the 50+ age group.](image2).

In summary, perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 are significantly influenced by both political affiliation and age, with Republicans and older Americans expressing more critical views.

In the United States, political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of foreign policy partners. Although both Democrats and Republicans agree on the importance of the UK, Republicans express a stronger preference for Israel as a key ally [8]. Democrats, conversely, prioritize relationships with Canada and Mexico [8]. However, when it comes to Germany, partisan views converge, with both sides acknowledging Germany's importance as a foreign policy partner [8]. Interestingly, Republicans show a greater inclination towards closer ties with Russia, with a notable portion preferring Russia over Germany, a sentiment less common among Democrats [4].  This preference also extends to cooperation, as Republicans are more inclined to seek increased collaboration with Russia compared to Democrats [5]. In Germany, political affiliations also influence foreign policy perspectives, albeit with less dramatic divides. Supporters of the CDU/CSU demonstrate a greater willingness to cooperate with the U.S. than those backing the Greens and SPD [3]. Those on the ideological right in Germany tend to have a more positive view of the U.S. overall [3]. Geographically, a significant divergence exists within Germany itself: East Germans exhibit considerably more support for close ties with Russia, whereas West Germans are more inclined to favor a close relationship with the U.S. [7]. Despite these internal variations, there is a general consensus among supporters of major German parties—CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens—that France is a top foreign policy partner, closely followed by the U.S. [9].

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany are influential factors in shaping preferences for foreign policy partners and desired levels of international cooperation.

While both Americans and Germans express a desire for increased cooperation with various nations, their perspectives diverge notably when it comes to Russia and China.  Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to favor greater collaboration with Russia [3], and when choosing between a close relationship with Russia or Germany, the gap is smaller for Germans compared to Americans who clearly favor Germany [8]. ![Americans show a stronger preference for Germany over Russia compared to Germans preference for US over Russia](image2).  In contrast, when considering China, Germans are more inclined to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China, a preference not as strongly mirrored in Americans who are almost equally divided between Germany and China [10].

Political affiliations in both countries further shape these preferences.  In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to prefer close relations and increased cooperation with Russia compared to Democrats [2, 3].  Conversely, Democrats are more likely to favor greater cooperation with Germany [9].  In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to seek greater cooperation with the U.S. compared to those supporting the Greens and the SPD [9].  These partisan differences highlight the influence of political ideology on foreign policy preferences in both nations. ![Party alignment in the US and Germany, showing different levels of support from different parties](image3).  Notably, regional differences within Germany also play a role, with East Germans showing considerably more support for close ties and cooperation with Russia than their West German counterparts [1, 3].  This is visualized in the differing preferences between East and West Germany, where East Germans show a stronger inclination towards Russia [1] and less preference for the U.S. compared to West Germans ![East Germans are more inclined towards Russia in their relationship preferences compared to West Germans](image4).

In conclusion, Germans generally exhibit a stronger preference for cooperation with both Russia and China compared to Americans, with political party affiliations and regional identities within Germany playing a significant role in shaping these differing viewpoints.

In the U.S., political party preferences play a role in shaping views on international cooperation, particularly concerning Germany and Russia.  Democrats are notably more inclined to desire greater cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans [1].  Interestingly, when considering Russia, Republicans in the U.S. show a slightly greater inclination towards increased collaboration than Democrats [3]. This difference in partisan attitudes is visually represented, showcasing varying levels of alignment with certain countries based on political affiliation in both the U.S. and Germany. ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany, highlighting different levels of support among political groups.](image1).

Similarly, in Germany, political leanings influence perspectives on international partnerships. Supporters of the CDU/CSU in Germany are more disposed towards stronger cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [1].  Despite these partisan nuances, when faced with choosing between close ties with Germany or Russia, Americans overwhelmingly favor Germany [8]. However, when Germans are presented with the same choice between Russia and the U.S., the preference gap is narrower, with a considerable portion volunteering a preference for both [8]. This is further nuanced by geographical factors within Germany, where a preference for close ties with Russia is more pronounced in former East Germany compared to the former West [2]. The divergence in regional preferences within Germany regarding Russia is depicted in a comparative chart. ![The image is a bar chart comparing the preferences of people from two regions, labeled "West" and "East," regarding the U.S., Russia, or Both, illustrating regional differences in attitudes towards international partners.](image4).

Considering China, attitudes diverge further. Germans are considerably more likely to express a preference for a close relationship with the U.S. over China, while Americans are more evenly split in their preference between Germany and China [6].  These differing preferences between Americans and Germans when choosing between relationships with Germany/Russia and Germany/China are further illustrated in comparative bar charts. ![This image is a bar chart comparing the opinions of Americans and Germans regarding their preferences between Germany/Russia and Germany/China, showcasing different national priorities in international relationships.](image5).

In conclusion, political party preferences in both the U.S. and Germany influence attitudes toward cooperation with other nations, especially Russia and China, though these attitudes are also shaped by other factors such as regional history and broader geopolitical considerations.

In both the U.S. and Germany, political views significantly shape perspectives on international collaboration, particularly concerning Russia [9].  Within the United States, partisan lines influence preferences, with Republicans showing a slightly greater inclination towards establishing closer ties with Russia compared to Democrats [4]. This is further highlighted by the fact that Republicans are more likely to advocate for increased cooperation with Russia compared to their Democratic counterparts [2].  Conversely, Democrats in the U.S. demonstrate a stronger preference for greater cooperation with Germany; a similar pattern emerges in Germany, where individuals on the ideological right, such as CDU/CSU supporters, express more willingness to enhance cooperation with the U.S. [3].  Overall, Germans are considerably more inclined than Americans to desire greater cooperation with Russia [2].  Ideologically, conservative individuals in both nations tend to view Russia more favorably, whereas liberals generally favor organizations like the UN and EU [9].

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany play a role in shaping attitudes towards cooperation with Russia, with conservative leaning groups generally displaying more openness to Russia than liberal groups.

Americans and Germans hold contrasting perspectives on which nation holds the title of the world's leading economic power [2].  A significant portion of Americans, approximately half, still consider the U.S. to be the foremost economic force, whereas a majority of Germans lean towards China as the leader in economic influence ![This chart visually represents the contrasting views of Americans and Germans regarding the world's leading economic power, clearly showing the higher percentage of Germans who believe China is the leading economic power compared to Americans.](image4).  This divergence in viewpoint extends to their broader opinions on international bodies and countries, with Germans generally exhibiting more positive sentiments towards these entities than their American counterparts [8].  This is particularly pronounced in their assessments of the European Union, where a substantial gap exists in favorable opinions between the two populations [8].  Indeed, when comparing approval ratings, Germans consistently show higher favorability towards the EU, as well as Russia and China, in contrast to Americans ![This chart compares the approval ratings of various international entities including the EU, Russia, and China between the US and Germany, demonstrating that Germans generally have higher approval ratings for these entities than Americans.](image5).  Even within each nation, political beliefs shape these perceptions, especially concerning the EU, where individuals with liberal or left-leaning ideologies in both America and Germany express more positive views compared to conservatives or those on the right ![This image illustrates that within both America and Germany, favorable opinions of the EU are more prevalent among liberals and those on the left, respectively, compared to conservatives and those on the right.](image1).

In conclusion, Americans and Germans differ in their views on the leading economic power and international relationships, with Germans more inclined to see China as the leading economic power and express more favorable opinions towards international entities like the EU and China compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans hold notably different perspectives on the global stage, particularly concerning international organizations and economic influence.  Germans generally express more favorable opinions towards international bodies like the EU, UN, and NATO compared to Americans [10].  This divergence is most pronounced when considering the European Union, where a substantial gap exists between German and American favorability [10]. For example, while a solid majority of Germans view the EU positively, only about half of Americans share this sentiment [10].  This difference in perception is visually represented in the approval ratings, highlighting a significant gap in EU favorability between the two nations, with Germany showing a +18% difference compared to the U.S. ![Germans have a higher approval rating of the EU compared to Americans.](image1).

Views on Russia also reveal a considerable divide, although positive opinions are less common in both countries than for the EU or UN [10].  Interestingly, ideological leanings play a role in shaping these opinions. In both the U.S. and Germany, those on the right of the political spectrum tend to view Russia more favorably, while those on the left are more inclined to favor the UN and EU [3].  These ideological differences are more pronounced among Americans than Germans, indicating a wider political chasm in the U.S. regarding these international entities [3]. The variance in opinions across the political spectrum in both nations is evident in the comparative chart, which shows the "Liberal-Conservative Diff" and "Left-Right Diff" in views of the UN, EU, and Russia. ![Ideological differences influence the favorability of the UN, EU, and Russia in both America and Germany.](image4).

Furthermore, geographical factors within Germany itself contribute to differing viewpoints. Germans residing in former East Germany exhibit a greater inclination towards Russia and a less favorable stance on the EU compared to their counterparts in the former West [5]. This regional variation suggests historical and socio-political influences shape attitudes towards international entities [5]. This regional difference is further illustrated by the preferences of people from West and East Germany towards the U.S. and Russia. ![People in East Germany show more preference for Russia compared to West Germany.](image5).

When it comes to economic power, Americans and Germans diverge sharply in their assessments. Half of Americans consider the U.S. as the world's leading economic power, while a larger proportion of Germans identify China as the dominant economic force [7].  This contrast is starkly illustrated when comparing the percentage of Americans and Germans who believe the U.S. or China is the top economic power. ![More Germans consider China the leading economic power, while more Americans consider the U.S. the leading economic power.](image2).  This difference in perspective may reflect varying economic realities and global outlooks in the two nations [7, 8].

In conclusion, Americans and Germans differ significantly in their views of international organizations and economic powers, influenced by factors such as political ideology, historical context, and geographical location.

Americans and Germans hold contrasting views on the role of military force in international affairs.  A significant majority of Americans believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain order in the world, while only about half of Germans agree with this sentiment [4]. This difference is further highlighted in their views on NATO obligations, where Americans are more inclined to support using military force to defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, a position not shared by a majority of Germans [7].

Conversely, when it comes to defense spending, opinions are also divided, although shifting.  Fewer Americans now believe that European allies should increase their defense spending compared to previous years [1, 3].  Germans themselves are split on whether to increase or maintain their current levels of defense expenditure, a change from 2017 when more Germans were satisfied with their existing defense budget [5].

Despite these divergences in security and defense perspectives, younger generations in both countries share a more positive outlook on the U.S.-German relationship.  Young people in both the U.S. and Germany express more favorable views of the bilateral relationship compared to older age groups [2, 8].

In conclusion, American and German perceptions differ on the necessity of military force and defense spending, but younger generations in both nations hold positive views on the U.S.-Germany relationship.

Differing perspectives on military intervention are evident between Americans and Germans, especially concerning NATO obligations. While Americans lean towards defending NATO allies against potential Russian aggression [1], Germans do not share this view, with an equal percentage believing they should not defend an ally, contrasting sharply with the American stance ![Americans are more inclined to support an action compared to Germans](image1). This divergence extends to the general necessity of military force, with Americans more readily seeing it as essential for maintaining global order [6], a sentiment less embraced in Germany, as shown by the disparity in agreement levels on the necessity of military force ![Americans are more likely to agree with a statement than Germans](image3).

In terms of defense spending, a shift in American sentiment is noticeable.  Although previously a considerable number advocated for increased defense spending by European allies, a larger proportion now prefer maintaining the current levels [2]. This contrasts with the divided German public, who are split between increasing or maintaining their existing defense budgets [10], showcasing distinct trends in both nations' opinions on defense expenditure over recent years ![Trends in defense spending opinions in US and Germany from 2017 to 2019](image4).

In conclusion, American and German public opinions diverge notably on military intervention and defense spending, with Americans generally exhibiting a greater inclination towards interventionism and potentially higher defense expenditures compared to Germans.

Opinions on defense spending have shown interesting shifts in both the United States and Germany.  In the U.S., while half of Americans in 2019 believed European allies should maintain their defense spending, this represents a change from 2017 when more Americans favored increased spending [5].  Germans, however, are more divided on their own defense spending, with public opinion split between increasing or maintaining current levels [7].

![This chart illustrates a general difference in opinion between the U.S. and Germany, with the U.S. leaning towards "Should" and Germany towards "Should not" on an unspecified issue.](image1)

This difference in perspective is further highlighted when considering the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany.  Americans overwhelmingly see these bases as vital for their national security [6], a view strongly held across party lines [10].  Republicans especially view these bases as important [4].  However, Germans are less convinced of the importance of these bases for their own security, with a significant portion disagreeing on their importance [9].  ![This bar chart compares the perceived importance of a subject between the U.S. and Germany, revealing that Americans find it "Very important" more often than Germans.](image3)

Partisan divisions also play a role in shaping these opinions. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to favor increased defense spending compared to those of the Green party, while SPD supporters fall in between [1].  ![This bar chart shows the percentages of support for increased defense spending among CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens parties in Germany.](image4)  In the U.S., Republicans are generally more in favor of increased defense spending in Europe than Democrats, although this view has seen a decrease among Republicans from 2017 to 2019 [8].  ![This line graph tracks the change in opinion on European defense spending increase among Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. from 2017 to 2019.](image2)  Despite these shifts, the belief that Europeans are spending too much on defense remains relatively low and stable in both countries [2].  Overall, fewer Americans now feel European allies need to increase defense spending compared to past years, while Germans are split on increasing or maintaining their defense budgets [3, 7].

In conclusion, opinions on defense spending have evolved in both the US and Germany, marked by a slight decrease in American support for increased European defense spending and a divided German public, alongside existing partisan differences within each nation.

From 2017 to 2019, public opinion regarding national defense spending in both the United States and Germany has seen some shifts.  Americans have become less inclined to believe that European allies should increase their defense budgets, as shown by a decrease from $45\%$ in 2017 to $35\%$ in 2019 who felt this way, while the proportion favoring consistent spending rose notably [4].  Germans, on the other hand, present a more divided view; approximately equal portions of the populace advocate for increasing or maintaining the current levels of national defense expenditure [10].  This divergence in perspectives is visually summarized, showcasing the trends in both countries over these years. ![Americans' support for increased European defense spending decreased while Germans are divided on increasing or maintaining their defense budgets.](image1)

Partisan divisions in the U.S. reveal that Republicans are more inclined to support increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats, although this sentiment has diminished among Republicans from 2017 to 2019 [3].  This partisan trend in the U.S. is further illustrated. ![Republicans' support for increased European defense spending has declined, while Democrats' support remains lower and also slightly decreased.](image3)  In Germany, partisan lines are also evident, with CDU/CSU supporters generally favoring increased defense spending, while Green party adherents are more skeptical [9].  The varying levels of support among different German political parties for increased defense spending are numerically represented. ![CDU/CSU shows the highest value, followed by SPD, and Greens showing the lowest value.](image5)

Furthermore, age appears to be a factor in Germany, particularly concerning the importance of U.S. military bases, where younger Germans are more likely to consider them unimportant for national security compared to older generations [8].  This age-related difference in perception within Germany regarding the importance of a certain topic is highlighted. ![Younger Germans aged 18-29 are more likely to consider it "Not important" compared to older Germans aged 65 and above who consider it "Important".](image4)  Overall, Americans tend to consider the U.S. military presence in Germany as more vital to their national security than Germans themselves do [6], reflecting a broader difference in how each country perceives the importance of such military installations, as shown in a comparative view. ![Americans perceive the subject as "Very important" more often than Germans, who are more inclined to see it as "Not too important" or "Somewhat important".](image2)

In conclusion, between 2017 and 2019, American views shifted towards maintaining rather than increasing European defense spending, with partisan divides showing Republicans more supportive, while German opinions remained split on increasing or maintaining their defense budgets, influenced by both political affiliation and age.

In the United States, political affiliation plays a role in opinions about defense spending, with Republicans historically more inclined to favor increases in Europe, though broad support exists across party lines for the American military presence in Germany [2].  However, backing among Republicans for European allies to raise their defense budgets has decreased between 2017 and 2019 [3].  This shift is visually represented, showing a decline in the percentage of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents who believe that European allies should increase their defense budgets, from 2017 to 2019, though Democrats also show a slight decrease over the same period ![The graph shows the trend of opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding European allies increasing defense budgets from 2017 to 2019](image5).

In Germany, partisan divides are also evident regarding defense spending.  Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increasing defense expenditure, while Green party supporters are more skeptical [5].  Specifically, a notable percentage of CDU/CSU voters supported increased defense spending [1].  Conversely, Green party supporters showed significantly lower support for increased defense spending, with SPD supporters falling in between, reflecting a spectrum of opinions across German political parties ![The bar chart shows numerical values for CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens, potentially representing levels of support for defense spending](image3).

Interestingly, public opinion on defense spending has seen some fluctuation over recent years in both countries.  In the United States, the percentage supporting increased defense spending by European allies decreased from 2017 to 2019.  Germany, on the other hand, witnessed an increase in support for their own defense spending over the same period, although opinions remained somewhat divided  ![The bar chart compares American and German opinions on increasing, keeping the same, or decreasing national defense spending from 2017 to 2019](image1). Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany shape opinions on defense spending, with some shifts observed over time reflecting evolving perspectives within each political group and nation.

Age significantly divides German opinions on the importance of American military bases, with older Germans being more inclined to see these bases as vital for their national security, whereas younger Germans are more skeptical [5, 9].  ![Older Germans are more likely to consider US military bases important, while younger Germans do not](image5). In contrast, political affiliations in the U.S. shape views on foreign policy partners. Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel, while Democrats lean towards Canada and Mexico as key partners, though both groups agree on the UK as a primary ally [4].  Despite these differences, both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. generally view Germany as a significant foreign policy partner [7].  ![Republican and Democrat preferences for foreign partners, highlighting differences in preference for Israel vs Canada/Mexico](image4).  Interestingly, when considering the presence of U.S. military bases in Germany, partisan divides in the U.S. become less pronounced, with both Republicans and Democrats largely supporting the American military presence in Germany [10].  Age in Germany and political affiliation in the U.S. create distinct perspectives on foreign policy and the role of U.S. military bases.

Partisan lines significantly shape opinions on U.S. global engagement, with Republicans more inclined to prioritize domestic issues over international aid, as approximately three-quarters advocate for the U.S. to address its own problems and allow other nations to manage independently [5].  This perspective is further visualized in survey data, where a larger percentage of Republicans believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems compared to Democrats, highlighting a clear partisan divide in attitudes toward international involvement ![This bar chart shows that Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems while Democrats are more divided on this issue.](image3). In contrast, Democrats are more divided, with a notable ideological split; liberal Democrats are more likely to support U.S. assistance to other countries compared to their conservative and moderate counterparts [8]. Evaluations of international issues, such as views on China's handling of the pandemic, also reveal partisan differences, with Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, being more critical than Democrats [6].

Education level, however, presents a nuanced perspective on both global engagement and views on international issues. While education has little bearing on perceptions of China's handling of the pandemic [1], as a majority across all educational levels express criticism  ![This bar chart shows that across all education levels, a majority of people believe China handled the pandemic only fair or poor.](image1), it does influence views on U.S. global engagement.  Individuals with higher education levels are more supportive of the U.S. assisting other nations [10].  Interestingly, more educated Americans are also more critical of the U.S.'s own handling of the pandemic [3].

In summary, political affiliation is a primary determinant in views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of international issues, while education level shows a more complex relationship, increasing support for global assistance yet not significantly altering opinions on specific international events like assessments of China's pandemic response.

Americans' opinions on the handling of the coronavirus outbreak are significantly shaped by their political affiliations.  As indicated by survey data, a large partisan gap exists in how Americans evaluate the United States' response to the pandemic, with Democrats being critical and Republicans praising the efforts [3, 10].  This partisan divide is visualized in a chart, highlighting the stark difference: 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals approve of the US handling, while only 27% of Democrats and Democrat-leaning individuals share this view ![This image illustrates the partisan divide in US COVID-19 handling evaluation.](image2).  Interestingly, this partisan lens is less pronounced when evaluating other nations like Italy, South Korea, and Germany [1].

However, education level also plays a role in perceptions of the US response.  Those with higher education levels, particularly postgraduate and college graduates, tend to be more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic compared to those with a high school degree or less [2].

When it comes to China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, a different pattern emerges.  A majority of Americans, regardless of their education level, express critical views [4, 6].  Older Americans tend to hold even more negative opinions towards China's handling compared to younger demographics [7].  Although political affiliation does influence views on China, as shown in a bar chart detailing opinions by political groups,  majorities across different political affiliations express criticism towards China's handling, with Republicans being more critical than Democrats ![This chart compares opinions on China's COVID handling across demographics and political groups.](image3).  Overall, political affiliation strongly dictates views on the US response, while opinions on China's response are largely critical across the board, with education playing a less significant role.

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly divides Americans' opinions on the U.S.'s COVID-19 response, while views on China's handling are predominantly critical across different education levels and political affiliations.

Political affiliations significantly shape how people perceive the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic by both the U.S. and China [4].  There is a noticeable partisan divide in how Americans assess their own country's response to the coronavirus [2].  ![This chart illustrates the differing opinions on a scale from 'Only fair/poor' to 'Good/excellent' across various demographic groups, highlighting political affiliation.](image3)  For instance, Republicans are considerably more inclined than Democrats to rate the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic positively [8].  Conversely, when it comes to China's response, Republicans are also more critical, with conservative Republicans being especially likely to express negative views [9].  ![This bar chart contrasts 'Only fair/poor' and 'Good/excellent' evaluations across demographics, emphasizing the political divide and its subcategories of conservatism and liberalism.](image5)  This partisan lens extends, although to a lesser degree, to the evaluation of other countries, where Democrats are somewhat more positive about the responses of nations like Italy, South Korea, and Germany compared to Republicans [4].  In conclusion, political affiliation is a key determinant in shaping perceptions of both the U.S.'s and China's effectiveness in managing the COVID-19 pandemic.

There is a notable political divide in the perception of the United States' capacity to learn from other nations in managing the coronavirus outbreak. Democrats are considerably more inclined than Republicans to believe that the U.S. can glean valuable lessons from the international response to the pandemic [6, 5].  This divergence in perspective is further reflected in how each group evaluates the U.S.'s handling of the crisis; individuals who believe the U.S. can learn from abroad tend to have a less favorable view of the nation's performance in managing the outbreak [1].  Interestingly, this pattern holds true within both Republicans and Democrats, suggesting that the belief in learning from others is linked to a more critical assessment of domestic efforts across the political spectrum [8].

This partisan polarization extends to the perception of international organizations, particularly the World Health Organization (WHO).  Democrats are significantly more likely to express trust in information from the WHO and to view its handling of the pandemic positively compared to Republicans [10, 9].  While trust in information from both the European Union (EU) and WHO is generally high, it is notably stronger among individuals with higher education levels, such as those holding postgraduate degrees [3].  Despite overall trust in the EU and WHO, there is a stark contrast with the widespread skepticism towards information originating from the Chinese government [4].

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in pandemic management, directly correlating with views on the U.S.'s handling of the outbreak and trust in international bodies like the WHO and EU.

Americans hold diverse opinions regarding the future global influence of China, the U.S., and the European Union, especially when considering political affiliations.  A notable portion of the public anticipates a decline in China's international standing following the coronavirus outbreak [6].  In fact, half of Americans believe China will have less influence on the world stage after the pandemic, whereas fewer predict the same for the U.S. or the EU [2].
