![Half of Americans anticipate China's global influence will diminish post-pandemic, while fewer expect the same for the U.S. or EU.](image3)

This perspective, however, is not uniform across political lines.  Significant partisan divisions are evident, particularly concerning China’s future influence. Republicans are considerably more inclined than Democrats to foresee a reduction in China's global clout because of the coronavirus outbreak [1].  This partisan gap is further highlighted when considering the perceived impact on the U.S.’s influence. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe that the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis, while Democrats are four times more likely to anticipate a weakening of American influence [3].

![Views on whether the pandemic will increase or decrease US influence are divided along political and educational lines.](image1)

Education also plays a role in shaping these views, especially concerning the United States' role in global affairs.  Generally, Americans with higher education levels are more prone to believe that the pandemic will diminish the country's international influence [10]. These differences in opinion, shaped by political affiliation and education level, underscore a divided American public regarding the future international influence of major global players in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. Ultimately, views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China are significantly shaped by political affiliation and education level, with Republicans and less educated individuals generally more optimistic about U.S. influence and pessimistic about China's, and vice versa for Democrats and more educated individuals.

Opinions on the future global influence of the United States diverge significantly along political lines.  Republicans are considerably more optimistic about America's standing, with twice as many believing the nation's international influence will grow stronger post-crisis compared to Democrats [1]. Conversely, Democrats are four times more inclined than Republicans to anticipate a weakening of US influence [1].  This partisan gap is further highlighted when examining views within the Democratic party itself, where liberals are 20 percentage points more likely than their conservative and moderate counterparts to foresee a decline in U.S. global power [1].  Interestingly, educational attainment also plays a role in these perceptions, as Americans with higher education levels are generally more inclined to predict a decrease in the country's global influence [9]. For instance, a notable percentage of highly educated individuals anticipate a receding global role for the U.S. ![People with higher education are more inclined to think U.S. global influence will recede](image1).

In contrast, when considering China's global influence after the coronavirus outbreak, a different perspective emerges.  Half of Americans predict a decline in China's influence, while a smaller fraction anticipates growth [3]. However, a considerable partisan divide persists in these views as well; Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to foresee a weakening of China's international clout [4].  Age also contributes to differing opinions on China, with older Americans being more inclined to expect a reduction in China's global influence compared to younger adults [4].  These partisan and age-related differences mirror broader attitudes towards China, where older Americans and Republicans often hold more negative opinions [7].  A significant portion across different demographics, particularly older age groups and Republicans, believes China will experience a decrease in global influence. ![Older age groups and Republicans are more likely to believe China will have less global influence](image4).

In summary, predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak are heavily influenced by political affiliation and demographic factors like age and education, showcasing clear partisan divides and generational differences in these expectations.

Many Americans express skepticism regarding China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, as a significant majority believe China has not managed the crisis effectively [3]. This is further highlighted by the fact that few Americans trust the information about the coronavirus originating from the Chinese government [1].  ![China is perceived poorly in handling the coronavirus outbreak compared to other countries and organizations](image5). Looking towards the future, a considerable portion of Americans anticipate a decline in China's influence on the global stage because of the pandemic [9].  Half of Americans predict a reduction in China's global influence, while a smaller percentage believes it will increase [2].  ![Most Americans believe China's influence will decrease after the pandemic](image3).

Partisan affiliations significantly influence these perceptions. Republicans are notably more critical of China's handling of the outbreak and are more inclined to expect a decrease in China's global influence compared to Democrats [7, 5].  Although negative views of China have risen across both parties, Republicans consistently hold more negative attitudes [4].  The diverging opinions across party lines are also evident in broader views on international affairs and the U.S.’s role in solving global issues [8]. ![Partisan division has been growing on the US role in solving world problems](image4).

In conclusion, Americans largely perceive China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decrease in China's future global influence, with significant partisan differences where Republicans hold more critical views.

Partisan viewpoints in the United States diverge significantly when it comes to the nation's engagement in global matters, with these differences becoming particularly pronounced concerning the coronavirus pandemic and its international consequences [6].  A notable divide exists in the perception of whether the U.S. should prioritize domestic issues or assist other countries; while a considerable portion of Americans advocate for focusing inwards, substantial partisan and ideological variations underlie this stance [3].  Notably, there's a clear partisan gap in opinions on whether the U.S. is overextended in its efforts to tackle global challenges [10].

This partisan divergence is further highlighted when examining views on America's role in addressing international issues.  Specifically, Republicans are considerably more inclined than Democrats to believe that the U.S. is excessively involved in resolving global problems [5].  This viewpoint among Republicans has intensified since 2013, indicating a growing partisan gap over time [5]. In contrast, Democrats are more inclined to support the U.S. playing a role in addressing global challenges, showcasing a fundamental difference in partisan philosophies regarding international engagement.

Furthermore, partisan lines are sharply drawn when assessing the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on U.S. global influence [7].  Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to anticipate a weakening of American influence on the world stage as a consequence of the pandemic [10].  Conversely, Republicans are more inclined to believe that the crisis could strengthen the U.S.’s international standing [10].  This stark contrast underscores the deep partisan polarization in interpreting the implications of the pandemic for America's global role, reflecting fundamentally different perspectives shaped by political affiliations.

In summary, partisan views regarding the U.S. role in solving world problems and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak differ substantially, with Republicans increasingly favoring a reduced international role and Democrats advocating for continued global engagement, particularly evident when considering the impact of the pandemic from 2013 to 2020.

While a majority of Americans acknowledge the potential for the U.S. to gain valuable insights from other nations in managing the coronavirus spread [1, 3, 5], significant partisan divisions emerge concerning the extent of this learning [8].  Notably, Democrats are considerably more inclined than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from international responses [8], with a stark contrast evident between liberal Democrats (67%) and conservative Republicans (25%) in this view [4].

![Bar chart showing varying levels of agreement on learning from other countries across demographics](image1)

This partisan divergence is further illustrated when examining survey data across different demographics, revealing that Democrats and those with higher education levels are more likely to advocate for learning from other countries, as shown in the provided bar chart ![Bar chart showing varying levels of agreement on learning from other countries across demographics](image1) and highlighted in survey findings [9].  These partisan differences extend beyond the perception of learning from other countries, influencing opinions on broader global affairs during the pandemic. For instance, liberal Democrats express more critical views on the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak and are more pessimistic about its future global standing compared to their conservative Republican counterparts [6].  This is visually represented, demonstrating the differing opinions between Republicans and Democrats on the U.S.'s job dealing with the virus, learning from other countries, the WHO's performance, helping other countries, and the U.S.'s influence after the outbreak. ![Chart comparing Republican and Democrat views on US coronavirus response, learning from other countries, WHO, helping other countries, and US influence](image5)

In conclusion, partisan views significantly diverge regarding the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic, with Democrats generally more open to international learning and critical of the U.S.'s global performance compared to Republicans.

While a general sentiment exists among Americans that the U.S. should prioritize its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [2], political affiliation introduces a significant divide in these views. Specifically, Democrats show a greater inclination towards the U.S. assisting other countries in addressing their issues [4]. This tendency is even more pronounced among liberal Democrats compared to their moderate and conservative counterparts [4]. Conversely, Republicans largely believe that the U.S. should focus on domestic matters and allow other nations to manage independently [6]. Furthermore, educational attainment appears to correlate with perspectives on this matter. Individuals with higher education levels are more inclined to support the U.S. in helping other countries, with postgraduate individuals showing particularly strong support for international assistance [9]. In contrast, those with lower education levels are more likely to favor the U.S. concentrating on its own problems [9]. Therefore, opinions on whether the U.S.'s role should be to solve its own issues instead of helping other countries are strongly differentiated by both political leaning and educational background.

Currently, there is a significant partisan divide in how Americans perceive the U.S.'s role in global affairs.  A majority of Republicans, specifically 62%, believe that the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems, while a considerable portion of Democrats, 48%, think the U.S. is doing too little [3]. This difference is further highlighted when examining the details within each party, as shown in a bar chart illustrating varying opinions across political affiliations, where 76% of Republicans/Lean Republican believe the U.S. should let other countries handle their own issues, compared to 46% of Democrats/Lean Democrat holding the same view ![Bar chart showing opinions on US role by political affiliation, highlighting differences between Republicans and Democrats](image2).

Interestingly, this partisan gap is a relatively recent development.  In prior years, the difference in these views across political parties was not as pronounced as it is today [6].  Looking at trends over time, a line graph depicts how the opinion that the U.S. does "too much" to solve world problems has evolved, showing a general increasing trend in this viewpoint from 2013 to 2020, reaching 62% in 2020 ![Line graph illustrating the increasing trend of Americans thinking the U.S. does "too much" to solve world problems from 2013 to 2020](image3).  This indicates a shift in perceptions, especially among certain political groups, regarding the appropriate level of U.S. involvement in global problem-solving.

In conclusion, perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems are strongly divided along political lines, with Republicans more likely to think the U.S. is doing too much, and Democrats more inclined to believe it's doing too little, and this partisan divide has become more pronounced in recent years.

Partisan divisions significantly shape opinions on America's global role.  A notable shift within the Republican party reveals that approximately six-in-ten now believe the U.S. is overextended in addressing global issues [1].  This contrasts sharply with Democrats, among whom only about a quarter share this viewpoint [1].  This partisan gap has widened considerably since 2013 [1].  Interestingly, a large majority of Republicans, around 75%, prioritize domestic issues, advocating that the U.S. should focus on its own problems and allow other nations to manage independently [10].

Despite differing views on global engagement, opinions on domestic issues like the coronavirus outbreak also reveal partisan divides.  While a substantial majority of Democrats express criticism towards the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus pandemic, a similar proportion of Republicans offer praise for the country's response [2]. This partisan polarization is further amplified by ideology, as liberal Democrats hold even more negative assessments of the U.S.'s performance compared to other Democrats [2].

However, education level introduces another layer of complexity to these perspectives.  Individuals with higher education levels are more inclined to support international cooperation.  Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other nations in addressing their challenges [6]. In contrast, those with less education, such as a high school diploma or some college experience, are more likely to favor the U.S. concentrating on its own domestic problems [6].  More educated Americans are also more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus, with about two-thirds of postgraduates and college graduates expressing negative views [9].

In conclusion, political affiliation and educational attainment are key factors influencing views on U.S. global engagement and domestic priorities, with Republicans and those with less education favoring domestic focus, while Democrats and the highly educated tend to support international cooperation.

Americans exhibit less confidence in President Biden's capability to effectively manage relations with China compared to other foreign policy challenges [1, 7].  Specifically, around half of Americans express confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China effectively, which is the lowest confidence level among six foreign policy issues tested; for instance, a higher percentage of Americans are confident in his ability to improve relationships with allies ![Americans show less confidence in Biden dealing with China than other foreign policy issues, with only 53% expressing confidence, the lowest among six issues.](image1).  This confidence level is further nuanced across demographics, with women, Black and Hispanic adults, and those with a college degree expressing greater confidence than men, White adults, and those with less schooling, respectively [3].  Partisan divides are also significant, with Democrats showing much higher confidence in Biden on China compared to Republicans [4, 5].

Despite this relatively lower confidence in Biden's handling of China, Americans express substantial concern about various issues in the U.S.-China relationship.  Issues like cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies are seen as very serious problems by half or more of Americans ![Americans perceive cyberattacks, military power, trade deficit, job losses, and human rights policies related to China as very serious issues.](image4).  This indicates that while Americans may have reservations about Biden's approach to China, they are acutely aware and concerned about the multifaceted challenges posed by the relationship.

In conclusion, Americans are less confident in Biden's ability to handle China compared to other foreign policy matters, yet they recognize the significant seriousness of various issues related to China, highlighting a potential gap between perceived leadership and the acknowledged challenges.

Americans exhibit moderate confidence in President Biden's ability to effectively handle China, with approximately half expressing confidence [2].  However, this level of confidence is notably lower when compared to other critical areas such as improving relationships with allies or addressing terrorism, as depicted in the comparative effectiveness ratings across various foreign policy issues ![Confidence in Biden's effectiveness across different foreign policy issues](image5).

Significant partisan divisions exist, with the vast majority of Democrats expressing confidence in Biden on China, while only a small fraction of Republicans share this view [3, 7]. This partisan gap is visually represented, highlighting the stark contrast in confidence levels between Democrats and Republicans ![Confidence levels in Biden across demographics, highlighting partisan divide](image2).  Moreover, concerns regarding China tend to be more pronounced among older Americans [4].

Americans' worries about the relationship with China are substantial and varied.  Issues like cyberattacks from China, the erosion of American jobs, China's growing military might, and human rights policies are frequently cited as very serious problems [5].  These concerns are further illustrated by the ranking of serious problems related to China, where cyberattacks and military power are among the top worries ![Americans' concerns about issues related to China](image3).  Furthermore, limiting China's power and influence is considered a priority for a significant portion of Americans, although it ranks lower compared to domestic issues such as job protection and terrorism, as well as other global concerns like infectious diseases and climate change ![Comparison of priorities, highlighting China's power and influence amongst other concerns](image1).

In conclusion, while around half of Americans are confident in Biden's ability to manage China, this confidence is the lowest among key foreign policy issues, and is heavily influenced by political affiliation, with primary concerns revolving around cyber security, economic impacts, military strength, and human rights.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to effectively manage relations with China is significantly divided along political lines, with a stark contrast between Democrats and Republicans [4, 8].  Notably, a large majority of Democrats express confidence in Biden on this matter, while only a small fraction of Republicans share this view [4]. This partisan divide is clearly visualized when comparing threat perceptions of different nations, where Republicans are considerably more likely to view China as a threat compared to Democrats ![Chart comparing threat perceptions of China across political parties](image1).

Furthermore, confidence levels are not uniform across all demographic groups.  Women tend to exhibit greater confidence in Biden's China policy compared to men, and similarly, Black and Hispanic adults express higher levels of confidence than White adults [6]. Education also appears to correlate with confidence, as individuals with a college degree are more likely to be confident in Biden's approach to China than those with less formal education [6].  These variations in confidence across different demographics are further detailed in survey data illustrating confidence levels across diverse groups. ![Confidence levels across different demographic groups](image3).

Despite the varying levels of confidence in leadership,  Americans broadly recognize a range of serious issues in the U.S.-China relationship [5].  Concerns such as cyber attacks originating from China, the loss of American jobs to China, China's expanding military strength, and China's human rights policies are frequently cited as very serious problems [5, 7, 9].  Interestingly, public perception of the severity of some of these issues, like job losses and human rights, has intensified over recent years [7, 9].  The increasing concern over these issues is reflected in trends showing shifts in the perceived seriousness of China-related problems across political affiliations over time. ![Trends in perceived seriousness of issues related to China by political affiliation from 2020 to 2021](image2). Overall, a substantial portion of Americans view various aspects of the relationship with China as serious problems for the United States. ![Percentage of Americans who consider various issues related to China as serious problems](image4).

In conclusion, confidence in Biden's China strategy is heavily influenced by political affiliation and demographics, while major concerns regarding China center around cyber threats, military growth, job displacement, and human rights issues.

Americans' confidence in President Biden to effectively handle China differs significantly across demographics, particularly along political lines.  Republicans express considerably less confidence in Biden's capabilities regarding China compared to Democrats [2, 3].  Partisan divisions are stark, with a large majority of Democrats expressing confidence, while only a small fraction of Republicans share this view [3].  This partisan gap is clearly visualized, demonstrating how confidence levels diverge based on political affiliation, and also highlighting variations across other demographic factors such as age, gender, and education levels. ![Confidence in Biden varies across demographics, with partisan affiliation being a major factor](image1).  Overall, when compared to other foreign policy challenges, dealing effectively with China ranks lower in terms of public confidence in Biden's abilities, falling below issues like improving relationships with allies and combating terrorism. ![Americans have moderate confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China compared to other foreign policy issues](image4).

Major concerns regarding the relationship with China encompass a range of issues.  Cyberattacks originating from China are a primary worry for many Americans [7, 10], with a significant percentage considering them a very serious problem.  This concern is further underscored when viewed alongside other critical issues such as China's growing military power and the economic impacts, like the loss of U.S. jobs to China, all of which are deemed very serious by a substantial portion of the population [8, 10].  These prominent issues, along with the U.S. trade deficit and China's human rights policies, consistently rank high in American's concerns about China. ![Cyberattacks, military power, trade deficit, job loss, and human rights are major concerns about China](image2).  Furthermore, concerns about China have generally intensified, particularly among Republicans, with issues like job losses seeing a notable increase in perceived seriousness within the Republican demographic [9].  This partisan divergence in concern is evident in the trends from 2020 to 2021, where Republican concern about various China-related issues grew more sharply than among Democrats. ![Republican concern about China-related issues increased more than Democrats' concern from 2020 to 2021](image3).

In conclusion, confidence in Biden's ability to effectively handle China is strongly influenced by political affiliation, and Americans are primarily concerned about cyberattacks, military power, job losses, and human rights issues in the context of the U.S.-China relationship.

Americans hold considerable reservations regarding China's approach to the COVID-19 pandemic.  More than half of Americans express dissatisfaction with China's handling of the outbreak [7]. This perspective is visually supported, revealing that 54% of respondents believe China has performed poorly in managing the pandemic ![54% of respondents believe China has done a "bad job" handling the pandemic](image2). Interestingly, a similar level of criticism is directed at the U.S.'s own pandemic response [10], as indicated by 58% of Americans who rate the U.S. performance negatively ![58% of respondents think the U.S. is doing a "bad job" handling the pandemic](image2).

Beyond pandemic management, a significant point of concern for Americans is China's human rights record.  An overwhelming majority, specifically 90% of adults in the U.S., perceive that the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [6]. This viewpoint is clearly illustrated, with a bar graph showing that 90% of respondents believe China "does not respect" personal freedoms ![90% believe China "does not respect" personal freedoms](image1).  Despite these human rights apprehensions, when considering the priorities for the U.S. in its relationship with China, a substantial 70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should prioritize the promotion of human rights, even if it comes at the expense of economic relations ![70% believe the U.S. should "promote human rights, even if it harms economic relations."](image1).

In summary, American perceptions of China are largely negative concerning both pandemic response and human rights, with a prevailing sentiment to prioritize human rights over economic benefits in the bilateral relationship.

Americans are inclined to prioritize human rights over economic benefits in dealings with China [3], with a significant 70% favoring human rights even if it strains economic ties [3, 4]. This preference is notably strong among both Democrats and Republicans, with about seven in ten from both parties agreeing that the U.S. should champion human rights in China, regardless of potential economic repercussions [6].  ![The chart shows that 70% of people prefer prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China.](image4).  Conservative Republicans especially lean towards prioritizing human rights more than their moderate or liberal counterparts within the Republican party [5, 6]. Similarly, liberal Democrats show a stronger inclination to emphasize human rights compared to moderate or conservative Democrats [6].  ![This image visually represents the percentage breakdown of opinions across different political affiliations regarding prioritizing human rights or economic relations with China.](image3).  When considering economic and trade policies towards China, a larger proportion of Americans advocate for a tougher stance with China rather than focusing on strengthening the relationship [9]. This view is particularly dominant among Republicans and those leaning Republican, with conservative Republicans most emphatically supporting a more assertive approach [9].  ![This chart illustrates the varying preferences across different demographic and political groups on whether to 'get tougher' with China or 'build a strong relationship'.](image2).  In conclusion, while a consensus exists among Americans to prioritize human rights in China, Republicans are more inclined to favor a tougher stance on trade and economic policies with China compared to Democrats.

Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, with a considerable percentage favoring the promotion of human rights even if it negatively impacts economic ties [7].  This sentiment is echoed across different political affiliations, as evidenced by the consistent preference for prioritizing human rights over economic relations within the total, Republican/Lean Republican, and Democrat/Lean Democrat categories ![The bar chart shows that across total, Republican/Lean Republican, and Democrat/Lean Democrat categories, a larger percentage favors prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China](image1).  However, when it comes to economic and trade policies with China, opinions diverge based on political affiliation. Republicans and those leaning Republican are more inclined to advocate for a tougher stance against China [6], especially conservative Republicans [6]. Conversely, Democrats and those leaning Democrat are more likely to support building a stronger relationship with China [6]. This partisan split is visually represented, illustrating that Republicans/Lean Republicans predominantly favor a "Get tougher" approach, while Democrats/Lean Democrats lean towards a "Build a strong relationship" approach in economic and trade policies with China ![The bar chart shows that Republicans/Lean Republicans predominantly favor "Get tougher" approach, while Democrats/Lean Democrats favor "Build a strong relationship" approach in economic and trade policies with China](image5).  In conclusion, while promoting human rights in China is broadly supported across political lines, approaches to trade and economic policies are significantly divided, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and Democrats preferring stronger ties.

Americans generally lean towards a tougher stance on economic policies concerning China [4].  A significant portion, 53%, advocates for the U.S. to "get tougher" with China, while 44% prefer to "build a strong relationship" ![Public opinion is split between getting tougher on China and building a stronger relationship, with "get tougher" being slightly favored overall.](image3). This preference for a tougher approach is notably stronger among Republicans, with 72% favoring it, as depicted in the bar chart showcasing political affiliations  ![Republicans strongly favor getting tougher on China, while Democrats are more inclined to build a stronger relationship, as shown by the green bars representing "get tougher" and blue bars representing "build a stronger relationship" for each political group.](image1) and as textual data confirms, stating that 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents want the U.S. to get tougher on China [1].  Conversely, Democrats are more inclined towards building stronger ties [1].  The perception of current economic relations with China is largely negative, with 64% of Americans viewing them as bad [6], a sentiment visually supported by the high percentage of "very bad" and "somewhat bad" responses in the provided chart ![A significant majority perceives the economic relationship with China as "bad," with "somewhat bad" being the most frequent response.](image2).  Regarding tariffs, opinions are divided along partisan lines; approximately half of Republicans believe increased tariffs on Chinese products are beneficial for the U.S. [2], as evidenced by the higher percentage of Republicans viewing tariffs as "good for the U.S." in the bar chart ![Republicans are more likely to view tariffs as "good for the U.S.," while Democrats predominantly see them as "bad for the U.S.," as indicated by the varying lengths of the green ("good") and blue ("bad") bars across political groups.](image5).  In contrast, most Democrats consider these tariffs detrimental to the U.S. [2].  Overall, when evaluating the effect of tariffs, more Americans lean towards viewing them as ultimately bad for the U.S. rather than good [5].

In conclusion, U.S. public opinion reveals a partisan split on China trade policy, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and tariffs, while Democrats prefer stronger relationships and view tariffs negatively.

Views on tariffs are notably divided along political lines. Republicans are more inclined to perceive tariffs, particularly on goods from China and other foreign nations, as beneficial for the United States [1]. This perspective is further emphasized among conservative Republicans [10].  Conversely, Democrats generally hold a different view, often considering these tariffs to be ultimately detrimental to the U.S. [10].  This partisan divide is visually represented, showing that a larger percentage of Republicans believe tariffs are good for the U.S., compared to Democrats who are more likely to view them as bad for the country ![Republicans are more likely to view tariffs as good for the U.S., while Democrats are more likely to see them as bad](image3).

Similarly, opinions on international students are also influenced by political affiliation.  While a large majority across party lines view international students favorably, Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to see them as a positive asset for U.S. colleges and universities [2].  Specifically, a higher percentage of Democrats believe it is good for universities to accept international students compared to Republicans, as illustrated in the chart ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view international students as good for U.S. colleges and universities](image1).  However, when focusing specifically on students from China, a different picture emerges.  A majority of Americans overall support limiting the number of Chinese students in the U.S., and while Democrats are more opposed to such limitations than Republicans, support for limiting Chinese students exists across both parties ![Support for limiting Chinese students in the U.S. is higher among Republicans than Democrats, but exists across both parties](image5).

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly shapes perspectives on both tariffs and international students, with Republicans generally favoring tariffs and expressing more reservations towards Chinese students, while Democrats are more critical of tariffs and more welcoming of international students, though there is a nuanced view regarding students specifically from China.

Opinions on limiting the presence of Chinese students in U.S. universities are indeed varied among Americans.  A majority of Americans express support for limiting the number of Chinese students studying in the U.S. [7], with 55% in favor and 43% opposed [6]. Older Americans show a stronger inclination towards limiting the number of Chinese students [3], as do those without a college degree [8].  Americans aged 65 and older express the highest level of "no confidence at all" on a certain topic ![Older groups show the highest "no confidence" levels](image1). In contrast, younger demographics, specifically those aged 18 to 29, tend to oppose such limitations [3, image4].  Politically, significant divisions exist, with Republicans being considerably more likely to favor stricter measures against China across various domains [1], including limiting student visas.  Republicans generally express greater "no confidence" ![Republicans/Lean Rep have more no confidence](image1) and are more inclined to view something as "good for the U.S." ![Republicans are more likely to perceive something as good for the U.S.](image3). Conversely, Democrats show slightly more confidence [5] and are less inclined to support limitations on Chinese students [3, image4], with Democrats expressing more "some confidence"  ![Democrats/Lean Dem show more confidence](image1) and a higher percentage viewing something as "bad for the U.S." ![Democrats are more likely to perceive something as bad for the U.S.](image3).  This perspective is echoed in sentiments like, “We rely TOO MUCH on goods from China...We have to stop kissing up to China” [2].  In conclusion, opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, reflecting broader sentiments and confidence levels in relation to China and its leadership.

American views on China have become markedly more negative since 2018 [5, 8].  This shift is evident in the increasing percentage of Americans who express "cold" feelings towards China, rising from 46% in 2018 to 67% by 2021 [8].  Notably, this negative trend is observed across both Republican and Democrat demographics, although it is more pronounced among Republicans [7].

![The graphs illustrate the increasing negative sentiment and priority to limit China's power among Americans from 2018 to 2021, with a partisan divide.](image2)

This growing negativity is further reflected in the increased priority Americans place on limiting China's power and influence, with nearly half considering it a top foreign policy objective [4].  The rise in negative perceptions is driven by a multitude of concerns, with human rights and economic issues being particularly prominent [2, 10].  A significant portion of Americans perceive China's human rights policies as a "very substantial problem" for the U.S., a concern that has intensified since 2020 [1, 6].  These human rights concerns frequently come to mind when Americans think of China, with one-in-five mentioning them, including specific focus on the treatment of Uyghurs [10].

![This bar chart breaks down the various perceptions Americans hold about China, highlighting human rights and economy as top-of-mind issues.](image3)

Economic relations with China are also viewed with increasing skepticism, as many Americans consider current economic ties to be "somewhat or very bad" [9]. This economic unease exists alongside the acknowledgement of China's economic power and manufacturing dominance [9].  A considerable percentage of Americans believe promoting human rights in China should take precedence, even if it potentially harms economic relations, indicating the weight given to human rights concerns in the overall perception of China.

![The graph shows that a significant majority of Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China over strengthening economic relations, even if it harms the economy.](image1)

In conclusion, American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative from 2018 to 2021, driven by major concerns centered around human rights and economic issues.

Americans harbor considerable worries about China, prominently focusing on human rights and economic ties [2]. These concerns are not only broad but also appear to be intensifying across various domains [3].  Issues such as cyberattacks originating from China, China's human rights policies, and the loss of American jobs to China are perceived as grave problems, and these issues have become even more critical in recent times ![The percentage of Americans viewing cyberattacks from China and China’s policies on human rights as a very serious problem have increased from 2020 to 2021](image1).  Public sentiment leans heavily towards prioritizing human rights in China, even if it entails economic sacrifices ![A significant majority of Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China even if it harms economic relations](image3).  Interestingly, confidence in the United States' ability to effectively handle China is notably lower when compared to other global challenges ![Americans express less confidence in dealing effectively with China compared to other global issues such as improving relationships with allies and dealing with terrorism](image2). This lack of confidence is further substantiated by the perception of China as a potential threat and the growing desire to curb its power and influence, a sentiment that has solidified over the years, accompanied by increasingly negative feelings towards China ![Negative sentiment and desire to limit China's power have increased from 2018 to 2021 across party lines](image5).  When Americans think about China, human rights and economic issues are at the forefront of their minds, along with concerns about its political system and perceived threats [2, image4].

Overall, key American concerns regarding China encompass human rights, economic impacts, and China's increasing global power, with these worries showing a trend of escalation over time.

Since 2008, a notable surge in financial optimism has been observed across most Latino subgroups [1].  This positive shift is particularly pronounced when compared to the general public, with Latinos consistently expressing greater optimism about their financial futures since 2004 [3].  ![Latinos show higher increase in financial optimism compared to general population](image3).  This difference in financial expectations has widened to a 20 percentage point gap, the largest observed since these surveys began, with 81% of Latinos optimistic compared to 61% of the general public [3].

The increase in optimism is not uniform across all education levels within the Latino community.  Notably, Latinos who have pursued some college education have experienced a significantly larger increase in economic optimism (+20 percentage points) compared to those with a high school diploma (+9 percentage points) or less education (+11 percentage points) since 2008 [2].  ![Financial optimism changes across different demographic groups](image1).  Examining age demographics reveals that while older Latinos (65+) show a modest increase in optimism, younger Hispanic adults under 30 exhibit a more substantial 13-point rise in their financial expectations [5].  In fact, nearly nine-in-ten Latinos in this younger age bracket anticipate improved financial conditions [5].  Furthermore, both Latino men and women have become more optimistic about their finances since seven years prior, with men showing a more significant increase (+18 points) than women (+11 points) [6].  This widespread optimism is also reflected across nativity, with both U.S.-born and immigrant Hispanics showing a 14 percentage point increase in hopeful views regarding their family's finances, reaching 81% in each group [6].

The data from 2015 indicates a significant portion of Latinos, 23%, foresee their financial situation improving "a lot," marking the highest share expressing such strong optimism since 2004 [4].  An additional 58% anticipate "some" improvement, indicating a broad expectation of positive financial change within the Latino community [4].  This trend of increasing optimism among Latinos compared to the general population is also visible over time, showing a widening gap in favorable opinions [5]. ![Trend of financial optimism for Hispanics and general public over time](image5).  In 2015, a substantial 81% of Latinos anticipated financial improvement, a 14 percentage point increase since 2008, while the general population's optimistic view rose by only 6 percentage points during the same period [9].

In conclusion, financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has significantly increased from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the general population, with variations across education levels, age groups, and gender, but a generally positive trend across all demographics.

Hispanics generally hold an optimistic view regarding their children's financial future, with a significant majority, around 72%, anticipating their children will surpass their current financial standing [6].  This positive outlook is particularly pronounced among those who are currently experiencing favorable financial conditions; individuals with a positive view of their present finances are notably more inclined to foresee improvements in their family's financial situation in the near future [3]. ![People in better financial situations are more likely to expect their finances to improve.](image2) As evidenced in the provided chart, individuals reporting ‘excellent’ or ‘good’ financial conditions express greater expectations for financial improvement compared to those in ‘fair’ or ‘poor’ conditions.  Interestingly, educational attainment presents a nuanced perspective; while a large percentage across all education levels anticipate their children will be better off, high school graduates exhibit the highest level of optimism (79%) compared to those with some college experience (69%) or less than a high school education (71%) [5]. ![High school graduates are the most optimistic about their children's financial future compared to other education levels.](image5) In conclusion, a positive current financial situation and the attainment of a high school education both contribute to heightened financial expectations for the children of Hispanics.

Hispanics have shown increasing optimism regarding their financial situations, particularly after the Great Recession. Since 2011, there has been a notable rise in Latinos expecting their family finances to improve, climbing to 81% in 2015 [2]. This upward trend in financial optimism among Latinos outpaces that of the general population [7].

![Hispanic optimism increased more than general public optimism](image4)

This growing confidence is further reflected in their outlook for future generations, with a significant majority anticipating their children will achieve greater financial success than themselves [3, 5].  However, despite this positive outlook and increasing economic influence, government data presents a mixed economic reality for the Hispanic community. While the unemployment rate for Latinos has decreased from its peak during the Great Recession, mirroring the trend for all Americans, it still remains higher than pre-recession levels and exceeds that of non-Hispanic workers [6].

![Hispanic unemployment consistently higher than non-Hispanic unemployment](image5)

Furthermore, when examining key financial indicators, Hispanic households still lag behind the general U.S. population in median income, poverty rates, and wealth [1].

![Hispanic households have lower income and wealth and higher poverty rate than all US households](image1)

In summary, while Latinos express increasing optimism about their financial future and that of their children, unemployment rates for this group remain elevated compared to pre-recession levels and non-Hispanic groups, and significant disparities in income and wealth persist.

Data indicates that while both Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations experienced improved unemployment rates following the Great Recession, disparities persist [6].  The Hispanic unemployment rate, although decreasing from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in late 2015, remained above the 5% low of 2006 and higher than that of non-Hispanic workers [6]. This trend of consistently higher unemployment rates for Hispanics compared to non-Hispanics is visually represented. ![The graph shows Hispanic unemployment rates are consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates from 2000 to 2015.](image5)  Despite these challenges in unemployment, Hispanics express considerable optimism regarding economic conditions.  Notably, 35% of Hispanics viewed economic conditions as good or excellent, surpassing the 25% of whites who shared this view in a 2015 survey [9].  Furthermore, a significant 72% of Latino adults anticipate their children achieving greater financial success than themselves, demonstrating a strong belief in upward mobility [5].  This positive outlook is further supported by data showing that a large majority of Latinos, particularly those with more education or who are U.S.-born, rate their personal financial situations as excellent or good [4].

However, this optimism occurs alongside persistent economic disparities.  Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining essentially unchanged at approximately $42,491 in 2014 [3].  This income level is notably lower than the median income for all U.S. households. ![The three graphs compare income, poverty and wealth of Hispanic households versus all US households, showing Hispanics consistently lower in income and wealth and higher in poverty.](image2)  Moreover, the Hispanic poverty rate, while improved from its peak in 2010, remained elevated above pre-recession levels in 2014 [3].  These factors contribute to a mixed economic picture where, despite growing economic influence and confidence, Hispanic households continue to experience income and wealth disparities compared to the broader U.S. population.  Although Hispanics show more optimistic economic perceptions than the general public, as seen in their higher percentages considering economic conditions as good or excellent over time, these perceptions do not fully align with the persistent income and wealth gaps [9]. ![The line graph indicates that Hispanics consistently have a higher percentage believing economic conditions are good or excellent compared to the general public from 2004 to 2015.](image1)

In conclusion, while Hispanic unemployment rates have improved and economic perceptions are generally optimistic, significant income and wealth disparities remain when compared to non-Hispanic populations.

Despite improvements since the Great Recession, the economic situation for Hispanic households reveals persistent challenges when compared to all U.S. households.  While the unemployment rate for Hispanics has decreased from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% by the end of 2015, it still remains above the low of 5% seen in 2006 and is higher than that of non-Hispanic workers [1].  ![Hispanic unemployment rates are consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates from 2000 to 2015](image5).  Although declining, the U.S. Latino unemployment rate has not yet returned to its pre-recession lows [8].

Furthermore, when considering household income and wealth, disparities become apparent.  In 2014, the median household income for Hispanic households was approximately \$42,491, a figure that has stagnated since the Great Recession [7].  ![Hispanic median income is lower than all US households in 2014](image2).  This income level is notably lower than the median income for all U.S. households.  Additionally, the poverty rate among Hispanic households in 2014 was 23.6%, significantly higher than the 14.8% rate for all U.S. households [image2], and remains above pre-recession levels [7].  Moreover, Hispanic households experienced a greater percentage decline in net worth during and after the recession compared to other groups, and their wealth accumulation lags significantly behind all U.S. households [7, image2].

In summary, from 2000 to 2015, Hispanic households experienced greater economic challenges than all U.S. households, evidenced by higher unemployment rates, lower median income, higher poverty rates, and diminished wealth.

From 2008 to 2015, Latino communities experienced a notable upswing in their perceptions of economic well-being [1, 7].  This positive shift is particularly evident among younger Latinos, with a remarkable 27 percentage point surge in 18- to 29-year-olds reporting good to excellent financial conditions by 2015 [6].  This trend of improved financial perception among Latinos is further illustrated when compared to the general public over time, as seen in trends from 2004 to 2015 ![The line graph displays that Hispanic financial perception decreased to the lowest point around 2008 and started to increase from 2008 to 2015, and it is higher than the general public’s financial perception in 2015](image2).  The increase in positive financial ratings is not limited to a specific demographic within the Latino community; similar gains are observed across various subgroups, including those based on nativity, gender, and education level [10].  These widespread improvements across Latino subgroups are visually summarized, showcasing the percentage change in positive views from 2008 to 2015 across different segments of the Latino population ![The bar chart illustrates that most Latino subgroups experienced an increase in support or approval from 2008 to 2015](image3).  When comparing the change in financial perceptions between the general population and Latinos specifically from 2008 to 2015, it's clear that Latinos experienced a more significant positive shift ![The bar chart indicates that both the general population and Hispanics experienced an increase from 2008 to 2015, with Hispanics showing a larger increase](image5).  In summary, Latino groups demonstrated a marked improvement in their perceptions of personal financial situations from 2008 to 2015.

Compared to the broader population, older adults show distinct patterns in internet use and device ownership, with adoption rates generally lower in the 65+ demographic [10].  There is a noticeable difference in technology adoption between all adults and seniors, as seen in the adoption rates for cell phones, internet, and broadband, highlighting a digital gap [image5].  Specifically, while cell phone ownership is widespread across all ages, it is less prevalent among seniors, and this disparity is even more pronounced for internet and broadband adoption in older age groups [image5].  Furthermore, the likelihood of going online and having broadband at home diminishes as age increases, particularly when moving from the 65-69 age group to those 80 and older, indicating a significant drop-off in digital engagement with advancing age [image2].  This trend is also reflected in device preferences, as smartphone ownership is considerably lower among seniors compared to all adults, though tablets or e-readers are somewhat more popular among the older demographic [image3]. Despite the lower overall adoption rates, seniors who do embrace the internet tend to integrate it into their daily lives quite regularly [8].  A large majority of older internet users access the internet either daily or almost daily, with a smaller segment going online multiple times a week, demonstrating a consistent engagement once they are online [image1].  Interestingly, a significant portion of online seniors utilize social networking sites, and these users tend to have more active social lives compared to their non-social networking counterparts [3, 9].  However, a notable percentage of the older adult population still does not use the internet at all [image4], and among these non-users, opinions are divided regarding whether this lack of internet access disadvantages them [1].

In conclusion, internet usage and device ownership are generally lower among seniors compared to all adults, but those seniors who are online engage frequently, often daily, in online activities including social networking.

Device ownership and internet usage patterns among older adults present a nuanced picture.  While device ownership among seniors differs notably from the general population [2, 9], with fewer older adults owning smartphones [5], their adoption of tablets and e-readers is comparable to smartphones [7].  In fact, a larger proportion of seniors own either a tablet or an e-reader than a smartphone [7].  This divergence in device preference is visually represented in ![This image shows that while smartphone ownership is higher among all adults, tablet or e-reader ownership is higher among older adults compared to smartphone ownership in their age group.](image4).

Despite potentially lower smartphone ownership, a significant percentage of seniors are embracing the internet.  Over half of seniors, ${\it59\%}$, use the internet, a number that has grown over the years [3].  Among those older adults who do use the internet, a substantial majority, $71\%$, make it a regular habit, going online almost daily [10]. This frequent engagement is consistent even when compared to younger age groups, as visualized in ![This image indicates that while the percentage of daily internet users is slightly lower for the 65+ group compared to younger groups, it is still a significant majority within the older adult internet user population.](image2).  However, when considering the entire older adult population, including those offline, only $27\%$ are social networking site users [1, 8], as shown in  ![This image illustrates that a significant portion of older adults do not go online, and among those who do, a smaller percentage uses social networking sites compared to those who browse without social media.](image3).

In conclusion, although older adults show lower overall rates of device ownership and internet usage compared to younger demographics, those who do engage with the internet tend to be frequent users, and their device preferences lean towards tablets and e-readers rather than smartphones.

Compared to the general adult population, seniors exhibit distinct patterns in device ownership and online engagement. While smartphone adoption is notably lower among seniors, with only $18\%$ owning smartphones compared to a much higher national rate [1], ownership of tablets or e-readers presents a different picture.  ![Seniors have lower smartphone ownership but slightly lower tablet/e-reader ownership compared to all adults.](image3) As illustrated,  $27\%$ of older adults possess a tablet, an e-reader, or both, which is not drastically lower than the $43\%$ ownership rate among all adults as indicated in the bar chart [5].

Internet usage is also less prevalent among seniors; approximately $59\%$ report using the internet, a figure that lags behind the $86\%$ of all U.S. adults who go online [4].  This disparity is further highlighted when considering the frequency of online access. ![Seniors access the internet less frequently compared to younger adults.](image5)  As shown, seniors are less likely to engage with the internet on a daily or near-daily basis compared to younger age groups.  Furthermore, a significant portion of seniors, $41\%$, do not go online at all, and only $27\%$ utilize social networking sites [image2], indicating a lower level of online social engagement compared to younger demographics [2, 10].

However, internet adoption among seniors is not static and has been growing, as evidenced by the increase in internet usage from $35\%$ in 2008 to $59\%$ by 2013 [4]. Broadband adoption has also more than doubled within a five-year span [9]. ![Internet adoption has increased for both seniors and all adults over time, but seniors lag behind.](image4) Despite this growth, the pace of smartphone adoption among seniors remains modest [1], and overall internet adoption rates still trail behind the general population [4, 8].  Notably, subgroups within the senior population, particularly those older, less affluent, or with less education, show even lower rates of online engagement [3, image1].

In conclusion, device ownership and online activity are generally lower among seniors compared to the general adult population, although internet and broadband adoption rates are increasing over time, with significant variations existing within the senior demographic itself.

Seniors exhibit unique trends in device ownership when compared to the general population.  Specifically, a notable observation is that tablets and e-book readers are just as popular as smartphones among older adults, with an equal ownership rate of 18% for each [10].  Interestingly, when considering combined ownership, a larger proportion of seniors, approximately 27%, possess either a tablet or an e-book reader, exceeding the 18% who own smartphones [10]. This contrasts sharply with the broader adult population where smartphones are considerably more prevalent than tablets or e-readers as shown in ![Seniors own tablets or e-readers more than smartphones, unlike all adults](image1).

While device ownership offers insights into technology access, social networking usage reveals how seniors engage online.  Approximately 27% of the total older adult demographic actively participates in social networking [4, 7]. This segment of seniors who use social networking platforms, like Facebook, experience more consistent social connections with their loved ones and tend to socialize more frequently than seniors who do not use these platforms [4, 7].  This online behavior is visually represented in ![27% of seniors use social networking sites](image2), highlighting that over a quarter of seniors are involved in online social networking.

Although device ownership and social networking usage are distinct aspects of technology adoption, it's worth noting that the percentage of seniors owning tablets or e-readers (27%) is numerically similar to the proportion engaging in social networking (27% of total seniors, 46% of online seniors) [10, 4]. This suggests that the adoption of tablets and e-readers might facilitate or correlate with online social activities for a segment of the senior population.

In summary, seniors show a preference for tablets and e-readers over smartphones in device ownership, and around a quarter of all seniors engage in online social networking, suggesting a connection between device preference and online social habits for some.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are indeed increasing, yet they still lag behind the national average [5]. However, it's important to note that these rates are not uniform across all seniors.  As indicated, certain groups within the senior population exhibit adoption rates that are comparable to, or even surpass, those of the general public [7].  Wealthier and more educated seniors are more likely to embrace the internet and broadband compared to those with less income and education [1].

![This table shows the percentage of older adults online and with broadband, broken down by age, education, and income, highlighting disparities within the senior demographic.](image5)

This disparity is further emphasized when considering age.  Younger seniors, particularly those under 75, tend to adopt internet and broadband at rates closer to the general population [8].  Conversely, a significant drop-off in both internet use and broadband adoption occurs around the age of 75 [3].  Those 80 and older, along with seniors with lower incomes and without college experience, are notably less connected to online life [10].  For example, only about 37% of those 80+ use the internet, and just 21% have home broadband [10].  You can see these trends in the table, where the percentages for both going online and broadband adoption decrease as age increases, and also increase with higher education and income levels.  While overall internet usage among seniors has grown to 59% [2], and broadband adoption has more than doubled in five years [6], these figures mask considerable variations within the older adult demographic.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, and are generally lower than those of the general adult population, although certain subgroups of seniors approach or exceed general population rates.

Technology adoption among seniors is not uniform and is significantly influenced by income and education levels [3, 5].  For example, seniors with a college degree exhibit significantly higher rates of internet and broadband adoption compared to those with less education [7].  ![A table displaying internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors, segmented by age, education, and income, clearly showing higher adoption rates with increased education and income levels.](image3). This is further emphasized when comparing seniors who are college graduates to those who have not attended college; a significant gap exists in both internet usage and broadband adoption [9].  Similarly, income plays a crucial role, with seniors in higher income brackets demonstrating much greater adoption rates than those with lower incomes [9].

Even within cell phone ownership, which is generally high among seniors, disparities based on education and income are evident.  While a large majority of seniors own cell phones, smartphone adoption tells a different story, particularly when considering education and income [4]. ![A table presenting cell phone and smartphone ownership percentages among seniors, categorized by age, education, and income, highlighting the influence of these factors on adoption rates.](image5).  Seniors with higher educational attainment and income levels are considerably more likely to own smartphones, while those with lower education and income lag behind [10].  These differences highlight that while overall technology adoption among seniors is increasing, significant variations persist across different socioeconomic groups [6].  Those with lower income and less education, particularly those 80 and older, remain less connected [8].

In conclusion, income and education are critical determinants influencing the adoption rates of internet, broadband, cell phones, and especially smartphones among seniors, with higher levels of income and education correlating with greater technology adoption.

Even though internet usage among older adults is increasing, with 59% of seniors online [9], and broadband adoption more than doubling in five years [2], significant disparities exist. Affluent and well-educated seniors are much more likely to adopt the internet and broadband [1].  This is visually represented in ![Seniors with higher education and income are more likely to go online and have broadband at home](image5), where we can observe that broadband access and internet usage are significantly higher for college graduates and those with higher incomes. Conversely, older seniors (80+), those with lower incomes, and those without college education are less connected [3].

While cell phone ownership is widespread among seniors, reaching 77% [4], smartphone adoption is much lower at only 18% [10], significantly trailing the national average.  As shown in ![Seniors with higher education and income are more likely to own smartphones](image4), smartphone adoption, similar to internet and broadband, is strongly correlated with income and education levels.  For example, smartphone ownership is notably low among seniors in their late 70s and almost nonexistent for those in their 80s and older [8]. Even though cell phone ownership is high across all demographics [4], the digital divide persists when it comes to more advanced devices like smartphones.

Looking at other devices, the trend continues with tablets and e-readers.  As depicted in ![Seniors with higher education and income are more likely to use e-book readers and tablets](image1), seniors with higher education and income are considerably more likely to own tablets and e-book readers [7], highlighting a consistent pattern of technology adoption influenced by socioeconomic factors.  While overall internet adoption among seniors has grown substantially over the years, as seen in ![Internet usage among seniors has increased from 2000 to 2013, but still lags behind all adults](image2), income and education remain critical determinants of both internet and smartphone adoption among older adults, showing a clear digital divide within this population.

In conclusion, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly influenced by income and education, with lower rates observed among those with lower income and less education compared to their wealthier and more educated counterparts and the general population.

Seniors' engagement with the internet and ownership of smartphones are notably influenced by their educational backgrounds.  Those with higher education levels are more inclined to embrace online platforms and broadband services [7].  In contrast, seniors who have not pursued college education often show less engagement in the digital world [4].  For example, a significant disparity exists in internet usage: only 40% of seniors with a high school diploma or less go online, whereas this figure jumps to 87% for college graduates, highlighting a considerable digital divide based on education ![The table shows that seniors who are college graduates have significantly higher rates of going online and broadband adoption compared to those with less education](image2).  This pattern extends to smartphone adoption as well. While overall smartphone ownership among seniors is low, it is considerably higher among the more educated.  Seniors who are college graduates demonstrate a 35% smartphone ownership, which is more than three times the rate of 10% observed among seniors with a high school education or less ![The table illustrates that smartphone ownership is much higher among college-educated seniors compared to those with less education](image5).  Educational attainment is a strong predictor of both internet usage and smartphone ownership among the senior demographic.

Seniors' adoption of internet and broadband services shows a significant correlation with their education levels.  Specifically, a large percentage of seniors who are college graduates utilize online services and have broadband at home [1].  Conversely, those without a college education show much lower adoption rates for both internet access and home broadband [3].  ![This image shows that seniors with higher education are more likely to go online and have broadband at home.](image3)  Similarly, income plays a crucial role, as seniors in higher income brackets are significantly more likely to be online and have broadband compared to those with lower incomes [3].

When considering cell phone ownership, it's evident that cell phones are quite prevalent among seniors across various demographics [7]. Even within older age groups and those with limited internet usage, cell phone adoption remains substantial [7]. However, the picture shifts when we look at smartphone adoption among seniors.  While cell phone ownership is widespread, smartphone adoption is considerably lower in the same demographic [6, 9].  ![This image shows that smartphone ownership is lower than cell phone ownership among seniors and is impacted by age, education and income.](image2)  Similar to internet and broadband adoption, smartphone ownership is notably influenced by both education and income. Seniors with higher education and income levels are significantly more likely to own smartphones compared to their counterparts with less education and lower incomes [2, 4].  This disparity highlights that while basic mobile communication via cell phones has become common, advanced mobile technology like smartphones and internet services are still disproportionately adopted by more educated and affluent segments of the senior population.

In summary, while cell phone ownership is broadly adopted among seniors regardless of education and income, the adoption of smartphones, internet, and broadband is significantly higher among seniors with higher education and income levels.

Seniors' adoption of broadband at home is significantly influenced by both their educational background and household income.  For instance, a large majority of seniors who are college graduates, specifically 76%, are broadband adopters [2]. This contrasts sharply with seniors who haven't attended college, where only 27% have broadband at home [10].  Similarly, income plays a crucial role: seniors with a higher annual household income of $75,000 or more show a much higher broadband adoption rate of 82%, compared to just 25% for those earning less than $30,000 annually [10]. These disparities are clearly visualized, showing that seniors with higher education and income levels are far more likely to have broadband access in their homes ![Broadband adoption at home among seniors based on education and income](image2).  These figures underscore a digital divide among seniors, where access to broadband is not uniform and is heavily dependent on socioeconomic factors. In conclusion, broadband adoption at home is notably higher among seniors with greater educational attainment and higher household incomes.

Among older adults, the popularity of tablets and e-book readers is notably influenced by education levels, mirroring national trends where these devices are favored by college graduates [4].  In fact, seniors who have graduated from college are approximately three times more likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to seniors without college experience [4]. This disparity is evident when examining the usage rates across different educational backgrounds as illustrated in ![The table shows that seniors with a college degree have significantly higher usage rates of both e-book readers and tablets compared to those with lower education levels.](image3).  Looking at broader technology adoption over time, it's clear that while adoption rates have increased across all age groups, younger demographics consistently exhibit higher levels of technology usage, although older adults have shown substantial growth as well over the years ![This line graph illustrates that technology adoption has grown across all age groups from 2006 to 2013, with younger age groups consistently leading in adoption rates, but seniors also showing a significant increase.](image4).  Internet usage among seniors has also increased significantly over the years, although it still lags behind younger adults, demonstrating a general trend of increasing technology adoption across all ages, albeit at different paces and levels [2] and ![This line graph shows the trend of internet adoption from 2000 to 2013 for both all adults and seniors, indicating growth in both groups, but with seniors starting from a lower base and growing at a slower rate.](image2).  In conclusion, education level significantly impacts tablet and e-book reader adoption among seniors, consistent with broader technology adoption trends that show increasing usage across all age groups but with younger, more educated, and higher-income demographics leading the way.

Current workforce technologies are viewed differently depending on levels of educational attainment [6].  Those with higher education are more inclined to see technology as a positive force that enhances their work and career prospects, while individuals without a college education are less likely to share this optimistic view [6].  For instance, only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less believe technology has made their jobs more interesting, compared to a significantly higher percentage of college graduates [7, 10]. Similarly, the perception of increased career advancement opportunities due to technology is also considerably lower among those with less formal education [7, 10].

![Individuals with more education are more likely to perceive technology as making their work more interesting and increasing career opportunities](image1)

These disparities are clearly illustrated when comparing the views of college graduates and those with only a high school diploma or less, as college graduates are substantially more likely to agree that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their career opportunities [10]. In contrast, when considering future technologies like driverless vehicles, a large majority of Americans are aware of their development [2].  A significant portion of the public, about two-thirds, anticipates that driverless vehicles will become commonplace on roads within the next half-century [2, 3].

![The majority of people expect driverless cars to be common within 50 years](image2)

Educational attainment significantly shapes perceptions of workforce technologies, while driverless car technology is largely expected to become widespread in the future.

Workers' opinions on workplace technology are notably different depending on their level of education [8, 10]. Those with higher education degrees tend to view workplace technologies more favorably [10].  This difference is particularly noticeable when considering specific technologies; for instance, a significant gap exists in how positively workers with college degrees view office productivity tools compared to those with only a high school education [4].  In fact, workers with less education are considerably more likely to express negative feelings about the impact of these tools on their careers [3].  Despite these varied perspectives on current technologies, a large percentage of Americans are aware of and expect driverless vehicles to become a common sight in the coming years [1]. In conclusion, education level significantly shapes perceptions of technology at work, while driverless cars are widely anticipated.

Americans are largely aware of and anticipate the rise of automation technologies, particularly driverless vehicles, with a vast majority foreseeing their prevalence within the next half-century [6]. This future expectation is visualized with timelines predicting adoption, as shown ![Timeline for driverless vehicles adoption](image2). However, current experiences with technology in the workplace present a more nuanced picture. Workers today hold mixed views on how technologies have affected their jobs and careers [2]. While many acknowledge the positive impact of tools like word processing software, smartphones, and email [4], visualized by the high percentage of positive responses in ![Positive impact of various technologies](image1), substantial portions express neutral or negative sentiments regarding technology's influence on their career prospects [1].  Indeed, perceptions vary, with some finding technology makes their work more interesting [7], ![Impact on work interestingness](image5) and expands career opportunities [7], ![Impact on career opportunities](image4), while others experience no change or even negative effects.  Furthermore, the impact of technology on work demands is also perceived differently by workers, with some finding work more demanding and others less so ![Impact on work demands](image3).  Importantly, the benefits of current technologies are not universally felt, with those holding higher education levels more likely to perceive technology as a positive force [8].  Therefore, while future automation like driverless vehicles is widely anticipated, present-day experiences with workforce technologies reveal a diverse range of impacts and perceptions among U.S. workers [4, 10].

In conclusion, future automation like driverless vehicles is broadly expected, while current technology experiences are viewed with mixed feelings, varying from positive to negative impacts on work and careers depending on the specific technology and the worker's background.

Workers' perceptions of workplace technologies are significantly shaped by their education level [7]. Individuals with more advanced education tend to view workplace technologies more favorably [1]. College graduates, for instance, are notably more inclined to agree that technology has enriched their work experience by making it more interesting and expanding their career prospects [3]. Specifically, a substantial 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their jobs more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [2].

This disparity is also evident in the perceived impact on career advancement, where 53% of college graduates see technology as a career booster, versus 32% of their counterparts with less education [2].
