In conclusion, while hospitality sectors perceive a greater impact of WiFi on customer loyalty, general merchandise demonstrates a stronger positive impact on sales percentage and EBITA increase.

Store networks with WiFi significantly influence customer experience [4, 6], leading to notable improvements in sales and profitability for retailers [9].  Across various sectors, the addition of customer and associate WiFi results in an average sales increase of 3.4% and a substantial 17.3% rise in EBITA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, and Amortization) overall  ![The table shows percentage increases in sales and EBITA after adding WiFi across different sectors.](image3).

In the General Merchandise sector, the average sales increase is even more pronounced at 6.5%, accompanied by a remarkable 32.1% increase in EBITA ![The table shows percentage increases in sales and EBITA after adding WiFi across different sectors.](image3). For an average retailer in this sector with \$850 million in sales, this translates to a \$55.2 million increase in sales after implementing WiFi.  The EBITA before WiFi was \$52.7 million, which rose to \$74.1 million afterwards, marking a \$21.4 million increase ![The table details average sales, sales increase, EBITA before and after WiFi, and EBITA increase for different retail sectors.](image5).

The Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass (FDCM) sector experiences a more modest but still positive impact, with a 0.9% average sales increase and a 5.8% increase in EBITA ![The table shows percentage increases in sales and EBITA after adding WiFi across different sectors.](image3).  For an average FDCM retailer with \$8 billion in sales, WiFi implementation leads to a \$72 million sales increase.  Their EBITA sees an uplift from \$384 million to \$410 million, an increase of \$26.1 million ![The table details average sales, sales increase, EBITA before and after WiFi, and EBITA increase for different retail sectors.](image5).

The Hospitality sector also benefits, observing a 5.2% average sales increase and a 17.4% increase in EBITA after adding WiFi ![The table shows percentage increases in sales and EBITA after adding WiFi across different sectors.](image3).  For an average hospitality retailer with \$1.1 billion in sales, this means a \$57.2 million increase in sales.  The EBITA increases from \$67.1 million to \$83 million, a \$15.8 million improvement ![The table details average sales, sales increase, EBITA before and after WiFi, and EBITA increase for different retail sectors.](image5).

In summary, adding WiFi enhances both sales and profitability across retail sectors, leading to increased EBITA compared to figures before WiFi implementation.

The digital landscape in India has experienced significant expansion, primarily fueled by the rapid growth in both e-commerce and digital media sectors.  This growth is underpinned by several factors, including advancements in infrastructure, increased smartphone adoption, and the proliferation of digital payment solutions, all contributing to a more convenient and value-driven online experience for customers [3, 5].  The digital sector itself has been identified as the fastest growing, evidenced by a compound annual growth rate of 30% ![Digital sector is the fastest growing with 30% CAGR](image3).

This dynamic growth is further illustrated by the substantial increase in e-commerce sales. In 2014, the total e-commerce sales, including product e-commerce and travel, stood at $11 billion, which impressively surged to $43 billion by 2018 ![e-commerce sales grew significantly from 2014 to 2018](image1). Concurrently, digital advertising spend in India has also witnessed a remarkable ascent.  Between 2014 and 2016 alone, digital ad spending escalated from 34 to 57, showcasing a robust compound annual growth rate of nearly 30% ![Digital advertising spend shows a CAGR of 29.9% and grew from 34 in 2014 to 57 in 2016](image5).

The increasing adoption of digital payments is reshaping the e-commerce transaction landscape.  While Cash on Delivery (COD) was a dominant payment method, its share is projected to decrease, giving way to a rise in debit card usage, EMI options, and the emergence of third-party wallets as preferred payment methods ![Payment methods are shifting from COD to digital methods like debit cards, EMI, and wallets between 2013 and 2016](image4).  This shift towards digital payments, alongside increasing order values and the appeal of EMI options and digital wallets, indicates an evolving consumer behavior in the digital marketplace [6].

Consequently, the e-commerce sector is undergoing a strategic evolution, transitioning from a heavy emphasis on discounting to prioritizing customer experience and retention, and shifting focus from Gross Merchandise Value (GMV) to actual profitability [9].  The growth in digital media and e-commerce between 2014 and 2018 has dramatically reshaped the digital advertising and online sales landscape in India, fostering significant growth and strategic shifts in business approaches.

The expansion of eCommerce sales from 2014 to 2018 was significantly propelled by several converging factors.  A major catalyst was the increasing adoption of digital payment methods.  As stated, "With the increasing digital payments penetration, the share of coD shipments is reducing" [3]. This shift indicates a growing comfort and reliance on digital transactions, moving away from cash-on-delivery, which traditionally limited the reach and efficiency of eCommerce.  This transition was further supported by the rise of "EMI payments" for higher order values and the emergence of "3rd party wallets" as a popular and valuable payment option, echoing trends observed in digitally advanced markets like China [3].

![A bar chart depicting the age distribution of online shoppers in India between 2014 and 2018, highlighting the majority within the 25-34 age group, followed by the 18-24 and 35-44 demographics.](image1)

Simultaneously, fundamental infrastructural developments played a crucial role.  "Infrastructure Development Smartphone Penetration Payments Best Prices available online Convenience Value Prop for customers" [8] are listed as key drivers.  The increased penetration of smartphones broadened access to online shopping platforms, while improvements in payment infrastructure facilitated smoother and more reliable transactions.  These developments, combined with the inherent convenience and value proposition of online shopping—offering "Best Prices available online" [8]—collectively fueled the growth.  This period also marked an "EVOLUTION" [6] in the eCommerce landscape, shifting from initial phases focused on aggressive discounting and customer acquisition to a more mature phase emphasizing "Profitability Consolidation Top horizontal players Few niche players with unique selection Focus from discounting to customer experience Customer acquisition to retention Focus from GM V to Profitability" [7]. This evolution towards customer retention and enhanced experience suggests a deepening market penetration and customer loyalty, contributing to sustained sales growth.

The primary factors driving eCommerce sales growth from 2014 to 2018 include increasing digital payment adoption, infrastructure development, smartphone penetration, and a market evolution towards customer experience and retention, with online shoppers primarily concentrated in the younger to middle-aged demographics.

Initially, eCommerce growth was propelled by infrastructural developments and increased smartphone usage, creating a convenient value proposition for customers [4].  This phase saw a rapid evolution from inventory-led models to broader marketplaces, encompassing diverse sectors like furniture and homes, as depicted in the market evolution diagram ![market evolution stages](image4).  The increasing adoption of digital payments and the shift away from cash-on-delivery further facilitated this expansion [10], with mobile platforms becoming central to transactions, evident from the high percentage of transactions occurring via smartphones for top eCommerce companies ![high mobile transaction share](image2). As the market matures, the focus is shifting from aggressive customer acquisition through discounting to prioritizing customer experience and retention, aiming for profitability and consolidation among key players [3, 1].  A significant demographic driving this growth is the 26-35 age group, which constitutes the largest segment of online consumers, indicating a tech-savvy and digitally engaged population fueling eCommerce sales ![dominant age group](image3].  This evolution has translated to substantial revenue growth across product eCommerce and travel sectors, demonstrating the tangible outcomes of these market developments and consumer trends ![eCommerce revenue growth](image5]. The expansion of eCommerce sales is intrinsically linked to the market's evolutionary stages, powered by infrastructural advancements and payment solutions, with the dominant 26-35 age group playing a crucial role in shaping its trajectory.

The payments landscape in India is undergoing a significant transformation [10].  Notably, Cash on Delivery (COD) is becoming less prevalent as digital payment methods gain traction [6]. This shift is accompanied by an increase in the adoption of EMI payments for higher order values and the emergence of third-party wallets as popular alternatives, mirroring trends observed in China [6].  ![The decline of Cash on Delivery (COD) and rise of digital payment methods like UPI, wallets, cards and EMI in e-commerce transactions](image1).  This change is partly fueled by the increasing number of debit card users in India [4].  ![A line graph showing the increasing number of debit card users in India over the years](image2).  The e-commerce sector itself presents substantial opportunities across various categories [3, 8].  ![A pie chart illustrating the category-wise breakup of online retail in India, showcasing different product categories and their market share](image3). These evolving payment preferences and expanding consumer demographics are key factors shaping the growing e-commerce opportunities in India.

The online retail payment landscape in India experienced a notable shift from 2013 to 2016, characterized by a decrease in traditional methods like Cash on Delivery (COD) and credit cards, and a rise in digital payment solutions [6].  This transition is evident in the projected figures, where COD declined from 60% to 50%, and credit cards from 16% to 12% of transactions. Simultaneously, debit card usage was expected to increase from 12% to 15%, and the adoption of newer methods like EMI and 3rd party wallets was anticipated to grow significantly, with 3rd party wallets projected to jump from 0% to 7% of payment methods used  ![Shift towards digital payments](image4).  This evolution was supported by increasing smartphone penetration and infrastructure development, making online payments more convenient and accessible [2].  Furthermore, the number of debit card users in India was on the rise, increasing from 399 million in 2014 to a projected 584.02 million in 2016, indicating a growing base for digital transactions ![Increase in debit card users](image3).

Examining the categories driving online retail transactions, Fashion, Footwear & Accessories emerged as a dominant segment, accounting for 35% of transactions, followed by Books at 21%  ![Transaction categories distribution](image5).  However, when considering the gross margin contributions, Mobile, Tablets & Accessories led with 35%, while Fashion, Footwear & Accessories contributed 28%  ![Gross margin by product categories](image2). This suggests that while Fashion might drive a larger volume of transactions, categories like Mobile and Accessories are more profitable. The online retail sector was also seeing a strategic shift from prioritizing Gross Merchandise Value (GMV) to focusing on profitability and enhancing customer experience, indicating a move towards sustainable growth and efficiency [1].

In conclusion, from 2013 to 2016, India's online retail sector saw a move away from COD towards digital payments, with debit cards and emerging wallets gaining traction, while Fashion and Books led in transaction volume, Mobile and Accessories were key for gross margin, reflecting an industry-wide pivot towards profitability and customer retention.

Driven by increasing digital payment methods, a notable shift is occurring in India's online retail sector, moving away from Cash on Delivery (COD) [10]. This evolution is significantly influenced by the expanding base of debit card users in India [6], shaping the payments landscape [4, 5]. Consumers now anticipate a seamless and comprehensive experience [3], where payment options play a crucial role in the value proposition of e-commerce platforms [2].  The projection that half of Indians would possess debit cards by 2016 [10] underscored a pivotal change in payment behavior, prompting e-commerce platforms to integrate diverse payment solutions beyond COD, such as EMI options and third-party wallets, to cater to evolving consumer preferences and enhance convenience.

The projected shift towards digital payments and increased debit card usage from 2013 to 2016 was expected to push e-commerce platforms to integrate diverse payment options and adapt to changing consumer payment behaviors in India.

Examining online retail category performance reveals a disparity between transaction volumes and gross margin contributions.  Categories like Fashion, Footwear & Accessories and Books show high transaction volumes, as depicted in the transaction pie chart ![This image shows the percentage of transactions by category, highlighting Fashion, Footwear & Accessories and Books as high volume categories.](image3).  However, when looking at gross margin contribution, Mobile, Tablets & Accessories and Fashion, Footwear & Accessories lead, as shown in the gross margin pie chart ![This image shows the percentage of gross margin contribution by category, highlighting Mobile, Tablets & Accessories and Fashion, Footwear & Accessories as high gross margin contributors.](image1). This suggests that while Fashion drives a significant portion of transactions, categories like Mobile, Tablets & Accessories are more profitable per transaction. This difference is critical for the two-sided business model of e-commerce, which relies on both attracting a wide selection of supply and fulfilling consumer demand, as illustrated in the business model diagram ![This image illustrates a two-sided e-commerce business model, showing the flow from supply to demand through a platform, emphasizing critical success factors like selection and experience.](image4). To optimize profitability, e-commerce platforms might need to shift focus from simply chasing Gross Merchandise Value (GMV) to prioritizing profitability, as mentioned in quote [2], and enhancing customer experience rather than just deep discounting.  This is further emphasized by the need for a robust ecosystem focusing on retention and logistics efficiency [1]. Ultimately, the varied relationships between category transaction volumes and gross margin contributions necessitate strategic decisions in supply chain management, marketing, and customer engagement to ensure sustainable and profitable growth in the e-commerce sector, aligning with the expectation of consumers for an "ALL TO ALL EXPERIENCE" [5].

The category-wise transaction volumes in online retail do not directly correlate with gross margin contributions, indicating that high transaction volume categories are not necessarily the most profitable, which implies e-commerce models must strategically balance volume and margin for overall profitability.

Consumers in today's digital marketplace have elevated expectations for their online shopping experiences [4]. They anticipate a seamless and comprehensive "ALL TO ALL EXPERIENCE" [4], which is facilitated by platforms striving for critical success factors such as offering the "Widest Selection", a "Great Shopping Experience", and competitive "Pricing" ![This image illustrates the critical success factors for an e-commerce platform within its two-sided business model, emphasizing selection, experience, and pricing.](image1).  Consumers often initiate their purchase journey with online research via smartphones and by consulting product reviews on social media. Subsequently, they engage in comparison shopping across different sites before deciding to buy either online or in a physical store, as depicted in ![This image outlines the typical consumer decision process, involving online research, social media reviews, comparison shopping, and the final purchase decision.](image2).  This demand for an integrated experience is further emphasized by the "Anywhere, Anytime, Any Channel" paradigm, highlighting the need for accessibility across various devices and platforms ![This image represents the concept of 'Anywhere, Anytime, Any Channel' access for consumers, showing various devices and platforms.](image3). E-commerce businesses are recognizing the shift from merely offering discounts to prioritizing customer experience and retention to meet these sophisticated consumer demands [3].  Ultimately, the critical success factors of an e-commerce platform are intrinsically linked to fulfilling and exceeding the diverse expectations of modern online consumers.

The digital sector has emerged as a powerhouse of growth, marking its territory as the most rapidly expanding segment within the broader media landscape [2, 5]. This dynamic expansion is highlighted by an impressive 30% compound annual growth rate, underscoring its swift ascent in advertising expenditure ![Digital sector is the fastest growing sector with 30% CAGR](image5). Examining the advertising spend across various media channels from 2012 to 2016 reveals digital's commanding lead over conventional categories.  The growth in digital advertising expenditure significantly outstripped print, television, out-of-home (OOH), and radio, demonstrated by its exceptional CAGR of 29.9% ![Digital media shows the highest CAGR compared to other media categories from 2012 to 2016](image4). This digital surge is intrinsically linked to the escalating adoption of mobile commerce [9].  The substantial increase in smartphone users, from 120 million in 2014 to 380 million in 2016, illustrates the broadening foundation for digital interaction and consumption ![Smartphone users significantly increased from 2014 to 2016](image3).

The digital sector experienced the most substantial growth compared to other media categories between 2012 and 2016, largely fueled by the rapid increase in smartphone adoption.

India's digital space experienced a notable transformation between 2014 and 2016. The number of smartphone users saw a dramatic surge, jumping from 120 million in 2014 to 380 million in 2016, showcasing a significant increase in "Smartphone Penetration" [3] and broader access to digital platforms ![Smartphone users increased from 120 million in 2014 to 380 million in 2016.](image3).  Concurrently, social media engagement also expanded, exemplified by the growth in Facebook users following public figures like Narendra Modi, which grew from 110 million in 2014 to 175 million in 2016, reflecting a rise in "Communication Networking" [5] and digital interaction  ![Narendra Modi's Facebook user base grew from 110 million in 2014 to 175 million in 2016.](image5).  This period also witnessed a robust increase in digital advertising expenditure, climbing from 34 to 57 between 2014 and 2016,  part of the overall "DIGITAL AD SPEND IN INDIA" growth trajectory [10] and indicating a strong 29.9% CAGR in the digital advertising sector ![Digital advertising spend increased from 34 to 57 between 2014 and 2016.](image4).  This expansion underscores that "Digital is the fastest growing sector" ![Digital sector experienced a 30% CAGR.](image2), marking a dynamic phase in India's digital evolution.  The digital space in India significantly evolved from 2014 to 2016, marked by substantial growth in smartphone users, Facebook users, and digital advertising spend.

From 2014 to 2016, India witnessed a significant surge in smartphone adoption, evidenced by the increase from 120 million to 380 million users, highlighting a rapid expansion of mobile technology accessibility ![Illustrates the substantial growth in smartphone users in India between 2014 and 2016](image3). This period also marked a considerable rise in social media engagement, exemplified by the growth of Facebook users from 110 million to 175 million, showcasing the increasing integration of social platforms into daily life ![Demonstrates the increasing number of Facebook users in India from 2014 to 2016](image2).  This digital expansion was not isolated to social media and smartphones; digital media as a whole emerged as the fastest-growing sector, boasting a 30% Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR), surpassing traditional media like print and television which had CAGRs of 11.5% and 14.7% respectively over a similar period ![Indicates that Digital is the fastest growing sector with 30% CAGR](image5). The broader digital landscape was also evolving, with digital payments gaining traction and influencing e-commerce, as reflected in the reducing share of Cash on Delivery (COD) for shipments [1].  This shift is further supported by the increasing preference for varied online payment methods, including debit cards and 3rd party wallets [1], and a projected decrease in COD usage in online retail payment methods from 60% in 2013 to 50% in 2016, alongside a rise in debit card payments from 12% to 15% and 3rd party wallets from 0% to 7% ![Shows the shift in online retail payment methods in India between 2013 and 2016, with a decrease in COD and increase in digital payments](image4). These trends were underpinned by factors like "Smartphone Penetration",  "Infrastructure Development", and the "Convenience" that digital platforms offered to customers [10].

The trends observed from 2014 to 2016 in India include a rapid increase in smartphone and social media usage, with digital media demonstrating the most significant growth compared to other media sectors, alongside a shift towards digital payment methods in online retail.

India witnessed a significant surge in its digital landscape, marking a transformative period for both advertising and eCommerce sectors. The digital sector emerged as the fastest growing area, boasting a compound annual growth rate of 30% [3, 4, 7] ![Digital sector is experiencing rapid growth at a 30% CAGR](image3).  This growth is mirrored in the increasing number of social media users, for example, Facebook users in India grew from 110 million in 2014 to 175 million by 2016 ![Facebook users in India are increasing over the years](image2).

This digital expansion has profoundly influenced advertising spending. Digital advertising expenditure in India saw remarkable growth, escalating from 34 billion INR in 2014 to 57 billion INR in 2016, achieving a CAGR of nearly 30% [5, 8] ![Digital advertising is experiencing high growth compared to other media](image5).  Concurrently, eCommerce sales experienced substantial growth. Product eCommerce revenues increased from $3 billion in 2014 to $13 billion in 2018, while the broader eCommerce market, including travel, expanded from $11 billion to $43 billion in the same period [6] ![eCommerce revenue in India is growing significantly between 2014 and 2018](image4).  This eCommerce growth is further supported by increasing digital payment penetration, which is changing payment preferences from cash on delivery to digital methods like debit cards and third-party wallets ![Digital payment methods like debit cards and 3rd party wallets are becoming more popular in India's online retail](image1, [9]).

The expansion of digital platforms and social media significantly boosted both advertising revenue and eCommerce sales in India between 2014 and 2018.

The Indian space program's organizational framework begins with the Space Commission, which is responsible for formulating policies and overseeing the execution of the Indian space program [7]. The Department of Space (DOS) was established in June 1972 to implement these policies, and the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) was placed under DOS in September of the same year [3]. ISRO is a primary body through which DOS carries out these programs, alongside other entities like the Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC), and Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) [7].  ![This chart illustrates the organizational hierarchy of the Department of Space in India](image3).  The financial resources for these space endeavors are allocated across various programs such as Space Technology, Space Applications, INSAT Operational, Space Sciences, and Direction & Administration [image1]. For example, the budget allocated to Space Technology was 4596.2 in Budget Estimates (BE) for 2015-2016, which was revised to 4351.78 in Revised Estimates (RE) for 2015-2016, and then increased to 5235.68 in BE for 2016-2017.  ![This bar chart shows the budgetary allocations for various space programs in 2015-2016 and 2016-2017](image1).  In total, the grand budget amounted to 7388.19 in BE 2015-2016 and rose to 7509.14 in BE 2016-2017 [image1].

The Indian Space Research Organisation operates under the Department of Space, with budget allocations distributed across diverse programs, demonstrating a structured approach to space activities.

The Department of Space (DOS) and the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) oversee a network of centers, each playing a crucial role in advancing India's space program [3]. ISRO, as the primary implementation arm of DOS, conducts its programs through various centers and autonomous bodies [3]. Antrix Corporation Limited, for instance, serves as the commercial and marketing wing, promoting ISRO’s technologies and services globally [2, 4].

![Antrix facilitates commercial exploitation of ISRO technologies.](image2)

Institutions like the National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) at Gadanki are dedicated to atmospheric research, contributing to weather prediction and climate understanding [9, 8]. NARL's research encompasses a wide array of atmospheric phenomena, utilizing advanced facilities such as the MST Radar [8].

![NARL's MST Radar facility is used for atmospheric research.](image3)

Similarly, the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) in Chandigarh focuses on developing microelectronics capabilities, essential for space technology and other strategic sectors [10]. SCL's work in VLSI and MEMS devices underpins the technological self-reliance in critical electronic components.

![SCL's cleanroom environment is crucial for semiconductor development.](image5)

The North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC) in Shillong tailors space technology applications for the unique developmental needs of the North Eastern Region, ensuring that space benefits reach all parts of India [6]. For nurturing future talent, the Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) in Thiruvananthapuram offers specialized education in space science and technology, ensuring a steady stream of qualified professionals for the Indian space program [5, 7]. The geographical distribution of these centers across India, as shown in the map, underscores the nationwide reach and impact of the space program.

![ISRO and related facilities are distributed across India.](image4)

Analyzing the budgetary allocations, as depicted in the bar chart, reveals the emphasis on different program areas. Space Technology consistently receives the largest share, highlighting its foundational importance in driving the space program forward. Space Applications also commands a significant portion, reflecting the practical utilization of space technology for societal benefits.

![Space Technology receives the largest budgetary allocation, indicating its priority.](image1)

In conclusion, the Indian Space Programme encompasses a diverse range of centers, each with specialized roles in research, development, commercialization, and education, and their budget allocation generally reflects the strategic priorities, with technology development and application receiving substantial emphasis.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) is dedicated to atmospheric research, aiming to predict atmospheric behavior through observation and modeling [4]. To achieve this, NARL emphasizes technology development, data handling, and dissemination [4].  NARL's research is structured into seven main groups, covering areas from radar applications to climate research, and includes specific projects like LIDAR and advanced space-borne instrument development [10].  A key facility supporting NARL's function is the MST Radar, used for atmospheric and meteorological research, as seen in the extensive antenna array at their Gadanki site. ![The MST Radar facility at NARL, featuring a large array of antennas for atmospheric research.](image5).

In contrast, the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) focuses on building a robust microelectronics sector within the country, particularly in VLSI technology [8].  SCL's work encompasses the entire lifecycle of CMOS and MEMS devices, from design to fabrication and testing [8].  The upgraded Wafer Fabrication Lab and the 8" CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line at SCL are crucial for production activities, including complex ASICs like the Vikram Processor for launch vehicles [9].  The cleanroom environments, equipped with advanced machinery and protective measures, are essential for the precise fabrication of semiconductors, ensuring a controlled environment for microelectronics manufacturing. ![Cleanroom environment within a semiconductor fabrication lab, showcasing workers in protective suits and advanced machinery for microfabrication.](image4).

In summary, NARL primarily functions as an atmospheric research center with facilities like the MST Radar, while SCL's main functions are in semiconductor technology development and fabrication, supported by facilities like the Wafer Fabrication Lab and cleanrooms.

Within households, mobile phones are the most commonly owned technology, reaching 86% of households, followed by television at 49% and radio at 45% [image2]. ![Mobile phones are the most commonly owned technology in households, followed by television and radio.](image2). Computer and internet access are significantly lower, especially in rural areas compared to urban areas, where technology penetration is generally higher across all devices [image2].  Outside of the home, a large majority, 68%, do not use any of the listed technologies, while mobile phones are used by 20% of people [image1]. ![Most people do not use any listed technologies outside of home, while mobile phones are used by a smaller percentage.](image1). This suggests a significant difference in technology engagement depending on location, with households being technology hubs, particularly for mobile phone ownership.

Interestingly, despite the rise of mobile phones, traditional radio sets remain a primary device for radio listening, with 76% using a radio set overall [image3]. ![Traditional radio sets are still the primary device for listening to the radio for most people.](image3). Mobile phones are also used for radio listening by 40% of respondents, indicating a diversification in listening devices [image3].  However, a substantial portion of the population, 46%, never listens to the radio [image4]. ![Nearly half of the population never listens to the radio.](image4). Some reasons for not listening to the radio include programs being perceived as uninteresting [3]. Furthermore, some individuals express they do not have a radio, their radio is damaged, or they cannot afford one [5, 6, 9], highlighting accessibility issues. Despite these challenges, radio still reaches a considerable audience, with 79% of people still engaging with it [1], although the reasons for listening or the context of this engagement are not fully detailed.

Technology usage is markedly different inside versus outside the household, with higher ownership within homes and mobile phones being prominent in both contexts; however, a considerable portion of the population does not engage with radio, even though traditional radio sets and mobile phones are both used for listening.

National surveys in Nepal have explored media consumption habits.  Access to newspapers is varied across the population, with a detailed breakdown available.  ![Newspaper readership frequency is detailed, showing daily readers and those who never read newspapers.](image1)  Television access also shows a range of usage patterns. ![Television viewing frequency is shown, indicating daily viewers and those who never watch TV.](image3) Comparing daily access, television is accessed more frequently than newspapers. Conversely, newspapers are never accessed more often than television. In summary, television is accessed more frequently daily, while newspapers are more often never accessed.

Based on national opinion polls covering media consumption in Nepal [3], survey data indicates varying levels of access to different media.  Television is accessed daily by 32% of the surveyed population, as depicted in the infographic ![32% of people watch TV every day](image1).  In contrast, newspaper readership shows a different pattern, with only 9% of respondents reading newspapers every day, as shown in the infographic ![Only 9% of respondents read newspaper every day](image4).  The data further reveals that while 23% of people never watch television ![23% of people never watch TV](image1), a much larger proportion, 70%, never read newspapers ![70% of respondents never read newspaper](image4). Overall, accessing television is a more frequent habit compared to accessing newspapers among the surveyed population.

Organizations like Internews are dedicated to empowering local media to provide essential news and information, thereby enabling people to connect and voice their opinions [7].  They conduct national opinion polls to understand media consumption habits, as visualized in infographics that summarize citizen engagement with different media [4].  Notably, radio stands out with a significant daily reach, as depicted in  ![46% of people access radio everyday](image5), indicating that 46% of people listen to the radio daily. Television also holds a considerable share of daily media consumption, although less than radio, with ![32% of people access television everyday](image3) tuning in every day.  In contrast, newspaper consumption shows a different pattern. While some still access newspapers daily, ![Only 9% of people access newspaper everyday](image2), a large majority, specifically ![70% of people never access newspaper](image2), never engage with this medium.  Similarly, internet access, represented here by laptop usage, reveals an even starker contrast. Although online platforms are increasingly important, daily laptop usage remains relatively low with ![Only 7% of people access internet everyday](image4), and a substantial ![82% of people never access internet](image4) never use laptops.  This data highlights the varying degrees of access and engagement across different media platforms.

In summary, radio has the highest daily usage, while the internet has the highest percentage of non-users.

Access to media varies in frequency, with some accessing media every day [1] and others a few times a week [2].  Different forms of media, such as television [3] and the internet [8], have their own patterns of access.  Notably, a certain percentage of individuals never access some forms of media, with one medium having a never-access rate of 24% [5], another at 15% [9], and yet another at 11% [7].  Based on these percentages, the medium with the highest proportion of people who never access it is the one associated with the 24% figure.

Newspaper has the highest percentage of people who never access it among the compared media.

Based on national opinion polls that investigated media consumption behaviors [7, 10], daily media access habits show a clear difference between television and internet usage. As visualized, 32% of individuals watch television every day ![32% of people watch TV every day](image3), whereas only 7% use laptops daily, which is indicative of internet access ![Only 7% of people use laptops daily for internet access](image4).  Television is used more frequently on a daily basis compared to the internet.

While "Access to Internet" is noted [2], the frequency of access is better illustrated through survey data. ![Laptop usage is low with only 7% accessing everyday and another 7% a few times a week](image1).  This indicates that daily or even weekly internet access via laptops is not typical for most respondents.  In comparison, when examining different media consumption types, television appears to be more widely consumed. ![Television consumption is higher than online media consumption](image5). Television is consumed by 32% of the surveyed population, significantly exceeding the 7% who consume online media. This suggests television is a more prevalent and likely more frequently accessed media source than the internet within this group.  Therefore, television is accessed more frequently than the internet among the surveyed population.

The survey conducted in Nepal considered various demographic factors to reflect the national population distribution, including caste/ethnic groups as shown in the sample composition [8]. These groups were further categorized into Non-Madhesi and Madhesi for comparative analysis [5].  Religious composition was also a factor in the survey design [7]. Furthermore, the geographic distribution of the sample was structured to mirror the general population across ecological and development regions, ensuring representativeness [4].

Therefore, the population distribution analysis in Nepal around September 2014, as reflected in this survey, accounted for caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location to ensure a representative sample.

The rural-urban distribution in the population sample remained consistent with the 2011 national census across the survey waves, with a significant majority, 83 percent, originating from rural areas and a smaller 17 percent from urban areas [5].  For the analysis of caste and ethnicity, the eight broad caste/ethnic groups were further categorized into two main groups: Non-Madhesi and Madhesi, to facilitate comparative analysis [6, 7].  Therefore, the rural-urban composition was stable, and caste/ethnicity was assessed using broader categories between the initial survey period and September 2014.

Indonesians' mobile internet usage is heavily skewed towards social media and entertainment, with social media accounting for 24% of mobile internet activities and entertainment following at 20% [image3]. This aligns with the fact that a vast majority of internet users in Indonesia, specifically 62%, access the internet through mobile devices, and for many, it serves as the primary source of information [6].  Interestingly, despite the popularity of social media and entertainment on mobile internet, shopping is still a notable activity, capturing 8% of mobile internet usage [image3].

When it comes to shopping preferences, apparel stands out as the most purchased item both offline and online, with 67.1% of online shoppers buying apparel  ![The chart compares offline and online shopping preferences, highlighting apparel as the top category in both.](image1).  Furthermore, instant messaging applications are incredibly popular for communication, with 90% of mobile phone users engaging in instant messaging daily [8]. These IM platforms, along with social media, play a significant role in online shopping in Indonesia.  E-commerce users frequently shop through social media (26%) and IM groups like BBM Groups (27%), demonstrating a strong connection between communication platforms and shopping habits [8]. This suggests that the high engagement with social media and instant messaging on mobile devices directly translates into shopping activities within these platforms.

In conclusion, mobile internet usage in Indonesia, dominated by social media and communication, significantly shapes shopping behaviors, with social media and IM platforms becoming key channels for e-commerce activities, especially for popular items like apparel.

With a substantial mobile subscriber base and significant mobile internet penetration in Indonesia [8, 5], understanding user demographics is crucial for tailoring content and business strategies.  A notable portion of mobile internet users fall within the 18-35 age range, with a considerable segment employed full-time or engaged in business, indicating a young and economically active demographic `![The charts display age and occupation distributions of mobile internet users, highlighting a young and professionally active demographic.](image3)`. This demographic actively engages with social media and entertainment on their mobile devices, as these constitute a large share of mobile internet activities and downloaded content  `![The graphic illustrates popular mobile internet activities and downloaded content, showing social media and entertainment are highly engaged.](image2)`.  Instant messaging further stands out as a primary communication method, preferred by a vast majority of mobile users [3], reflecting a highly connected and socially oriented user base.  For businesses, this mobile-centric behavior presents significant opportunities, particularly in mobile advertising, which is a growing market in Indonesia [7, 5]. Potential revenue streams in this mobile ecosystem encompass advertisements, value-added services, games, and music, among others `![The list outlines potential revenue sources including advertisement and value-added services.](image4)`. Moreover, the rise of mobile e-commerce and social commerce, facilitated by platforms like BBM Groups and social media shops [9, 3], is underpinned by the availability of various payment service providers catering to the Indonesian market `![The table details various payment service providers facilitating mobile transactions in Indonesia.](image1)`.  The demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia, characterized by a young, active, and socially engaged population, directly influence their content preferences towards social media, entertainment, and instant communication, thereby shaping the landscape of business opportunities in mobile advertising, e-commerce, and value-added services.

In Indonesia's telecommunications sector, key players such as Telkomsel, XL Axiata, and Indosat stand out as major GSM operators [9]. Examining their performance reveals interesting trends over time. A snapshot from a later period shows Telkomsel leading with 132.7 million subscribers and 60.5 million data users, followed by XL with 68.5 million subscribers and 37.5 million data users, and Indosat with 59.7 million subscribers and 29 million data users, as well as other metrics for comparison ![Comparison of subscriber and data user numbers among telecommunications providers, including Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat, along with other metrics like smartphone and BlackBerry users](image1). This data reflects the landscape in late 2014 [10].

Earlier data, potentially from 2013-2014 [7], illustrates a similar hierarchy but with different figures: Telkomsel reported 139.3 million subscribers and 63.5 million data users; XL had 58.3 million subscribers and 32 million data users; and Indosat recorded 54.2 million subscribers and 29 million data users. Alongside these, the numbers of smartphone, BlackBerry, and Android users are also detailed for each company ![Comparison of subscribers, smartphone users, BlackBerry users, Android users, and data users for Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat, showing metrics in millions and color-coded legends](image3).  Comparing these datasets, Telkomsel consistently leads in both subscriber and data user numbers, with XL and Indosat following respectively, though the specific figures fluctuate across different reporting periods.

Telkomsel consistently demonstrates a larger subscriber base and data user count compared to both XL and Indosat over the observed periods.

From 2013 to 2014, Telkomsel saw an expansion in its subscriber base.  As depicted in a 2013-2014 overview, Telkomsel's subscriber count reached 132.7 million. ![Telkomsel had 132.7 million subscribers in 2013-2014.](image5)  This number further increased to 139.3 million by late 2014. ![Telkomsel had 139.3 million subscribers in late 2014.](image4)  Despite this growth in subscribers, the Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) for Telkomsel likely experienced a decrease, mirroring a broader trend in Indonesia where prepaid ARPU was already declining. ![ARPU for prepaid services in Indonesia declined from 2008 to 2012.](image2)  This ARPU decline was not unique to Telkomsel but reflected an industry-wide shift, with voice and SMS ARPU generally decreasing during this time. ![ARPU for voice and SMS was decreasing while data ARPU was fluctuating from 2013 to 2017.](image1)  This ARPU reduction was influenced by factors such as the increasing adoption of data-based communication methods over traditional SMS and voice calls [1, 9], and price competition among operators [2, 3].  The shift towards data services and competitive pricing likely contributed to a decrease in ARPU despite the growing subscriber numbers for Telkomsel.  In conclusion, Telkomsel's subscriber base increased from 2013 to 2014, but its ARPU likely decreased due to market trends and changing service usage patterns.

The Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) for voice and SMS services continued to decline between 2013 and 2014 [2], a trend visualized in the graph depicting ARPU from 2013 to 2017, where voice and SMS ARPUs show a consistent decrease. ![The graph shows voice and SMS ARPU are decreasing from 2013 to 2014, while data ARPU is initially decreasing and then increasing](image2). This decline is attributed to the increasing adoption of data-based communication methods like Instant Messaging and VoIP, which reduce the reliance on traditional SMS and voice calls [4]. Consequently, reduced usage of SMS and voice services directly leads to a decrease in overall ARPU [5].

However, the number of smartphone users for both Telkomsel and XL saw an increase during this period, as shown in the comparison of subscribers and user types across different telecom operators in late 2014. ![The bar chart shows that Telkomsel and XL have significant numbers of smartphone users in late 2014](image3). This growth in smartphone adoption was significantly influenced by the increasing availability and affordability of Android devices [1], and initiatives from operators like Telkomsel to boost smartphone penetration [7].  Despite an initial dip, data ARPU was expected to recover and eventually grow as users consumed more mobile internet, compensating for the losses in voice and SMS ARPU [2].

In conclusion, while ARPU from traditional voice and SMS services decreased for Telkomsel and XL between 2013 and 2014, the number of smartphone users increased, driven by the growing popularity of smartphones and data services, which was anticipated to shift the revenue focus towards data consumption.

The rise of streaming has significantly reshaped music consumption, becoming the dominant format in the industry [4]. This shift is evident across various genres, as streaming now constitutes the largest portion of the music business [1].  ![Streaming is the largest part of music consumption compared to album and song sales.](image5)

Examining genre-specific trends, we observe variations in how streaming and album sales contribute to overall consumption.  Rock music, for instance, demonstrates a strong catalog presence across formats, particularly in streaming, where it reaches 82% catalog share, while Pop music is more current-driven [3].  ![Rock music has a higher catalog share in streams compared to Pop, R&B/Hip-Hop and Country music.](image1)

Analyzing the share of total activity by genre, we see that for Rock, album sales still hold a significant portion at 37%, while streams account for 23%. In contrast, R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop genres show a larger share in streams (26% and 23% respectively) compared to album sales (18% and 19% respectively) ![Different music genres have different shares in album sales, song sales and streams.](image4).  Looking at the format distribution across genres, Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA) represents a substantial portion for most genres, especially Latin and Dance/Electronic, while Physical Albums maintain a stronger presence in genres like Rock and Country [image2].

In conclusion, streaming has become the leading format for music consumption across genres, generally surpassing album sales in terms of share, although album sales retain relevance, particularly within specific genres like Rock and Country.

Streaming has indeed become a dominant force in music consumption [5].  Across the entire music landscape, streams constitute a significant portion of total activity.  ![Streams represent 70% of the total music consumption activity.](image4). However, the reliance on streaming varies considerably across different music genres. Genres like R&B/Hip-Hop, Latin, and Dance/Electronic demonstrate a notably higher proportion of their consumption coming from streams, whereas genres like Rock and Country, while still embracing streaming, show a more balanced consumption across different formats.  ![This bar chart shows the percentage distribution of music album sales, song sales, and streams across different music genres, highlighting the varying stream shares by genre.](image1). In conclusion, while streaming is a leading format overall, its contribution to total music activity is not uniform across genres, with some genres being significantly more stream-driven than others.

Rock music is notably propelled by its catalog across all formats, whereas pop music's popularity is predominantly influenced by current trends [1]. This divergence in drivers is reflected in the catalog share across genres, as illustrated in the provided data.

![Rock genre has the highest catalog share across all formats](image5)

Looking at catalog share across different genres, Rock exhibits a significantly high catalog share across all formats, with 68% for total activity, 63% for album sales, 68% for song sales, and a striking 82% for streams.  In contrast, Pop music shows a lower catalog share, particularly in album sales at 21% and song sales at 30%, although its streaming catalog share is higher at 58%. R&B/Hip-Hop and Country also present substantial catalog shares, demonstrating the varying influence of catalog music across genres.

![Nicki Minaj's album has the highest On-Demand Audio Stream Share](image2)

Examining albums with high on-demand audio stream share, Nicki Minaj's album stands out with the highest percentage at 18%.

In summary, catalog share varies significantly across music genres, with Rock leading in catalog consumption across formats, and Nicki Minaj's album has the highest on-demand audio stream share among the listed albums.

In 2015, the music landscape was characterized by distinct genre performances across different sales formats, with streaming emerging as a leading force [8].  Rock was identified as the biggest genre overall, but R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop also demonstrated significant strength [3].  This is visually represented in the share of total activity across genres, where Rock leads with 30%, followed by R&B/Hip-Hop at 21% and Pop at 17% ![This bar chart illustrates the overall share of different music genres in total activity.](image5).

Looking at specific formats, Rock notably dominated album sales, while Pop was the driving force in song sales, and R&B/Hip-Hop took the lead in streaming [4]. This divergence is further highlighted when examining the genre share across album sales, song sales, and streams, revealing Rock's strong presence in album sales and R&B/Hip-Hop's prominence in streams ![This bar chart compares the percentage distribution of music album sales, song sales, and streams across different music genres, showcasing format-specific genre strengths.](image1).  The distribution of music sales formats across genres further emphasizes these format preferences, showing the varying importance of physical albums, digital albums, track equivalent albums (TEA), and streaming equivalent albums (SEA) for each genre [1].  For instance, Latin music shows a substantial 68% in SEA, indicating a strong preference for streaming within this genre ![This bar chart depicts the distribution of music sales across different genres, broken down into physical albums, digital albums, TEA, and SEA, revealing format-specific consumption patterns per genre.](image3).  Notably, Rock's consumption is driven by catalog music across all formats, whereas Pop is primarily driven by current releases [2].

In conclusion, the music genres in 2015 exhibited varied performance across sales formats and streaming, with Rock leading overall but showing format-specific nuances alongside the strengths of Pop and R&B/Hip-Hop in song sales and streaming respectively.

In the music industry, streaming has emerged as the dominant format across various genres [2].  This shift is visually represented, highlighting that streams constitute the largest portion of total music activity compared to album sales and song sales ![Streaming represents the largest portion of total music activity](image1). However, the preference for music sales formats varies significantly among genres. For instance, Rock music is largely propelled by its extensive catalog across all formats, whereas Pop music is more reliant on current releases [3].

Delving into the catalog share by format, it's notable that for Rock, streams contribute to a significant 82% of catalog activity, underscoring the importance of streaming for catalog consumption within this genre ![Catalog share of different music formats across genres](image5).

In conclusion, while streaming is the leading format overall, genres like R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin rely most heavily on streaming for their music consumption, while Rock, despite its catalog strength in streaming, maintains a more balanced distribution across formats.

The shift in music consumption habits shows that streaming has become a primary way people listen to music [3]. Different genres, however, exhibit varied patterns in how they are consumed across formats.  ![This image displays the percentage distribution of music consumption across album sales, song sales, and streams for various genres, highlighting the format preferences for each genre.](image1) For instance, while rock exhibits a strong presence in album sales, R&B/Hip-Hop demonstrates a clear lead in streaming [9]. The music industry in 2015 reveals a significant format shift, where streaming has risen to prominence, becoming the leading method of music consumption [2, 7].  While streaming dominates overall activity, album sales remain a notable portion of the market, indicating diverse consumer preferences across formats as visualized in a chart breaking down format shares of total equivalents ![Streaming accounts for the largest share of total music activity at 70%, while album sales still represent a significant portion.](image1). Reports indicate the mobile landscape in Vietnam experienced notable shifts in operating system preferences between the second and third quarters of 2015 [5, 1].  Specifically, within the Android ecosystem, the Lollipop version witnessed a significant surge in adoption, reaching 35% of total Android users by Q3, demonstrating a strong move towards Google's newer OS ![Lollipop usage increased substantially between Q2 and Q3 2015](image1).  This upward trend in Lollipop adoption is clearly visualized, highlighting the change from Q2 to Q3.  Simultaneously, the iOS platform introduced iOS 9, which quickly gained traction upon its Q3 release, achieving a remarkably fast adoption rate [4, 7].  The data illustrates this adoption pattern, with iOS 9 entering the market in Q3, while iOS 8 also experienced a considerable rise in usage during the same timeframe, suggesting a swift transition to more recent iOS iterations ![iOS 9 was adopted in Q3 2015 and iOS 8 usage significantly increased](image2).  Despite these advancements in OS adoption, iOS faced a market share contraction of 22.3% in Q2 compared to the preceding quarter [2].  Regarding brand dominance in Vietnam, Samsung solidified its leading position, attracting a user base larger than the combined users of the next five vendors ![Samsung dominated the phone brand market share](image4), underscoring its strong market influence throughout this period [9].

In summary, during Q2 and Q3 of 2015 in Vietnam, Android saw increased adoption of Lollipop, iOS introduced and rapidly adopted iOS 9, and Samsung maintained the largest phone brand market share.

The hypothesis posits that label words act as anchors in the information flow within the model [1], illustrated as a two-stage process where shallow layers aggregate information from examples through label words, while deep layers extract information from label words for final predictions [1, 4].  This is visually supported by an illustration depicting information aggregation in shallow layers and label prediction in deeper layers based on sentiment labels like "Negative" and "Positive" ![Illustration of information flow in shallow and deep layers for sentiment analysis](image4). To understand this flow, metrics such as \(S_{wp}\), which measures the information flow from the text part to label words [10], and \(S_{pq}\), which measures the information flow from label words to the target position [9], are used [5].  Observations reveal that in the initial layers, \(S_{wp}\) is prominent, while \(S_{pq}\) is less significant [6, 8]. However, this dynamic shifts in deeper layers where \(S_{pq}\) becomes dominant [6, 8]. This trend is visualized in line graphs for datasets like SST-2 and AGNews, where \(S_{wp}\) (blue line) starts higher but decreases with layers, and \(S_{pq}\) (orange line) increases and eventually surpasses \(S_{wp}\) in deeper layers ![Line graph of S values across layers for SST-2 dataset](image1) and ![Line graph of S values across layers for AGNews dataset](image2).  Therefore, the mean significance of information flow from the text part to label words is not always greater than the mean significance of information flow from label words to the target position.

No.

The LOGIC-LM framework is introduced to enhance logical problem-solving by integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) with symbolic solvers [3, 9]. This framework decomposes logical reasoning into problem formulation, symbolic reasoning, and result interpretation [9].  Within the symbolic reasoning stage, various methods are employed depending on the nature of the problem, including logic programming, first-order logic proving, and constraint optimization, as visually depicted in the model structure ![The LOGIC-LM model is structured with modules for problem formulation, symbolic reasoning, and result interpretation, utilizing different methods like Logic Programming, First-order Logic Prover, and Constraint Optimization based on problem type.](image5). For deductive reasoning and implementing the logic programming module, the Pyke expert system is incorporated [5]. Pyke operates by creating a knowledge base and applying forward and backward chaining algorithms to perform logical inferences based on logic programming language [5].

In this paper, the Pyke expert system is used as the symbolic solver to implement the logic programming module.

RAPTOR employs two distinct methods for retrieving information within its tree structure: tree traversal and collapsed tree [7]. The tree traversal method navigates the tree layer by layer, refining the node selection at each stage to pinpoint the most pertinent information [7]. This method begins broadly at the top layers and progressively narrows down to specific details in the lower layers, offering adjustable control over the specificity and breadth of retrieved information by modifying the depth and number of selected nodes at each layer [4].  The pseudocode for the tree traversal algorithm, named `TRAVERSETREE`, outlines a function that takes a tree, a query, and a parameter `k` to perform layer-by-layer selection of top-k nodes based on cosine similarity, returning a union of selected nodes from each layer ![Pseudocode for the Tree Traversal Algorithm.](image2).

In contrast, the collapsed tree method assesses nodes across all layers collectively to identify the most relevant ones [7].  This approach flattens the tree into a single layer and retrieves nodes based on cosine similarity until a token threshold is reached, as detailed in its pseudocode, `COLLAPSEDTREE` function, which takes tree, query, k, and `max_tokens` as parameters to select nodes while respecting token limits ![Pseudocode for the Collapsed Tree Algorithm.](image5). Comparing the pseudocode descriptions, the Tree Traversal Algorithm has more lines.

The Tree Traversal Algorithm has more lines in its pseudocode.

Active learning strategies often encounter a significant challenge: biased queries, where the selection of data points leans heavily towards specific classes, particularly the majority classes [8, 10]. This bias is visually evident when examining the class distribution of different querying methods, as some strategies disproportionately select data from certain categories while neglecting others, leading to imbalanced datasets for training. For instance, in the PathMNIST dataset, strategies like VAAL exhibit a strong preference for the muscle class, almost entirely overlooking classes like mucus and mucosa, as depicted in the bar chart of class distributions ![VAAL querying strategy demonstrates a biased selection towards the muscle class while neglecting mucus and mucosa in PathMNIST dataset](image5). This skewed selection is not unique to PathMNIST; similar patterns are observed in other datasets like OrganAMNIST, where VAAL tends to favor femur-right and platelet classes while disregarding lung, liver, and monocyte classes [6]. The consequence of such biased querying is that these active learning strategies, including Entropy, Margin, and VAAL, may struggle to outperform even random sampling, especially at the initial stages of learning, because crucial classes remain underrepresented or entirely unselected [8].

Label diversity emerges as a critical factor in mitigating these issues and enhancing the effectiveness of active querying [2, 9].  Incorporating label diversity into querying criteria generally improves the performance and robustness of most active querying strategies, including BALD, Margin, VAAL, and Uncertainty, across various datasets such as PathMNIST, OrganMNIST, and BloodMNIST, as illustrated in performance comparisons ![Label diversity enhances the AUC scores across various active querying strategies on MedMNIST datasets](image3). This improvement is particularly noticeable in low-budget scenarios where the initial dataset is small, and balanced class representation is crucial for effective learning [4, 10]. While various active querying strategies suffer from this issue to different extents, those like VAAL, Entropy and Margin, which demonstrably skew class selection, generally exhibit the worst label diversity across datasets.

In summary, **VAAL and similar biased active querying strategies generally yield the worst label diversity across the datasets.**

The system architecture is designed to process user requests and generate relevant responses by employing a series of steps. Initially, the user's natural language input is encoded into a continuous vector using a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder [4]. This encoded user utterance, combined with the encoding of the previous system action, is then fed into a dialogue-level LSTM, which maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state [7].  This dialogue state allows the system to track user goals by estimating slot-value pairs and formulating queries to a knowledge base to retrieve pertinent information [4]. ![The architecture illustrates user input being processed to generate a system response through various components like encoders and a natural language generator.](image2) Based on the dialogue state, the estimated user goal, and query results, a policy network determines the next system action [4, 9].  This policy network takes into account the dialogue-level LSTM state, log probabilities of candidate values from the belief tracker, and the encoding of query results to decide on the appropriate system action [1, 9]. ![The diagram highlights the dialogue state and policy network involved in selecting system actions.](image3)  Finally, to produce a natural language response, the system uses a template-based natural language generator (NLG) [6]. This NLG component combines the state tracker outputs and retrieved knowledge base entities, replacing delexicalized tokens in the template with values from either the estimated user goal or the knowledge base entities, depending on the emitted system action [6]. The system generates a response by utilizing a natural language generator that is informed by the dialogue state and system actions.

RAPTOR significantly improves model performance in question answering tasks. Controlled evaluations show that incorporating RAPTOR enhances both accuracy and F1 scores across various models [3]. For example, when using SBERT, RAPTOR boosts both accuracy and F1 score compared to using SBERT alone, as demonstrated in ![SBERT with RAPTOR achieves 56.6% accuracy and 36.70% F-1, outperforming SBERT without RAPTOR which scores 54.9% accuracy and 36.23% F-1.](image1).  This improvement is consistent across different language models; on the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR when paired with GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, achieving superior F-1 scores [5, 7].  Specifically, RAPTOR combined with GPT-4 reaches an F-1 score of 55.7% ![RAPTOR achieves the highest F-1 score of 55.7% when combined with GPT-4, compared to 50.2% for BM25 and 53.0% for DPR with GPT-4.](image3).  Similarly, on the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR exhibits enhanced accuracy compared to BM25 and DPR when used with both GPT-3 and UnifiedQA [10]. For instance, RAPTOR achieves 62.4% accuracy with GPT-3 ![RAPTOR achieves the highest accuracy of 62.4% with GPT-3, compared to 57.3% for BM25 and 60.4% for DPR with GPT-3.](image4).  Notably, RAPTOR, when combined with GPT-4, establishes a new state-of-the-art performance on QASPER with a 55.7% F-1 score [1, 5], outperforming other state-of-the-art systems like CoLT5 XL ![RAPTOR + GPT-4 achieves the highest F-1 score of 55.7, surpassing LongT5 XL at 53.1 and CoLT5 XL at 53.9.](image5).  In summary, RAPTOR significantly enhances model performance, leading to improved accuracy and F1 scores across various datasets and language models.

Error analysis reveals key differences in error rates when Step-Back + RAG is applied to TimeQA and StrategyQA datasets. For TimeQA, as depicted in error analysis, Step-Back + RAG introduces errors in 5.6% of predictions compared to the baseline and 6.3% when compared to RAG alone ![Error analysis of Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA, showing error percentages compared to baseline and RAG predictions](image1) [2].  Conversely, for StrategyQA, the error analysis indicates that Step-Back + RAG leads to a 6.1% error rate against the baseline and a 4.4% error rate against RAG predictions ![Error analysis of Step-Back Prompting on StrategyQA, illustrating error percentages against baseline and RAG predictions](image3) [4].  Notably, the errors introduced by Step-Back Prompting to RAG are 6.3% for TimeQA and 4.4% for StrategyQA [2, 4].  In summary, Step-Back + RAG exhibits slightly varying error rates between TimeQA and StrategyQA, with TimeQA showing a marginally higher error introduction when integrated with RAG.

The SnapNTell dataset notably differs from other Visual Question Answering (VQA) datasets by emphasizing entity-centric knowledge-based questions, filling a void where existing datasets often lack the granularity and complexity needed to assess models on real-world entities [2, 6, 8].  SnapNTell is structured with a wide array of fine-grained entities, distributed across 22 diverse categories, encompassing a total of 7,568 unique entities, which is visualized in the entity category breakdown ![SnapNTell dataset comprises 22 diverse categories and 7,568 entities in total.](image1) and further substantiated by comparative dataset attributes ![SnapNTell dataset has significantly more categories, entities, QA pairs, images, and longer answers compared to ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA.](image5).  Unlike many VQA datasets that rely on simple yes/no answers or broad categories, SnapNTell is designed with question-answer pairs that necessitate knowledge-intensive responses, specifically incorporating entity names within the answer sets [1, 4]. This contrasts with datasets that might use general terms or lack entity specificity, as highlighted in dataset examples ![SnapNTell dataset includes knowledge-intensive question compared to other datasets.](image2).  In comparison to datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA, SnapNTell offers a larger variety of categories, a greater number of unique entities, a higher volume of QA pairs and images, and substantially longer answer lengths [5].  Moreover, SnapNTell uniquely combines knowledge, entities, and categorization within its framework, a feature set not consistently present across other VQA datasets ![SnapNTell dataset incorporates knowledge, entities, and categorization, unlike some other VQA datasets.](image3).

In essence, the SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself through its focus on diverse, fine-grained entities and knowledge-intensive questions, providing a more demanding and nuanced benchmark compared to other VQA datasets.

Across various datasets, the DSC loss function consistently demonstrates superior performance [10].  Looking at the Chinese datasets CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4, the model BERT+DSC achieves the highest F1 scores in all three, reaching 97.92, 96.57, and 96.98 respectively, outperforming other models like Joint-POS and Lattice-LSTM and even the baseline BERT-Tagger ![BERT+DSC achieves the highest F1 scores on CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4 datasets](image5). On English datasets such as OntoNotes 5.0, BERT-MRC+DSC also attains the highest F1 score at 92.07, surpassing other BERT-MRC variants and CVT ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset](image1).  Similarly, for English WSJ and Tweets, BERT-Tagger+DSC leads with F1 scores of 99.38 and 92.58 respectively, indicating its effectiveness across different text types ![BERT-Tagger+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English WSJ and Tweets datasets](image2).  The consistent top performance of DSC is further highlighted by its F1 score of 93.33 on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, again outperforming other models like ELMo and CVT ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English CoNLL 2003 dataset](image3). Therefore, DSC consistently achieves the highest F1 score across multiple datasets.

Named entity recognition (NER) involves identifying and categorizing entities within text spans [3]. State-of-the-art models like BERT-MRC are used as backbones for this task [3]. Evaluated on datasets such as CoNLL 2003 and OntoNotes 5.0, BERT-MRC's performance can be enhanced through modifications.  For the CoNLL 2003 dataset,  ![BERT-MRC achieves an F1 score of 93.04 on the CoNLL 2003 dataset](image4), BERT-MRC achieves a precision of 92.33, recall of 94.61, and an F1 score of 93.04.  Variations of BERT-MRC, including those with FL, DL, and DSC enhancements, show improved performance [8]. Specifically, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves a higher F1 score of 93.33 on CoNLL 2003, outperforming the base BERT-MRC model [8].  Similarly, on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, ![BERT-MRC achieves an F1-score of 91.11 on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset](image1), BERT-MRC achieves an F1-score of 91.11.  The DSC-enhanced version, BERT-MRC+DSC, again leads with the highest F1 score of 92.07, demonstrating a notable improvement [8]. These results highlight that BERT-MRC and its DSC variant achieve state-of-the-art performance on both the English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets [8].

BERT-MRC model variations show enhanced performance on both English CoNLL 2003 and OntoNotes 5.0 datasets, with DSC enhancements leading to state-of-the-art results.

The models DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy when compared to BERT-DST and ToD-BERT, reaching a joint accuracy of 53.30% [9, 7].  This is notably higher than BERT-DST's 43.40% and ToD-BERT's 48.00%, as shown in the comparative analysis of different models ![The table compares joint accuracy of different models, showing DS-Picklist with the highest value.](image3).  Furthermore, DS-Picklist also demonstrates the highest average slot accuracy at 97.40% [4]. In comparison, DS-Span achieves 96.38% and DS-DST reaches 97.35% for average slot accuracy ![The table displays slot accuracy percentages for DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist, with DS-Picklist having the highest average accuracy.](image4). The improved performance of DS-Picklist is attributed to its access to a full ontology and its treatment of all domain-slot pairs as categorical slots, leveraging candidate-value lists [10, 8].  The architecture of DS-Picklist and DS-DST models, incorporating BERT models for feature extraction and context processing, contributes to these accuracy improvements [5].

DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy and average slot accuracy among the compared models.

For credibility regression tasks, models are evaluated using Mean Squared Error (MSE), where lower values indicate better performance [1].  As depicted in a performance comparison table, DeClarE (Full) achieves the lowest MSE of 0.29 among several configurations, including CNN-text, CCRF+SVR, LSTM-text, DistantSup, and DeClarE (Plain)  ![DeClarE (Full) achieves the lowest MSE of 0.29 among compared configurations](image4).  This is further substantiated by findings that DeClarE (Full) demonstrates a 17% reduction in MSE compared to the best-performing baselines in credibility regression [10]. In credibility classification tasks for tweet confidence scores, Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE) is used as an evaluation metric [8].  Another table shows that DeClarE (Full) has the lowest RMSE at 0.604 when compared to IITP (Open), NileTMRG (Close), and DeClarE (Plain) ![DeClarE (Full) achieves the lowest RMSE of 0.604 among compared configurations](image5). DeClarE (Full) configuration exhibits superior performance with the lowest error metrics compared to other models.

Our approach demonstrates significant performance improvements when compared to other methods on both the LANI and CHAI datasets, especially in navigation tasks [6].  The detailed performance metrics across various methods, including baselines and previous approaches, are clearly presented in the comparative results. ![Performance comparison with baselines and variations](image3).  Specifically on the LANI navigation task, 'Our Approach' outperforms methods like CHAPLOT and MISRA, achieving a notable increase in task completion accuracy [3]. This improvement in instruction execution is further highlighted when examining the performance metrics against several baselines and state-of-the-art methods, where 'Our Approach' consistently achieves top results in terms of stop distance and task completion for LANI. ![Performance on LANI and CHAI compared to several methods](image1).  While the CHAI task presents greater complexity, leading to weaker overall results across all models, 'Our Approach' still manages to show improvements in stop distance compared to other methods, despite the challenges in manipulation tasks [3, 2].  Looking at the detailed breakdown, 'Our Approach' consistently demonstrates competitive or superior performance in both LANI and CHAI datasets when evaluated against various baselines and existing methodologies.

In summary, 'Our Approach' generally exhibits superior or competitive performance compared to other methods on both LANI and CHAI datasets.

The 'Ours' model demonstrates a clear advancement in performance compared to existing Named Entity Recognition (NER) models, achieving state-of-the-art results [8].  This improvement is evident when comparing 'Ours' against models like AttentiveNER, AFET, and LNR, which rely solely on knowledge base supervision [7]. The table below illustrates this comparison across accuracy (Acc.), macro-averaged F1 (Ma-F1), and micro-averaged F1 (Mi-F1) scores, clearly showing 'Ours' model achieving the highest values in all metrics. ![Ours model achieves the highest accuracy and F1 scores compared to AttentiveNER++, AFET and LNR](image3) Further analysis reveals that when compared directly to AttentiveNER, 'Ours' model consistently shows superior performance across development and test datasets, particularly in Recall and F1-score. While AttentiveNER exhibits higher precision, 'Ours' model compensates with significantly improved recall, leading to a better overall F1-score and Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR). ![Our Model demonstrates better MRR, Recall and F1 score than AttentiveNER](image2)  The effectiveness of 'Ours' model is further highlighted when considering different training data combinations.  When trained using a combination of ONTO, WIKI, and HEAD datasets, 'Ours' consistently outperforms 'Attn. NER' across accuracy and F1 scores.  This comprehensive training approach contributes to the model's enhanced ability to recognize and classify named entities. ![Our Model trained on ONTO, WIKI, HEAD data achieves the best performance](image4)

In summary, the 'Ours' model generally outperforms other NER models in terms of both accuracy and F1 scores, marking a significant improvement in the field.

The architecture incorporating CCNN+WLSTM+CRF stands out with a superior F1-value in Named Entity Recognition tasks, as detailed in performance benchmarks [6]. This effectiveness is partly attributed to the model's LSTM's capacity to capture global features, outperforming WCNN-based models, and the significant performance improvement gained from character information [6]. The architecture of NCRF++ models, like the one used here, typically includes layers for character sequences and word sequences, culminating in an inference layer utilizing CRF or Softmax functions, as depicted in its structural representation ![NCRF++ model structure includes Char and Word Sequence Layers](image1). Examining feature contributions, models enhanced with CCNN demonstrate a notable F1 score of 91.35, surpassing those with CLSTM or human-engineered features, showcasing the advantage of automatic feature extraction in NER tasks ![CCNN feature leads to a higher F1 score](image2).
