PMI's shipment volumes in Latin America and Canada experienced a notable shift between 2019 and 2020.  Total shipment volume in Latin America and Canada decreased by 11.6% from 2019 to 2020, totaling 64,200 million units in 2020 [image3]. This decrease is part of a broader trend where total shipment volume for PMI decreased by 11.6% overall [10].  Specifically, in Canada, shipment volumes declined by 18.6%, partly attributed to the deconsolidation of RBH [2].  The deconsolidation of RBH also had a financial impact, contributing to a decrease in net cash used in investing activities by $\S0.7$ billion [1].

However, despite the decrease in shipment volumes, the financial performance in Latin America & Canada presents a mixed picture.  Net revenues in this region decreased by 22.9% from 2019 to 2020, but operating income remarkably increased by 100% in the same period [image4].  Although volume/mix negatively impacted both net revenues and operating income, price variances and cost/other factors positively influenced the operating income, offsetting the negative impacts from volume and currency exchange [image4].  This improvement in operating income occurred even as net cash provided by operating activities saw a slight decrease in 2020 compared to 2019 [7, image5].  The net cash used in investing activities also decreased, which aligns with the deconsolidation of RBH and reduced capital expenditures [1, image5].  Furthermore, higher working capital requirements were observed due to inventory build-up related to the COVID-19 pandemic [5, 7].

In conclusion, despite a significant decrease in shipment volumes and net revenues in Latin America & Canada, PMI's overall financial performance in this region showed improvement in operating income, driven by pricing strategies and cost management, amidst changes in investment and operating cash flows influenced by factors like deconsolidation and pandemic-related inventory adjustments.

In 2021, Consumer Banking and Lending experienced a significant surge in net income compared to the previous year, reaching $10,855 million, a substantial increase from $2,743 million in 2020 and also exceeding the $7,823 million recorded in 2019, as detailed in the financial summary across different business segments ![Net income for Consumer Banking and Lending in 2021 was significantly higher than in 2020 and 2019](image3). This overall financial performance in 2021 was marked by a considerable increase in net income and diluted earnings per share in comparison to 2020 [6].

However, when examining the balance sheet, a different trend emerges.  Total loans, on average, for Consumer Banking and Lending decreased from $534,321 million in 2019 to $526,037 million in 2020 and further down to $487,734 million in 2021, indicating a consistent decline over the three years ![Average total loans for Consumer Banking and Lending decreased from 2019 to 2021](image4). This reduction in loan balances is attributed to paydowns surpassing new loan originations [9].  Conversely, total deposits for Consumer Banking and Lending demonstrated a clear upward trend, increasing from $561,394 million in 2019 to $608,648 million in 2020 and further to $722,456 million in 2021, reflecting growth over the period ![Average total deposits for Consumer Banking and Lending increased from 2019 to 2021](image4). This surge in deposits is linked to increased liquidity and savings among consumer customers, spurred by government stimulus and payment deferral programs amidst economic uncertainties during the COVID-19 pandemic [3].

In summary, from 2019 to 2021, Consumer Banking and Lending saw a notable increase in net income alongside decreasing loan balances and increasing deposit balances.

From 2019 to 2021, average Card Member loans experienced a decrease, while net interest income also saw a reduction over the same period, even though net interest yield on these loans remained consistent at 2.5% in both years ![Net interest income decreased while yields remained stable](image2).  Despite a decrease in net interest income [6], the company's overall revenues net of interest expense actually increased by 17 percent year-over-year, driven by double-digit growth in non-interest revenue lines [6]. Discount revenue, the largest revenue component, increased by 26 percent, boosted by growth in Card Member spending [6].  This growth in non-interest revenues, especially discount revenue and net card fees [3], indicates a shift in revenue composition, and the company effectively compensated for the slight decline in net interest income with strong performance in other areas. Provisions for credit losses also decreased, resulting in a net benefit, largely due to reserve releases driven by improved portfolio quality and a better macroeconomic outlook [2, 9].  However, it's also important to note that operating expenses and expenses related to marketing and Card Member rewards increased [1, 4].  Despite rising expenses, the significant growth in revenues net of interest expense and the positive impact from provisions for credit losses resulted in a substantial increase in pretax segment income from $936M in 2020 to $2,928M in 2021 ![Total revenues and pretax income increased significantly from 2020 to 2021](image1).  The company's financial performance improved significantly from 2019 to 2021, primarily due to growth in non-interest revenues and a reduction in provisions for credit losses, which offset the decrease in net interest income and increased expenses.

Siemens Healthineers experienced notable shifts in its equity and liabilities between 2020 and 2021. Equity saw an increase of €3,828 million, reaching a total of €16,339 million [10]. This growth was significantly propelled by the issuance of new shares in March 2021, specifically to finance the acquisition of Varian [10]. This share issuance contributed to a rise in subscribed capital by €53 million and capital reserves by €2,284 million [3].  Despite this substantial increase in equity, the equity ratio actually declined from 76% to 55% [3].

This seemingly contradictory decrease in the equity ratio despite equity growth is explained by a "significant increase in loan liabilities" [3].  Indeed, Siemens Healthineers received substantial financial inflows from the Siemens Group, including borrowings of €10 billion and an additional €850 million, explicitly for financing the Varian acquisition [7]. These borrowings and other financing arrangements, alongside existing credit facilities, contributed to the rise in liabilities. While dividends paid to shareholders represented a cash outflow of €856 million [1] and decreased unappropriated net income [3], the overall net income for the year, combined with the capital increase, still resulted in a net positive effect on equity [3].

In conclusion, Siemens Healthineers' equity increased primarily due to capital injections related to the Varian acquisition, while its liabilities also significantly increased due to loans taken to finance this acquisition, resulting in a decreased equity ratio despite the overall growth in equity.

Overall, in both the European Union and Eastern Europe, cigarette shipment volumes decreased while heated tobacco unit shipment volumes significantly increased from 2019 to 2020.

In 2020, IBM's financial standing experienced notable shifts.  Despite the unprecedented environment brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, IBM maintained a strong balance sheet with considerable flexibility [3].  However, total equity saw a decrease of $258 million compared to 2019, primarily influenced by dividend payouts of $5,797 million and a $740 million decline in accumulated other comprehensive income, largely due to foreign currency translation adjustments [4]. This was partially offset by net income of $5,590 million and an increase from common stock of $661 million [4].  ![IBM's total equity decreased in 2020 primarily due to dividends and foreign currency translation adjustments](image1).  Conversely, IBM successfully reduced its total debt by $1,361 million from the prior year-end, reaching $61,538 million at December 31, 2020 [7].  This debt reduction occurred alongside an increase in cash, restricted cash, and marketable securities, which rose by $5,265 million to $14,275 million [7].  ![IBM reduced its total debt by $1,361 million from the prior year-end](image2).  Simultaneously, financing receivables experienced a decrease of $4,925 million, settling at $17,979 million [7].  ![IBM's cash and marketable securities increased while financing receivables declined in 2020](image3).  Overall, while equity diminished slightly, IBM strengthened its liquidity and reduced its debt, indicating a strategic realignment of its financial position from 2019 to 2020.

In summary, from 2019 to 2020, IBM experienced a decrease in total equity and total debt, alongside shifts in asset components such as increased cash and decreased receivables, while maintaining a strong balance sheet.

Qualcomm's tax provisions and benefits have experienced notable shifts across fiscal years 2019, 2020, and 2021. In fiscal year 2019, the company recorded a tax benefit of \$570 million due to certain foreign subsidiaries' elections to be treated as U.S. branches [6]. However, this year also saw a significant \$2.5 billion charge to income tax expense due to the derecognition of a deferred tax asset [6].  The total tax benefits related to share-based awards in 2019 were \$237 million [8].

Moving into fiscal year 2020, the landscape changed again. The total tax benefits from share-based awards increased to \$273 million [8]. Unrecognized tax benefits were reported at \$1.9 billion at the end of fiscal 2020 [3].

Fiscal year 2021 witnessed further developments. Unrecognized tax benefits rose to \$2.1 billion, primarily due to expected refunds of Korean withholding taxes [3].  The tax benefits realized from share-based awards saw a substantial increase, reaching \$567 million [8]. Additionally, the company continued to manage the financial implications of a one-time repatriation tax from fiscal year 2018, with estimated remaining future payments of \$1.9 billion at the end of fiscal 2021 [4].

In summary, Qualcomm's tax provisions and benefits fluctuated significantly between 2019 and 2021, with notable impacts from strategic tax elections, changes in tax regulations, and increasing benefits from share-based awards, alongside ongoing management of repatriation tax obligations and unrecognized tax benefits.

Earnings per share is fundamentally derived from the net income attributable to shareholders [5, 9]. To transition from IFRS reported figures to core results, several adjustments are applied to operating income [10].  These adjustments are substantial, totaling USD 4.9 billion in 2021, compared to USD 5.3 billion in the previous year [10]. These adjustments encompass a wide array of items, including restructuring charges related to rationalizing manufacturing sites, costs associated with acquisitions, and the amortization and impairment of intangible assets [2, 4, 6, 7, 8]. Furthermore, adjustments account for legal settlements, divestments of products and financial assets, and fair value adjustments [2, 4, 6, 7, 8]. Taxes are carefully considered for each adjustment, based on the applicable tax rate in the relevant jurisdiction [1, 3].  These adjustments, by their nature and magnitude, significantly alter both net income and consequently basic EPS when moving from IFRS to core financial reporting. The adjustments made to reconcile IFRS and core results have a considerable impact on net income and basic EPS.

In 2021, both cash dividends and treasury stock transactions played a significant role in shaping Chevron's equity structure and cash flow.  Cash dividends directly reduced the retained earnings, a key component of equity, as seen in the statement of equity, where cash dividends are explicitly listed as a reduction in retained earnings for 2021. ![Equity Changes](image3).  This action reflects a distribution of profits back to shareholders, decreasing the equity available within the company while providing a return to investors.

Furthermore, treasury stock transactions also influenced Chevron's equity in 2021. The equity statement details both purchases and issuances of treasury shares, indicating active management of company stock.  Purchasing treasury stock reduces the number of outstanding shares and decreases stockholders' equity, while issuing treasury stock can have the opposite effect, although in net, treasury stock usually represents a reduction in equity.

From a cash flow perspective, these activities are categorized as financing activities. The consolidated cash flow statement for 2021 shows a substantial cash outflow for cash dividends paid, reflecting the distribution to shareholders.  ![Cash Flow Statement](image4).  Additionally, the statement reveals cash outflows for purchases of company common stock for treasury and cash inflows from proceeds from sales of company common stock from treasury, further demonstrating the cash impact of treasury stock management. The adoption of AASB 16 Leases from 1 July 2019 brought about a significant change in accounting for leases, moving to a single, on-balance sheet model for lessees [2, 10]. This meant that the company, acting as a lessee, started recognising right-of-use assets, representing the right to use leased assets, and lease liabilities, reflecting the obligation to make lease payments [10]. For leases previously classified as operating leases under AASB 117, lease liabilities were measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments using the Group’s incremental borrowing rate at the transition date of 1 July 2019, and right-of-use assets were set equal to these lease liabilities, adjusted for any prepaid or accrued lease payments [8].  Furthermore, site restoration costs, which were previously treated differently, became capitalised as part of the lease right-of-use asset and depreciated over the lease term since the adoption of AASB 16 [4]. In contrast, liabilities for employee benefits like wages, salaries, and annual leave are treated separately; these represent obligations from employee services, calculated at undiscounted amounts based on expected remuneration rates, including associated costs, and are not directly impacted by the AASB 16 transition [1].

AASB 16 led to the recognition of lease liabilities and right-of-use assets on the balance sheet, changing the financial presentation of lease obligations but did not directly impact employee benefit liabilities.

The fair value allocation of net assets acquired shows both similarities and differences between the ClickSoftware and Salesforce.org acquisitions. For ClickSoftware, the acquisition involved a significant allocation to goodwill, primarily attributed to the assembled workforce and expanded market opportunities [3, 4]. This is also the case for Salesforce.org where goodwill is similarly attributed [3, 4].  In both acquisitions, the fair values assigned to tangible and intangible assets were based on management’s estimates and were preliminary, subject to further adjustments [4, 5].  Notably, both acquisitions also included transaction costs that were deemed immaterial [2, 8].

![This image displays the fair values and useful lives of developed technology and customer relationships acquired from ClickSoftware.](image1)

However, there are key differences. The ClickSoftware acquisition, valued at approximately $1.4 billion [8], explicitly recognized significant intangible assets such as developed technology and customer relationships, with fair values of $215 million and $61 million respectively [image1].  These intangible assets were subject to amortization over their useful lives [image1]. In contrast, the details provided for the Salesforce.org acquisition do not explicitly break down intangible assets in the same manner [image2].  Furthermore, the Salesforce.org acquisition involved the settlement of a pre-existing reseller agreement which was not at fair value, leading to a non-cash charge of approximately $166 million [10], an element absent in the description of the ClickSoftware acquisition.

![This image details the fair values of assets and liabilities acquired from Salesforce.org, showing a net asset value of $134 million.](image2)

Another difference is the scale; the net assets acquired for ClickSoftware totaled $1,386 million [image5], while for Salesforce.org, the net assets acquired were significantly smaller at $134 million [image2], indicating a considerably larger scale for the ClickSoftware acquisition.  Despite both acquisitions resulting in goodwill, the proportion of goodwill to net assets appears much higher in the ClickSoftware acquisition ($1,132 million goodwill out of $1,386 million net assets [image5]) compared to Salesforce.org ($164 million goodwill out of $134 million net assets [image2], which seems inconsistent and may indicate incomplete data for Salesforce.org net assets in image2 given goodwill exceeds net assets).

![This image summarizes the assets, liabilities, and net assets acquired from ClickSoftware, highlighting the substantial goodwill and intangible assets.](image5)

In summary, both acquisitions involved goodwill and fair value assessments with similar rationales, but ClickSoftware's acquisition was significantly larger, included detailed intangible asset recognition, and lacked the reseller agreement complexities seen in the Salesforce.org acquisition.

Toyota's executive remuneration system is intricately linked to business performance and shareholder value indicators. The system is designed to ensure that remuneration is effectively tied to corporate performance, reflecting both individual job responsibilities and performance [2].  Specifically, the Annual Total Remuneration is set using a formula that benchmarks executive compensation against other companies and is directly based on consolidated operating income and the volatility of Toyota's share price [1]. This approach ensures that as the company's financial performance improves, and as shareholder value, reflected by the share price, fluctuates, executive compensation is adjusted accordingly [3].

The determination of remuneration involves a structured process where the Board of Directors sets the policy, and the Executive Compensation Meeting determines the amount for each member, considering corporate performance, individual responsibilities, and performance [5]. This system includes both fixed and performance-based remuneration, with the latter directly tied to consolidated operating income and share price volatility, ensuring that executives are incentivized to drive business success and enhance shareholder value [10]. Toyota views the benefit of its shareholders as crucial and aims to improve corporate structure and value for sustainable growth, further aligning executive interests with shareholder interests through this performance-linked remuneration system [7]. Ultimately, Toyota's executive remuneration evaluation method directly reflects their business performance and shareholder value indicators by linking compensation to operating income and share price volatility.

Danaher Corporation's comprehensive income experienced a significant increase between 2018 and 2020.  The comprehensive income was \$2,005 million in 2018, rose to \$2,731 million in 2019, and then substantially increased to \$6,346 million in 2020 ![The table shows the comprehensive income values for 2018, 2019, and 2020, highlighting a significant increase in 2020.](image1). This notable surge in 2020 was primarily driven by a dramatic shift in foreign currency translation adjustments, which swung from a loss of \$75 million in 2019 to a gain of approximately \$2.9 billion in 2020 [1].  Furthermore, net earnings also contributed positively to this increase, rising from approximately \$2.4 billion in 2019 to approximately \$3.6 billion in 2020 [6].

In addition to favorable foreign currency translation and higher net earnings, a decrease in the loss from cash flow hedge adjustments in 2020 compared to 2019 also played a role in the overall increase in comprehensive income [1]. However, this positive impact was partially offset by an increase in losses from pension and postretirement plan benefit adjustments in 2020 compared to the previous year [1]. Despite this offsetting factor, the substantial gain from foreign currency translation adjustments and the increase in net earnings were the major contributors to the overall growth in comprehensive income from 2018 to 2020. In conclusion, Danaher Corporation's comprehensive income increased considerably from 2018 to 2020, primarily due to favorable foreign currency translation adjustments and higher net earnings, although partially offset by increased pension and postretirement plan losses.

These projects, often categorized separately, focus on long-term improvements in rural areas, distinct from immediate COVID relief efforts ![Rural Development Projects with details on location, duration, and implementation.](image2).  Examining the implementation modes reveals that both COVID Relief and Rural Development projects utilize both direct implementation and implementation through agencies, though the specific distribution may vary.  Projects related to COVID relief, especially large-scale initiatives, often involve implementing agencies to ensure efficient and widespread reach, while Rural Development projects might have a mix depending on the project's nature and scale.

In conclusion, while both COVID Relief and Rural Development projects address critical needs across India, COVID Relief projects are characterized by their immediate response nature and often larger scale during the pandemic peak, and both types employ varied implementation strategies involving direct efforts and partnerships with implementing agencies depending on project specifics.

Actuarial valuations are crucial for determining defined benefit obligations, relying on key assumptions such as discount rates, expected compensation increases, and pension progression and mortality rates [2]. These assumptions are sensitive, and changes in them can significantly impact the defined benefit obligation and the funded status of pension plans [4].  For instance, discount rates, a primary actuarial assumption, saw an increase from 2020 to 2021 across different currencies, as depicted in the rates for Euro, U.S. dollar, British pound, and Swiss franc. ![Discount rates increased from 2020 to 2021.](image4). The sensitivity analysis further illustrates how changes in these assumptions affect the defined benefit obligation. A decrease in the discount rate by half a percentage point would lead to an increase in the defined benefit obligation by €271 million in 2021 and €266 million in 2020, while an increase of the same magnitude would result in a decrease of €242 million and €227 million, respectively. Similarly, changes in compensation increase and pension progression also influence the defined benefit obligation. ![Changes in actuarial assumptions like discount rate, compensation increase, and pension progression affect the defined benefit obligation.](image1).  The overall impact of these changes in actuarial assumptions is reflected in the actuarial gains and losses. In 2021, there was a total actuarial loss of €22 million, a significant shift from the gain of €67 million in 2020. This change was largely driven by changes in financial assumptions, which resulted in a loss of €26 million in 2021 compared to a gain of €72 million in 2020. ![Actuarial losses increased significantly in 2021 compared to gains in 2020 due to changes in financial assumptions.](image3). Changes in actuarial assumptions led to a shift from actuarial gains in 2020 to losses in 2021, primarily impacting the defined benefit obligation.

McDonald's faced a challenging year in 2020, as reflected in an overall decrease in total revenues, primarily stemming from the International Operated Markets segment due to the widespread impact of COVID-19 [1].  This impact was particularly pronounced in markets like the U.K., France, Germany, Italy, and Spain, where temporary restaurant closures and restricted operations significantly hampered revenue generation [3]. The decline in revenue within the International Operated segment was a major factor in the overall decrease in restaurant margins for the company [10].  Simultaneously, the U.S. market demonstrated positive sales performance; however, this growth was counterbalanced by substantial investments in marketing and franchisee support initiatives aimed at accelerating recovery and stimulating growth, including the notable "Thank You Meals" program for first responders and healthcare workers [1].  These support measures, along with investments in Experience of the Future ("EOTF"), also influenced franchised margins in the U.S. [2]. Despite positive sales trends in the U.S., the International Operated Markets experienced negative comparable sales across most markets due to COVID-19, with the same European countries leading the decline, although Australia showed some positive results [4]. The decrease in operating income within the International Operated Markets was attributed to these sales declines, coupled with over $\S100$ million in marketing support, increased COVID-19 related operational expenses such as employee costs, and other factors like restaurant closing costs and obsolete inventory payments [5].  It's important to note that both U.S. and International Operated Markets saw increased company-operated margin expenses due to COVID-19 related costs for employees, protective equipment, and restaurant modifications [6].  McDonald's revenue model is based on sales from company-operated restaurants and fees from franchised locations, with franchised restaurants making up a significant majority of their global presence [7, 9].  The predominantly fixed cost structure of franchised margins contrasts with the more variable nature of company-operated restaurant expenses, which is pertinent to understanding overall profitability shifts during this period [8].

In 2020, McDonald's experienced revenue declines in its International Operated Markets segment due to COVID-19 impacts, while the U.S. market showed positive sales growth offset by significant support investments.

Examining the sales of Prolia®, Neulasta®, and Otezla® between 2018 and 2020 reveals distinct trends across different regions. Prolia® demonstrated consistent growth in both the U.S. and the rest of the world (ROW). Specifically, U.S. sales climbed from $1,500 million in 2018 to $1,830 million in 2020, while ROW sales increased from $791 million to $933 million in the same period, indicating a robust upward trend.  ![Prolia® sales saw steady growth across US and ROW from 2018 to 2020](image2). This growth in Prolia's global sales was attributed to increased unit demand and a higher net selling price [4].

Conversely, Neulasta® experienced a significant decline in sales in both the U.S. and ROW markets from 2018 to 2020. U.S. sales plummeted from $3,866 million in 2018 to $2,001 million in 2020, and ROW sales decreased from $609 million to $292 million during the same timeframe. ![Neulasta® sales declined sharply in both US and ROW from 2018 to 2020](image5).  This decrease was largely due to biosimilar competition impacting both net selling price and unit demand [5], a consequence of increased competition from biosimilar versions in the United States and Europe [1].

In contrast, Otezla® presents a different scenario, primarily because it was acquired in November 2019.  While data for 2018 is unavailable, sales in 2020, after its acquisition, were substantially higher in both the U.S. ($1,790 million) and ROW ($405 million) compared to 2019 (U.S.: $139 million; ROW: $39 million). ![Otezla® sales increased significantly from 2019 to 2020 post-acquisition](image4). This surge in sales post-acquisition suggests a strong market reception and integration into the acquiring company's portfolio, positioning Otezla® as a significant growth driver [8].

In summary, Prolia® sales consistently increased, Neulasta® sales sharply declined due to biosimilar competition, and Otezla® sales dramatically increased following its acquisition in late 2019.

Value-Added Services highlight a multifaceted commercialization approach [7]. The net value of solar energy systems saw a reduction between 2019 and 2020, as detailed in the financial information ![The table shows financial data related to solar energy systems for the years ended December 31, 2020, and December 31, 2019](image2). The net value was $6,138 million in 2019, which decreased to $5,979 million in 2020. This happened even as the value of solar energy systems in service increased from $6,682 million in 2019 to $6,758 million in 2020 [2]. The increase in accumulated depreciation and amortization, from $(723) million in 2019 to $(955) million in 2020, played a key role in this net value decrease. The total net value of assets rose from $10,396 million in 2019 to $12,747 million in 2020, as shown in the asset breakdown ![The table provides a breakdown of asset categories and their recorded values as of December 31, 2020, and December 31, 2019, along with accumulated depreciation and total net value](image1). The depreciation expense for property, plant, and equipment was $\S1.37$ billion in 2019 and increased to $\S1.57$ billion in 2020 [5], reflecting the higher depreciation aligned with asset growth.

Accumulated depreciation decreased the net value of solar energy systems from 2019 to 2020, while for property, plant, and equipment overall, increased asset values led to a net increase despite higher accumulated depreciation.

Shareholders' equity is directly influenced by a company's net income and comprehensive income, as these represent key changes in the financial position of the business over time.  Net income, which is a component of comprehensive income, reflects the profit earned from the company's operations after all expenses are accounted for. Comprehensive income is a broader measure that includes net income and other changes in equity from non-owner sources, such as foreign currency translation adjustments and unrealized gains or losses on certain investments.

For Accenture, we can observe the progression of these figures over three fiscal years. In fiscal year 2018, Accenture's net income was approximately $4,214.6 million, and the comprehensive income attributable to Accenture PLC was about $3,578.5 million, as detailed in a financial table summarizing Accenture PLC's financial data across fiscal years [![The table displays Accenture PLC's net income and comprehensive income figures for fiscal years 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image2)].  The changes in shareholders' equity for this period, including the impact of net income and comprehensive income, are further elaborated in a table outlining equity changes from August 2017 to August 2018, reflecting how these earnings contribute to the overall equity balance [![This table details the changes in Accenture's shareholders' equity for the fiscal year ending August 31, 2018, including net income and comprehensive income contributions.](image3)].

Moving into fiscal year 2019, Accenture saw an increase in both measures. Net income rose to around $4,846.2 million, and comprehensive income attributable to Accenture PLC increased to approximately $4,514.7 million [![The table displays Accenture PLC's net income and comprehensive income figures for fiscal years 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image2)].  These increases are reflected in the changes to shareholders’ equity for the year ending August 2019, demonstrating the positive impact of higher earnings on the equity position [![This table details the changes in Accenture's shareholders' equity for the fiscal year ending August 31, 2019, including net income and comprehensive income contributions.](image4)].

By fiscal year 2020, Accenture's financial performance continued to improve. Net income reached approximately $5,185.3 million, and comprehensive income attributable to Accenture PLC was about $5,386.6 million [![The table displays Accenture PLC's net income and comprehensive income figures for fiscal years 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image2)].  The cumulative effect of these incomes, along with other equity transactions, is summarized in the shareholders' equity changes for the fiscal year ending August 2020, which shows how net income and comprehensive income are key components in the overall change in shareholders' equity [![This table summarizes the changes in shareholder equity for Accenture up to August 31, 2020, highlighting the impact of net income and comprehensive income on total equity.](image5)].

Accenture's net income and comprehensive income positively and cumulatively increased total shareholders' equity from 2018 to 2020.

Lovisa's international store expansion has been a core strategy for growth, focusing on establishing a global footprint while maintaining profitability [4, 10]. The company adopts a nimble and opportunistic approach to entering new markets, carefully assessing each region and leveraging local networks to build knowledge and secure store portfolios [3]. This strategic entry allows Lovisa to quickly establish a significant presence in new territories.  ![The table outlines Lovisa's international expansion strategy, highlighting achievements such as opening 47 stores outside Australia and expanding into key markets like the UK, France, and the USA.](image4)  This expansion is evident in the increasing number of stores across various countries and regions from 2016 to 2020.  ![This bar chart visually represents the consistent increase in Lovisa's Gross Margin % over the years, peaking at 80% in FY18 and FY19, indicating strong financial performance alongside international expansion.](image3) Lovisa aims to secure quality retail sites in high pedestrian traffic locations, typically within AA, A, or B grade shopping centers, utilizing a refined global store model of approximately 50 square meters to facilitate rapid and cost-effective store roll-outs [9].  However, the fast-fashion jewellery sector is highly competitive with relatively low barriers to entry, posing a challenge to maintaining market share and brand recognition [7]. Despite this, Lovisa's established business model, design team, and store network create substantial barriers for new entrants to directly compete, offering a degree of protection in the expanding international market [8].

Lovisa's international store expansion strategy from 2016 to 2020 demonstrates a consistent and successful drive to increase its global presence and market share.

![Interest expense also decreased in 2020 compared to 2019](image2)

![Net operating income and profit for the year decreased from 2019 to 2020](image5)

In 2020, Nestlé experienced varying organic growth and trading operating profit margins across its geographic zones. Zone EMENA (Europe, Middle East, and North Africa) demonstrated a positive organic growth of $2.9\%$, driven by a strong real internal growth (RIG) of $3.3\%$ although partially offset by negative pricing [1]. This zone achieved its best organic growth in five years, with broad-based positive growth across all regions, particularly in Russia, Germany, the United Kingdom, and Israel, and market share gains in pet food and coffee products [2].  ![Zone EMENA achieved 2.9% organic growth with a 18.6% underlying trading operating profit margin.](image3)  The underlying trading operating profit margin for Zone EMENA increased by 50 basis points to $18.6\%$ [1], benefiting from lower marketing expenses and cost reductions [9].

Zone AOA (Asia, Oceania, and sub-Saharan Africa) showed a modest organic growth of $0.5\%$, with flat RIG and a $0.5\%$ contribution from pricing [3]. While experiencing a sales decline in China, this was compensated by mid-single-digit organic growth in other regions within AOA [7].  ![Zone AOA reported 0.5% organic growth and a 22.2% underlying trading operating profit margin.](image2)  Despite positive RIG in Japan, South Korea, and Oceania, negative pricing resulted in almost flat organic growth for these combined markets [3]. The underlying trading operating profit margin in Zone AOA decreased by 30 basis points to $22.2\%$ due to commodity inflation and COVID-19 costs, which outweighed reduced marketing expenses [3, 8].

"Other businesses," including Nespresso and Nestlé Health Science, exhibited the highest organic growth at $7.9\%$, fueled by a robust $7.3\%$ RIG and $0.6\%$ pricing [4, 5]. Notably, Nestlé Health Science was entirely driven by RIG [4].  ![Other businesses achieved a high organic growth of 7.9% and a 19.6% underlying trading operating profit margin.](image1)  The underlying trading operating profit margin for Other businesses increased significantly by 90 basis points to $19.6\%$ [4].

In summary, organic growth rates and trading operating profit margins varied across Nestlé’s zones in 2020, with "Other businesses" leading in organic growth, while Zone AOA maintained the highest profit margin despite a slight decrease.

Examining the inventory composition reveals a notable increase across all categories from 2019 to 2020. Specifically, finished goods inventory rose to $1,232 million in 2020 from $833 million in 2019, work in process increased to $369 million from $285 million, and raw materials reached $691 million from $510 million, culminating in a total inventory of $2,292 million in 2020 compared to $1,628 million in 2019. ![Inventory levels increased in all categories from 2019 to 2020](image1).  This overall increase in inventory is partially reflected in the cost of sales, as highlighted by acquisition-related charges from fair value adjustments to inventory linked to the Cytiva Acquisition, which alone augmented the cost of sales by $457 million in 2020 [9]. Despite the company utilizing the LIFO method for inventory valuation, the difference between LIFO and FIFO was deemed insignificant, and the liquidation of LIFO inventory had no substantial impact on the financial results [7].

Turning to lease assets, the company's operating lease Right-of-Use (ROU) assets also saw an increase, climbing to $942 million in 2020 from $764 million in 2019.  ![Operating lease ROU assets increased from 2019 to 2020](image4).  This is further contextualized by the lease liability data, which similarly shows growth in both current and long-term operating lease liabilities. The weighted average remaining lease term remained constant at 7 years for both periods, while the weighted average discount rate slightly decreased from 3.1% in 2019 to 2.8% in 2020 [5].

In conclusion, both inventory and lease assets saw significant increases from 2019 to 2020, with inventory growth impacting the cost of sales and lease asset growth reflected in the balance sheet through increased ROU assets and lease liabilities. These changes, particularly the inventory adjustments, are partly attributable to acquisitions like Cytiva, demonstrating how strategic business activities influence the financial statement's asset and liability sections.

Roche's business operations are divided into two primary divisions: Pharmaceuticals and Diagnostics [7].  The Pharmaceuticals division encompasses Roche Pharmaceuticals and Chugai, and it has integrated Genentech as a segment within Roche Pharmaceuticals [1].  The structure of the Diagnostics Division underwent a transformation in 2021, shifting from a business area framework to a customer-centric model [10].  Prior to 2021, the Diagnostics division was organized into business areas such as Centralised and Point of Care Solutions, Molecular Diagnostics, Tissue Diagnostics, and Diabetes Care. As of 2021, this structure was replaced by customer areas including Core Lab, Molecular Lab, Point of Care, Pathology Lab, and Diabetes Care [10]. This structural shift in the Diagnostics division is visually represented in the following table: ![The table illustrates the change in Diagnostics division structure from business areas to customer areas starting in 2021.](image3).

Key executives responsible for overseeing these divisions are part of the Corporate Executive Committee.  This committee includes the CEO of Roche Group, the CEO of Pharmaceuticals, and the CEO of Diagnostics, among other key roles [image4].  The composition of the Corporate Executive Committee as of December 31, 2021, is detailed in the following table, outlining the key leaders at the helm of Roche’s divisions: ![The table shows the composition of the Corporate Executive Committee and Enlarged Corporate Executive Committee as of December 31, 2021, listing key executive roles and names.](image1).

In summary, the Diagnostics division transitioned from business areas to customer areas in 2021, and key executives like the CEOs of Pharmaceuticals and Diagnostics within the Corporate Executive Committee are central to managing these divisions.

To understand the fluctuation in the weighted-average grant date fair value, one would typically examine summaries of stock option and restricted share activities. These summaries, detailed for the year ended December 31, 2020, are mentioned to be available in a tabular format [5, 6].  The principal financial elements considered when determining the fair value of stock options at the time of grant include several key factors [8]. These factors are the risk-free interest rates, expected volatilities, expected dividend yields, and expected lives of the options [8]. Specifically, risk-free interest rates are derived from U.S. Treasury yields at the grant's inception, while expected volatilities are assessed from the company's stock's historical volatility and implied volatility from traded options. Expected dividend yields are based on the company's per share cash dividend. Furthermore, historical data aids in estimating option exercises and forfeitures, and expected option lives are gauged from past exercise patterns [7].

To determine the change from 2018 to 2020 in the weighted-average grant date fair value and to see the actual values for 2020, one would need to refer to the tables mentioned in quotes [5] and [6], which are not provided here in text format. The increase in noncurrent assets by $^{\S3,039}$ million indicates a growth in IBM's resources, which is further detailed as a $^{\S}829$ million increase when adjusted for currency [4]. Simultaneously, long-term debt saw a slight rise, as shown in financial data for 2020 and 2019 ![Noncurrent assets increased while long-term debt saw a slight rise between 2019 and 2020](image2). This minor increase in long-term debt occurred while overall company debt actually decreased by $^{\oplus1,361}$ million, or $^{\oplus2,859}$ million when adjusted for currency, primarily due to debt retirements and maturities partially offset by new issuances [9]. This suggests a strategic management of debt, potentially shifting its composition or focusing on reducing total liabilities, as evidenced by the total company debt figures for 2020 and 2019 ![Total company debt decreased between 2019 and 2020, alongside Global Financing segment debt](image4).

Despite these changes in assets and debt, financing activities transitioned to a net use of cash in 2020, a significant shift from being a net source of cash in 2019, reflecting a year-over-year change of $^{\S18,763}$ million [10]. This shift in financing activities occurred in a context where net cash from operating activities increased substantially, from $^{\S14,770}$ million in 2019 to $^{\S18,197}$ million in 2020, and investing activities required less cash due to factors like the Red Hat acquisition being in the prior year ![Net cash from operating activities increased while financing activities became a net use of cash in 2020](image3).  Furthermore, while total equity decreased by $^{\S258}$ million, primarily due to dividends and foreign currency adjustments, Global Financing maintained a consistent return on equity of 25.8% in both 2019 and 2020 ![Global Financing maintained a consistent return on equity in 2019 and 2020](image1), indicating stable profitability within this segment despite broader equity fluctuations [7].

In conclusion, while IBM experienced growth in noncurrent assets and managed to reduce overall debt, a shift towards cash use in financing activities and a slight equity decrease suggest a complex financial landscape where strategic debt management and operational cash generation are key to maintaining financial stability.

In 2020, there was a noticeable downturn in credit card activity, with outstandings decreasing by $\S18.9$ billion to $\Updownarrow78.7$ billion [4]. This reduction was mirrored in purchase volumes, which declined by $\Updownarrow26.3$ billion to $\S251.6$ billion, a shift attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on consumer spending [6].  However, despite this decrease, the risk-adjusted margin for credit cards actually increased, rising from 8.28 in 2019 to 9.16 in 2020, suggesting improved profitability despite lower overall activity ![The table shows that credit card purchase volumes decreased from $277,852 million in 2019 to $251,599 million in 2020](image2).

Conversely, debit card usage saw an increase, with purchase volumes rising by $\S23.8$ billion to $\S384.5$ billion, even amidst the pandemic [6].  Similarly, the home equity sector experienced a contraction, as originations in Consumer Banking decreased from $9,755 million in 2019 to $6,930 million in 2020, and total originations also fell from $11,131 million to $8,160 million ![The table shows that home equity originations in Consumer Banking decreased from $9,755 million in 2019 to $6,930 million in 2020](image4). This decline in home equity production and credit card usage, contrasted with increased debit card activity, indicates a shift in consumer behavior towards reduced borrowing and spending on credit, possibly due to economic uncertainty and a preference for using available funds or debit instruments during the pandemic.

Commodity prices significantly drive BHP's financial outcomes [5]. In contrast, coal experienced a decrease in Underlying EBITDA, largely due to lower price impacts [2]. ![The table shows financial figures for Coal, highlighting the decrease in revenue and underlying EBITDA in 2021 compared to 2020, alongside reduced average realized prices for metallurgical and hard coking coal](image2).  Therefore, commodity price variations are a key determinant of BHP's financial results, with demand and market sentiment playing crucial roles in the performance of commodities like nickel, while price fluctuations directly impact the profitability of coal operations.

In the financial year spanning from 2020 to 2021, there were notable shifts in both net interest income and noninterest income as reflected in the income statement summary. Net interest income experienced a considerable downturn, moving from $441 million in 2020 to a deficit of $(1,541) million in 2021, while noninterest income saw a substantial surge, climbing from $4,916 million to $10,036 million within the same timeframe. ![The income statement shows a decrease in net interest income and a significant increase in noninterest income from 2020 to 2021](image1). The decline in net interest income can be attributed to a confluence of factors, including the impact of reduced interest rates, a decrease in loan balances due to weakened demand, increased prepayment and refinancing activities, and the divestiture of the student loan portfolio during the first half of 2021 [3].  Conversely, the rise in noninterest income was propelled by increased net gains from equity securities, enhanced mortgage banking income, and stronger investment advisory and other asset-based fee income [9]. This surge in noninterest income was further supported by higher unrealized gains from nonmarketable equity securities and realized gains from equity securities sales, coupled with a reduction in equity securities impairment owing to improved market conditions [7].  Despite the contraction in net interest income, the marked expansion of noninterest income was robust enough to drive an overall increase in total revenue from 2020 to 2021.

The Global Technology Services (GTS) segment experienced a decrease in external total gross profit, moving from $9,515 million in 2019 to $8,975 million in 2020, which is a 5.7% year-over-year decrease. Despite this decrease in gross profit, the gross profit margin for GTS remained flat at 34.8% in both 2020 and 2019 ![The gross profit margin for GTS was flat year-over-year in 2020](image5). According to the text, this stable margin was achieved through workforce rebalancing and a shift towards higher-value business, although it was partially offset by revenue declines in TSS [1].  However, pre-tax income for GTS significantly decreased by 92.9%, falling from $1,645 million in 2019 to $117 million in 2020, and the pre-tax margin also declined by 5.3 percentage points to 0.4% in 2020 ![Pre-tax income and margin for GTS decreased significantly in 2020 compared to 2019](image5). This substantial drop in pre-tax income and margin was primarily attributed to higher workforce rebalancing charges in 2020, which had a 4.2 percentage point impact on the pre-tax margin [1].

In summary, the Global Technology Services segment in 2020 saw a decrease in gross profit and a significant decrease in pre-tax income and margin compared to 2019, while maintaining a flat gross profit margin.

Capital ratios, crucial indicators of a bank's financial health, are meticulously tracked under both Standardized and Advanced approaches defined by Basel 3 regulations [2, 3, 9]. These ratios, including the Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) and Total Capital ratios, are essential for assessing capital adequacy and ensuring banks operate above regulatory minimums [4].  The presented data reflects the capital ratios calculated under these frameworks for the years 2019 and 2020.

![Table showing capital ratios and metrics for 2019 and 2020 under Standardized and Advanced Approaches](image5)

Examining the changes from December 31, 2019, to December 31, 2020, the Common Equity Tier 1 Capital Ratio increased from 11.2% to 11.9% under the Standardized Approach and from 11.5% to 12.9% under the Advanced Approach.  Similarly, the Total Capital Ratio saw an increase from 14.8% to 16.1% under the Standardized Approach and from 14.7% to 16.6% under the Advanced Approach, as detailed in the provided financial table.  In summary, both Common Equity Tier 1 Capital Ratio and Total Capital Ratio increased from 2019 to 2020 for both Standardized and Advanced approaches.

The valuation of available-for-sale securities is subject to market fluctuations, which results in unrealized gains and losses. These unrealized changes directly influence the recorded basis of these securities. As shown in the provided table, for securities with an initial cost basis of $534, unrealized losses of $5 net reduce the recorded basis to $529, and for securities with a cost basis of $375, unrealized gains of $6 net increase the recorded basis to $381 ![This table demonstrates how unrealized losses and gains adjust the recorded basis from the cost basis for available-for-sale securities.](image2). This adjustment to recorded basis to reflect fair value is further clarified as short-term investments classified as available-for-sale are indeed recorded at fair value, with these unrealized gains and losses being temporarily accounted for in accumulated other comprehensive income until they are realized [6].

The table breaks down the cost basis and fair value for available-for-sale securities, demonstrating this principle in practice. For instance, available-for-sale securities have a cost basis of $534 but a fair value of $529, reflecting a net unrealized loss and a corresponding reduction in recorded value ![This table illustrates the difference between cost basis and fair value for available-for-sale securities, showing how unrealized losses affect the recorded basis.](image3). It's also mentioned that significant changes in interest rates would not have a material impact on the fair market value, and unrealized gains and losses are channeled through stockholders’ equity [1].

Unrealized gains increase and unrealized losses decrease the recorded basis for available-for-sale securities in 2022.

Brazil Minerals Inc. has several mineral projects in Minas Gerais. For lithium projects in Minas Gerais, both hard-rock lithium properties and the Minas Gerais Lithium Project are in the Research Exploration stage, focusing on detailed mapping and systematic sampling [4, 9, image4].

![Lithium projects in Minas Gerais are in the Research Exploration phase.](image4)

The sand deposits along the Jequitinhonha River in Minas Gerais are considered to be in Commercial Mining, indicating active extraction and sales [6, image4].  A professional mining engineer surveyor has already measured substantial cubic meters of sand in one surveyed deposit [6].

![Sand project in Minas Gerais showing mineral rights in yellow.](image2)

Diamond projects in Minas Gerais, located along the Jequitinhonha River, are in the Pre-Mining stage, with mineral rights including mining concessions, the highest level of mining title in Brazil [7, image4].  Historically, this region is known for significant diamond production [7].

![Diamond projects in Minas Gerais are in Pre-Mining stage.](image4)

The Titanium Project in central-western Minas Gerais is currently in Research Exploration [3, image4]. Iron projects such as Rio Piracicaba, Barão de Cocais, and Itabira, also located in Minas Gerais, are at different stages, with Rio Piracicaba in Pre-Mining Licensing while Barão de Cocais and Itabira are in Research Exploration [image1].

![Iron projects in Minas Gerais have statuses of Pre-Mining Licensing and Research Exploration.](image1)

In summary, the mineral projects in Minas Gerais, Brazil, are in various stages ranging from Research Exploration for lithium and titanium to Pre-Mining for diamond and Commercial Mining for sand.

This growth in QCT revenue in 2021 by $64\%$ was primarily driven by increased demand for 5G products, recovery from COVID-19 impacts, and growth in automotive and IoT sectors [7]. Similarly, QTL revenues also saw a $26\%$ increase in fiscal year 2021, mainly due to higher estimated sales of 3G/4G/5G-based multimode products [7]. It is important to note that revenue reporting by country for QCT is based on the location where products are delivered, which is generally where customers manufacture their products, not necessarily where the end consumer is located or where the customer is headquartered [2]. For instance, revenue attributed to China might include sales to a South Korean company manufacturing in China [2].  While QCT revenue reached $\S27.0$ billion in fiscal 2021 [6] and both QCT and QTL segments showed significant growth in 2021 [7], the provided text quotes do not offer a direct comparison between the revenue from QCT and QTL segments and the revenue specifically from China and South Korea across 2019 to 2021.  Therefore, a direct revenue comparison using the provided text quotes is not feasible.

Between 2019 and 2020, the sales of cigarettes and heated tobacco units presented divergent trends across East Asia & Australia and Latin America & Canada. In East Asia & Australia, cigarette sales experienced a 9.7% decrease, while heated tobacco units saw a 10.4% increase, as visualized in ![Sales data for East Asia and Australia for 2019 and 2020](image2). This shift in East Asia & Australia was largely influenced by Japan, where cigarette shipment volumes decreased, but heated tobacco unit shipments increased [8]. In Latin America & Canada, cigarette shipment volume declined by 11.8%, whereas heated tobacco unit shipments significantly increased by 50.8% in the same period, as depicted in ![PMI shipment volume in Latin America and Canada for 2019 and 2020](image4). The reduction in cigarette volume in Latin America & Canada was primarily attributed to Argentina and Mexico, although partially offset by Brazil [8]. Factors contributing to these changes in Latin America & Canada included lower market share and consumer down-trading to cheaper brands in Argentina [5], excise tax-driven price increases and pandemic-related consumption pattern changes in Mexico [1, 5], and a lower total market coupled with pandemic-related mobility restrictions in Colombia [1, 5]. Canada's figures were also affected by the deconsolidation of RBH [5, 8].  In both regions, cigarette sales decreased while heated tobacco unit sales increased, but the underlying reasons and extent of these changes varied.

Discount revenue experienced a significant surge from 2020 to 2021, with an increase of 26 percent year-over-year [2]. This growth is clearly depicted in the financial data which shows discount revenue rising to $27,986 million in 2021 from $22,203 million in 2020 ![Discount revenue increased from 2020 to 2021 and its specific values for these years](image4).  Several factors contributed to this substantial rise, notably the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic's adverse effects, which boosted commercial billed business [1, 4, 5, 10].  The increase was primarily driven by growth in Card Member spending and worldwide network volumes, which saw a 24 percent increase [2, 5].  Furthermore, billed business, which constitutes a large portion of network volumes, grew by 25 percent, indicating a strong recovery and expansion in business activities ![Year-over-year percentage increases or decreases in network volumes and billed business](image3).  Interestingly, the average discount rate also played a role, increasing slightly from 2.28 percent in 2020 to 2.30 percent in 2021, attributed to a shift in spending mix towards higher T&E-related volumes [7].

In conclusion, discount revenue significantly increased from 2020 to 2021 due to factors like post-pandemic recovery, increased network volumes, higher card member spending, and a slight rise in the average discount rate.

Net cash from operating activities saw a notable increase between 2020 and 2021, rising from $24,737 million to $29,146 million. ![Net cash provided by operating activities increased from 2020 to 2021.](image3) This positive change was influenced by several factors affecting operating assets and liabilities [2]. Specifically, the timing of amortization and payments for film and television costs, alongside increased production spending, played a role. These were counteracted by a greater number of sporting events in 2021 and changes in accounts receivable and deferred revenue, including impacts from the Tokyo Olympics broadcast [2].  Moreover, increased cash distributions from equity method investments further contributed to the rise in cash flow from operating activities [5].  It's also worth noting that higher taxable income from operations in 2021, though offset by tax deductions from senior notes exchange, still played a part in the overall financial landscape [1]. In summary, the net cash provided by operating activities increased from 2020 to 2021 due to a combination of factors including changes in operating assets and liabilities and increased investment distributions.

The U.S. downstream segment experienced a notable financial turnaround, shifting from a loss to substantial earnings between 2020 and 2021 [10]. This positive change is visually represented in the provided financial table.

![U.S. downstream earnings moved from a loss in 2020 to profit in 2021](image1)

According to the report, U.S. downstream reported earnings of \$2.4 billion in 2021, a significant increase compared to the loss of \$571 million in 2020 [10]. Several factors drove this improvement, most notably higher margins on refined product sales, which contributed \$1.6 billion.  Additionally, increased earnings from CPChem, a 50 percent-owned entity, added \$1.0 billion, and higher sales volumes further boosted earnings by \$470 million [10]. While higher operating expenses partially offset these gains by \$150 million, the overall impact of these positive factors led to a strong earnings recovery in the U.S. downstream sector [10].

In conclusion, the U.S. downstream segment's earnings dramatically improved from a loss in 2020 to a profit in 2021, primarily due to higher margins, increased equity affiliate income, and greater sales volumes.

EBIT growth is a crucial determinant for the exercisable percentage of incentives over a performance period [2, 10].  As illustrated, achieving different levels of compound EBIT growth directly correlates with the percentage of incentives that become exercisable. For instance, if the EBIT growth falls below a certain threshold, no incentives are exercisable ![No incentives are exercisable when EBIT growth is below a threshold](image3).  However, as EBIT growth increases, the exercisable percentage rises incrementally.  One structure shows that 24% compound growth leads to 10% exercisable, scaling up to 100% exercisable at 26% compound growth ![Incentives scale from 10% to 100% exercisable as EBIT growth increases from 24% to 26%](image3).  Another similar incentive structure demonstrates that 17.5% compound growth results in 40% of incentives being awarded, reaching 100% at 25% compound growth ![Incentives scale from 40% to 100% exercisable as EBIT growth increases from 17.5% to 25%](image4).  The Board establishes these EBIT target growth hurdles applicable to performance option grants [2, 10].  Thus, higher EBIT growth leads to a greater percentage of exercisable incentives.

Chevron Corporation experienced a significant turnaround in net income, shifting from a net loss in 2020 to a substantial net income in 2021. The consolidated statement of income visually confirms this, showing a net loss of $\$(5,561)$ million in 2020 transforming into a net income of $\S15,689$ million in 2021 ![Net income significantly increased in 2021 compared to a net loss in 2020](image5).  This dramatic increase is largely attributed to several factors across different sectors.  In the U.S. upstream sector, earnings surged from a loss of $\S1.6$ billion in 2020 to a profit of $\S7.3$ billion in 2021, driven by higher price realizations, increased sales volumes, and the absence of impairments and write-offs that had impacted 2020 [9]. Similarly, U.S. downstream operations saw a turnaround from a loss of $\S571$ million to earnings of $\S2.4$ billion, primarily due to improved margins on refined product sales and increased earnings from CPChem [8]. International upstream also contributed significantly, moving from a loss of $\S825$ million to earnings of $\S8.5$ billion, mainly due to higher price realizations and the absence of prior year impairments [6].

Looking at comprehensive income, a similar positive trend is evident.  The consolidated statement of comprehensive income shows a comprehensive loss attributable to Chevron Corporation of $\$(7,484)$ million in 2020, which turned into a comprehensive income of $\S17,412$ million in 2021 ![Comprehensive income significantly increased in 2021 compared to a comprehensive loss in 2020](image4). This overall improvement in both net and comprehensive income reflects a strong recovery driven by improved market conditions and operational performance across Chevron’s business segments.

In summary, Chevron Corporation's financial performance dramatically improved from 2020 to 2021, with both net income and comprehensive income experiencing substantial positive changes due to higher realizations, improved margins, and increased sales volumes across its upstream and downstream operations.

The comprehensive income attributable to shareholders experienced a significant increase from 2020 to 2021. In 2020, it was \$3,677 million, rising to \$5,824 million in 2021, as detailed in the consolidated statement data ![Comprehensive income attributable to shareholders increased from \$3,677 million in 2020 to \$5,824 million in 2021.](image3).  This overall change is influenced by several factors. The profit of consolidated and affiliated companies, a key component of comprehensive income, increased substantially from \$3,003 million in 2020 to \$6,493 million in 2021 ![Comprehensive income attributable to shareholders increased from \$3,677 million in 2020 to \$5,824 million in 2021.](image3). This profit growth was largely driven by higher sales volume and favorable price realization [10].  Sales and revenues saw a 22 percent increase, reaching \$50.971 billion in 2021 compared to \$41.748 billion in 2020 [10].  Furthermore, other income components also played a role; for example, 2021 saw mark-to-market gains for pension and OPEB plans, contrasting with losses in 2020 [7].  Concurrently, the effective tax rate decreased from 27.8 percent in 2020 to 22.9 percent in 2021, further contributing to the profit increase [7]. Despite these gains, some factors partially offset the positive impact, including unfavorable manufacturing costs and increased SG&A and R&D expenses [10]. The comprehensive income attributable to shareholders significantly increased from 2020 to 2021, primarily due to increased profit driven by higher sales and favorable price realization, further enhanced by pension gains and a lower tax rate.

The financial data reveals a shift in the company's financial position over three years, particularly when examining interest and pension-related figures.  Notably, interest expense has risen from \$199 million in 2016 to \$350 million in 2018, as shown in the provided data table ![The table shows interest expense increased from 2016 to 2018](image1).  In contrast, interest income has also increased but to a lesser extent, moving from \$29 million in 2016 to \$70 million in 2018 ![The table shows interest income increased from 2016 to 2018](image1).  Furthermore, the pension and postretirement net periodic benefit, which was a benefit, has decreased from \$196 million in 2016 to \$73 million in 2018 ![The table shows pension and postretirement net periodic benefit decreased from 2016 to 2018](image1).  This change is partly explained by the year-on-year increase in pension and post retirement net periodic benefit non-service costs, primarily due to an increase in the net actuarial amortization expense [2].  Additionally, the early debt extinguishment charge of approximately \$96 million in the fourth quarter of 2017 significantly impacted interest expense for that year [1], and while not repeated in 2018, higher average debt balances and borrowing costs contributed to increased interest expense in 2018 [4].  The comprehensive effect of these factors is reflected in the total net amount, which transitioned from a benefit of \$26 million in 2016 to an expense of \$207 million in 2018 ![The table shows total amount changed from benefit in 2016 to expense in 2018](image1).

The total net expense increased by \$233 million from 2016 to 2018.

In 2020, there was a notable shift in IBM's cash flow from different activities compared to 2019.  Cash from operating activities saw a significant increase, reaching $18,197 million in 2020 from $14,770 million in 2019, an increase of $3,426 million. This improvement was largely due to a reduction in financing receivables through sales of receivables, enhancing the cash inflow from operations [5, 6].  Conversely, net cash used in investing activities decreased dramatically by $23,908 million, moving from a net use of $26,936 million in 2019 to $3,028 million in 2020. This decrease was primarily driven by a significant reduction in cash used for acquisitions, as the large Red Hat acquisition occurred in the prior year, alongside other factors like changes in finance receivables and marketable securities [2, 3].

![Net cash from operating activities increased while net cash used in investing activities decreased, and financing activities changed from a net source to a net use of cash between 2019 and 2020.](image4)

However, financing activities experienced a considerable swing, transitioning from a net source of cash of $9,042 million in 2019 to a net use of $9,721 million in 2020, a total change of $18,763 million [1].  Despite the decrease in free cash flow by $1,104 million to $10,805 million in 2020 [5], the combined effect of increased operating cash flow and decreased investment cash use resulted in a positive net change in cash of $5,361 million in 2020, a stark contrast to the negative net change of $3,290 million in 2019.  Overall, the shifts in operating, investing, and financing activities led to a positive turnaround in IBM's net cash position in 2020 compared to 2019.

Toyota's advancements in battery control models are integral to the evolution of their next-generation Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs), focusing on key aspects of battery performance and reliability.  Enhancements in battery control models are specifically aimed at bolstering safety, security, and longevity, which are crucial for reliable battery performance [image2].  These models are developed as part of a broader strategy to ensure battery security, which Toyota defines as encompassing safety, long service life, and high quality in their battery technology for EVs [image1].

This focus on longevity is evident in the development targets for BEV batteries, such as aiming for a 90 percent endurance performance in the Toyota bZ4X, which is set to be among the highest globally [3].  Moreover, improved battery control models contribute to enhanced power efficiency in vehicles. By optimizing energy management and thermal aspects through vehicle development, Toyota targets a 30% improvement in power efficiency starting with the bZ4X [image2, 8]. This improved efficiency not only reduces the demand on battery capacity but also leads to a decrease in overall battery costs [8].  Ultimately, the evolution of battery control models is a cornerstone in Toyota's strategy to create next-generation BEVs that are safer, more durable, and cost-effective.

Battery control model evolution is crucial for enhancing the safety, longevity, and efficiency of Toyota's next-generation BEVs.

Risk-based capital ratios are calculated using both Standardized and Advanced Approaches, which differ in their methods for determining risk-weighted assets (RWA) [1, 3]. In 2020, under both approaches, there was an increase in credit risk RWA, primarily due to derivatives and investment securities, influenced by market volatility and acquisitions [6].  Market risk RWA also saw an increase in 2020 under both methodologies due to higher market volatility [9]. However, operational risk RWA under the Advanced Approach experienced a decrease in 2020, attributed to fewer litigation-related losses [4].  Concurrently, Common Equity Tier 1 capital increased compared to 2019, mainly due to increased retained earnings and acquisitions [10]. It is also noted that the differences between the actual and required risk-based capital ratio were lower under the Standardized Approach in both 2020 and 2019 [1].  While specific figures for the change in risk-based and leverage-based capital ratios are not provided, the components that influence these ratios, such as RWA and capital, experienced changes in 2020 compared to 2019.  Therefore, while the exact change in risk-based and leverage-based capital ratios cannot be definitively stated, Risk Weighted Assets generally increased while Common Equity Tier 1 capital also increased, and the difference between actual and required ratios was lower under the Standardized Approach.

From 2018 to 2020, UnitedHealth Group experienced notable changes in its financial performance. Net earnings progressively increased, reaching $15,769 million in 2020, up from $14,239 million in 2019 and $12,382 million in 2018.  ![Net earnings steadily increased from 2018 to 2020.](image2) This upward trend in net earnings reflects the company's overall improved profitability during this period. Similarly, comprehensive income also showed an increase, though with some fluctuation in the rate of growth. In 2020, comprehensive income was $15,533 million, compared to $14,821 million in 2019 and $10,865 million in 2018. ![Comprehensive income also increased, showing yearly fluctuations.](image3)

These financial results are grounded in the operational framework of UnitedHealth Group, which operates with a mission to enhance healthcare for everyone [6]. A significant portion of their revenue comes from premium revenues, which are recognized as individuals become eligible for health benefits [9]. These revenues are primarily derived from risk-based health insurance arrangements [10], where premiums are set at a fixed rate, and the company manages the financial risks associated with customer healthcare costs. However, it's important to note that the financial statements, including these figures, are built upon estimates and judgments, particularly concerning medical costs and goodwill, which inherently involve uncertainties and potential adjustments in later periods [4]. Furthermore, specific revenue streams like Medicare Advantage and Medicare Part D premiums are subject to adjustments based on CMS's risk adjustment payment methodology, which apportions premiums based on health severity and demographic factors, adding another layer of complexity and variability to revenue recognition [5].

The net earnings and comprehensive income of UnitedHealth Group increased from 2018 to 2020, influenced by factors such as premium revenues, risk-based insurance models, and estimates inherent in financial reporting, as well as adjustments from healthcare regulations.

In 2020, ENBREL sales declined because of lower unit demand and reduced net selling price, a trend intensified by continuous market share erosion and a slower expansion of the rheumatology market due to COVID-19 disruptions [4]. However, in 2019, ENBREL sales had actually increased, mainly due to positive adjustments in estimated sales deductions and a higher net selling price, although this was partially offset by reduced unit demand [7]. The introduction of biosimilar versions of ENBREL, with a second biosimilar approved by the FDA in April 2019, and ongoing patent litigations, are key factors influencing ENBREL's sales performance [8]. In contrast, Prolia experienced sales growth in both 2020 and 2019.  Prolia's sales increase in both years was driven by higher unit demand and improved net selling prices [5].  The COVID-19 pandemic did have an impact on Prolia by disrupting patient visits, altering the timing of semiannual doses and decreasing new osteoporosis diagnoses, which softened the previously robust growth rates [6].

ENBREL sales decreased due to market competition and pricing pressure, while Prolia sales increased driven by strong demand, despite the pandemic's influence on demand patterns for Prolia.

In fiscal year 2019, Activision Blizzard's total net revenues amounted to $6,489 [image5]. The property and equipment, net, which can be considered as fixed assets, were $253 in 2019 and $282 in 2018 [image4]. To calculate the Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio for FY2019, we need to divide the net revenue by the average fixed assets. The average fixed assets are calculated by averaging the fixed assets from the beginning and end of the fiscal year, which in this case is the average of 2018 and 2019. Thus, average fixed assets are ($282 + $253) / 2 = $267.5.

![The balance sheet shows property and equipment, net in 2019 and 2018](image4)

Dividing the net revenue of $6,489 by the average fixed assets of $267.5, we get a Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio of approximately 24.25.

![The income statement shows net revenues in 2019](image5)

Therefore, the Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio for Activision Blizzard in FY2019 is approximately 24.25.

The Allowance for Credit Losses (ACL) experienced a notable increase from 2019 to 2020, moving from an initial balance of $590 million to an ending balance of $1,231 million [image4]. This shift is significantly influenced by several factors detailed in the provided documents. A primary driver was the adoption of the Current Expected Credit Loss (CECL) accounting standard at the beginning of 2020, which itself had an effect of -$41 million on the ACL [image4].  This adoption at the start of the year led to an initial increase in the allowance for credit losses of $131 million, primarily attributed to employee loans, although this was net of tax implications and reduced retained earnings [5].

![The ACL increased from $590 million to $1,231 million between 2019 and 2020.](image4)

Furthermore, the economic repercussions of COVID-19 played a crucial role in the increase of the aggregate allowance for loan and lending commitment losses during 2020 [8]. This impact is reflected in the substantial provision for credit losses amounting to $762 million, which accounts for actual and anticipated changes in asset quality due to the uncertain economic outlook caused by COVID-19 [8, image4].  In addition to these provisions, gross charge-offs of $105 million and recoveries of $8 million also contributed to the changes in ACL during this period [image4].  The ACL significantly increased from 2019 to 2020, primarily due to the adoption of CECL and the economic impact of COVID-19.

Bank of America integrates sustainability into its operations, striving to diminish environmental impacts [7]. Their leadership in sustainable finance is also evident in their active participation in global alliances focused on sustainable development, demonstrating a broader impact beyond their direct operations [4].  Bank of America actively addresses environmental issues and greenhouse gas emissions through operational changes, financial instruments, and industry leadership, significantly impacting both their operations and broader society.
