Views on expanding the U.S.-Mexico border wall are significantly divided along party lines.  Individuals who identify with or lean towards the Republican party show strong support for expanding the border wall.  Specifically, a large majority of Republicans favor substantially expanding the wall, with a margin of nearly eight-to-one [2].  This is further visualized in survey data, where 87% of Republicans support the expansion, contrasting sharply with only 11% who oppose it ![Republicans overwhelmingly favor expanding the border wall](image4).

Conversely, Democrats and those who lean Democratic are overwhelmingly against the border wall expansion.  Democratic identifiers and Democratic-leaning independents strongly oppose the expansion of the U.S.-Mexico border wall, with disapproval rates as high as 92% and 95% respectively [4].  This opposition is mirrored in the survey data, where 92% of Democrats oppose the border wall, compared to a mere 6% who are in favor ![Democrats overwhelmingly oppose expanding the border wall](image4).

In conclusion, Republicans largely support expanding the U.S.-Mexico border wall, while Democrats are strongly opposed.

Views on public health officials' handling of the coronavirus outbreak diverge significantly along party lines.  A notable partisan gap exists in the assessment of public health officials, such as those at the CDC, with Democrats showing considerably higher confidence than Republicans [9].  Currently, a substantial majority of Democrats, approximately $72\%$, express positive views of public health officials, while this sentiment is shared by only about half of Republicans, around $53\%$ [7].

![Democrats show higher confidence in public health officials than Republicans.](image2)

This difference is further highlighted by the changes in approval ratings over time; positive evaluations from Republicans have sharply decreased by 31 points since March, contrasting with the relatively stable views among Democrats [3].  This shift indicates a significant decline in Republican confidence in public health officials as the pandemic has progressed [4].

![Approval ratings for public health officials have declined more significantly among Republicans than Democrats between March and August.](image5)

In conclusion, Democrats are considerably more likely than Republicans to hold positive views regarding the job public health officials are doing in response to the coronavirus outbreak.

Based on the survey, 63% of respondents belong to the 'General Merchandise & Specialty' segment, as shown in the pie chart illustrating respondent segmentation.  ![Pie charts showing respondent segments and revenue](image3)  Furthermore, another pie chart details that 51% of the survey respondents have a revenue exceeding $1 billion.  In conclusion, 63% of respondents are in 'General Merchandise & Specialty' and 51% have revenue over $1 billion.

Compared to younger individuals, older adults historically adopt technology at a slower pace, yet they are increasingly integrating into the digital world [4].  While a considerable majority of seniors own cell phones [3, 6], adoption is still less prevalent than among all adults [3].  ![Cell phone adoption is lower in adults 65+ compared to all adults](image3).  Smartphones, specifically, have not achieved widespread use among older adults [1, 7, 6].  ![Smartphone ownership is substantially lower in adults 65+ compared to all adults](image1).  This disparity in adoption extends to internet and broadband access, with seniors lagging behind the general population [9]. ![Internet and broadband adoption are lower in adults 65+ compared to all adults](image3).  Moreover, technology adoption rates decline within the older demographic as age increases [2]. ![Internet and broadband adoption decreases with increasing age among seniors](image5).  Even among seniors with higher incomes, smartphone adoption trails behind that of the general population with similar income levels [8].  Thus, technology adoption rates are generally lower among adults aged 65 and older compared to all adults.

Currently, Caltrain utilizes 5-car trains running 5 times per hour during peak hours, resulting in 25 train cars in operation [10].  If Caltrain were to use Metrolink's used cars, this could shift to 6 trains per hour with 5 cars, requiring 30 train cars [9]. Electrification could further increase the capacity to 6 trains per hour with 6 cars, necessitating 36 cars. With longer platforms, 8-car trains could run 6 times per hour, totaling 48 train cars [5].  Looking at a scenario with increased frequency, potentially with High-Speed Rail integration, service could reach 8 trains per hour with 8 cars, demanding 64 train cars [2]. These varying scenarios and their corresponding peak hour train car requirements are clearly outlined in a table ![A table summarizing different Caltrain service scenarios and their peak hour train car needs.](image5). The peak hour train car requirement increases as Caltrain implements service improvements.

Public opinion suggests a dim view of the ethical conduct within the Trump administration [6].  These perceptions are not just negative in isolation, but when placed in historical context, they are significantly more critical.  Evaluations of ethical standards for Trump administration officials are lower than those for officials in the past five administrations [2], and reach record lows when compared across administrations dating back to the 1980s [5].  Specifically, only a minority, 39% of the public, believes the ethical standards of top Trump officials are either excellent or good [9]. ![Trump's approval ratings were at 39% in January 2019.](image5) This contrasts with the more favorable ethical assessments given to prior administrations [6].  In conclusion, ethical standards for officials in the Trump administration are rated more poorly than those of previous administrations.

While workforce automation's future impacts are a major concern, a segment of Americans is already experiencing its effects on their jobs [1].  Notably, younger adults, specifically those aged 18 to 24, are among the most affected demographics [1, 9]. This is further illustrated in the data, showing that within this age bracket, a significant 6% have reported job losses due to automation, and an even larger 11% have experienced reduced pay or hours for the same reason. ![The bar chart visually presents data showing that the 18-24 age group has the highest percentage of individuals who experienced job loss or reduced pay/hours due to automation compared to other age groups.](image1)  This contrasts with the overall U.S. adult population, where the impact is less pronounced, with 2% reporting job loss and 5% pay or hour reductions [1].

The age group most impacted by workforce automation in terms of job loss and reduced pay or hours is individuals aged 18-24.

Workers hold varied perspectives regarding the influence of technology in their professional lives, yet a considerable number acknowledge the positive contributions of tools such as email and social media to their career advancement [6]. A significant portion of workers specifically recognize email and social media as having a beneficial effect. ![Image3 illustrates that 60% of workers reported a positive impact from email or social media](image3). In conclusion, sixty percent of US workers indicate that email or social media has had a positive influence on their jobs.

Initially, public opinion showed more disapproval than approval for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS, with disapproval at 31% and approval at 54% in August 2014 ![The graph illustrates initial disapproval at 31% and approval at 54% in August 2014](image5). However, over time, approval for the campaign steadily increased, while disapproval saw a gradual decrease. By December 2015, approval had risen to 64%, and disapproval had slightly declined to 28% ![The graph shows approval increasing to 64% and disapproval decreasing to 28% by December 2015](image5). This indicates a positive shift in public perception, with a majority continuing to support the U.S. military efforts against Islamic militants [5].  Despite events such as the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, there wasn't a significant change in the public's view of the campaign [3], and in late 2015, a majority still approved of the U.S. military campaign, with 64% in favor and 28% opposed [10].  In summary, from August 2014 to December 2015, approval ratings for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS increased, while disapproval ratings decreased.

Public opinion towards China has shifted notably in recent years, with negative sentiments reaching unprecedented levels [9]. This shift is evident when examining trends over a longer period.  ![This graph illustrates the trend of public opinion towards China, showing a decline in favorable views and a rise in unfavorable views from 2005 to 2020.](image5).  As depicted in the graph, there has been a clear change in American perceptions of China over the years. The proportion of favorable views of China among the American public decreased by approximately 30% from 2005 to 2020.

Americans have generally perceived the U.S. as the world's leading economic power [1]. However, this perception has seen fluctuations over the years as depicted in the trend from 2008 to 2020 ![Line graph showing the trend of US economic power perception from 2008 to 2020](image1).  More recently, there's been a noticeable decrease in this view, particularly since March [2, 9].  Examining political affiliations, this decline is more pronounced among Democrats, with a significant drop from 54% in March to 44% currently [7]. This indicates that while a majority may still view the U.S. as economically dominant, confidence is waning, especially within the Democratic party.

In summary, Americans' perception of the U.S. as the leading economic power has decreased recently, with a notable partisan divide showing a sharper decline among Democrats.

Based on infrastructure survey results [1], organizations are evaluating different technologies for updates [9].  Looking at the readiness levels across various technologies from the IHL Group Store Infrastructure Survey 2015, we can see different adoption timelines. ![The bar chart shows that Beacons have the highest percentage of organizations with no plans for infrastructure updates among the listed technologies.](image5)  Specifically, when considering organizations with no plans for updates, Beacons stand out with the highest percentage compared to other technologies like Loyalty-Mobile App, EMV Compliance, WiFi-Store Level, WAN Bandwidth/Optimization, WAN/LAN Network Security, and VOIP. Beacons technology has the highest percentage of organizations reporting no plans for infrastructure updates.

Mobile advertising in Vietnam shows a significant focus on mobile applications. It has been reported that a large portion of ad impressions are specifically within mobile apps [6].  This focus could be related to platforms like Appota, which is described as a key mobile content distribution platform in Vietnam, aiding developers in reaching smartphone users and boosting app installs and revenue, as suggested by logos associated with app distribution and mobile app growth ![logos for mobile app distribution platforms](image3).  Therefore, the percentage of ad impressions on mobile apps in Vietnam is 84%.

Americans and Germans diverge in their opinions regarding which nation holds the title of the world's leading economic power [2].  A significant portion of Americans believe that the United States is the foremost economic power, while Germans are more inclined to identify China as the leader [1].  This difference is highlighted in surveys asking "% who say __ is the world’s leading economic power" [6].  Specifically, half of Americans consider the U.S. to be the top economic power, with about a third thinking China is, whereas over half of Germans believe China leads economically, compared to less than a quarter who think it is the U.S. [1].  These contrasting perspectives are visually represented in comparative bar charts, clearly illustrating the differing viewpoints on whether the U.S. or China is perceived as the dominant economic force by people in both countries ![The image is a bar chart comparing the percentage of Americans and Germans who believe the US and China are the leading economic power](image3).  In essence, Americans are more inclined to see the U.S. as the leading economic power, while Germans are more likely to consider China as the world's leading economic power.

The number of farms in the U.S. experienced fluctuations between 1880 and 1950, as indicated by available data. In 1880, the U.S. had 1,597 farms. By 1900, this number increased to 2,049, marking a peak in farm numbers during this period ![Table showing farm numbers from 1880 to 1950](image3).  This era also saw the rise of agricultural infrastructure, such as grain elevators, which became focal points in farming communities, reflecting the scale of agricultural output ![Grain elevators are central to agricultural towns](image1).

However, following 1900, a gradual decline in the number of farms began. By 1950, the number of farms had decreased to 1,453 ![Table showing farm numbers from 1880 to 1950](image3). This reduction aligns with broader trends of agricultural mechanization and farm consolidation, leading to larger but fewer farms [1].  Grain elevators, like those seen across the landscape, continued to be vital for handling and storing the yields from these evolving farms ![Grain elevators are central to agricultural towns](image2). These structures are indicative of the enduring importance of grain crops in the agricultural economy, even as farm numbers changed ![Grain elevators are central to agricultural towns](image5).

In summary, the number of farms in the U.S. increased from 1880 to 1900 and then decreased from 1900 to 1950.

Americans have mixed feelings regarding Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions [10].  While a considerable portion of the general population expresses a lack of complete confidence [6], Republicans generally show higher confidence levels in this aspect [9]. However, even among Republicans, a segment remains not fully confident, as detailed in survey results categorizing confidence levels across political affiliations ![Survey results indicate that 10% of Republicans/Lean Republicans are "Not at all" confident about Trump separating his business and presidential decisions.](image4).  Specifically, 10% of Republicans are not at all confident that Trump keeps his own business interests separate from his presidential decisions.

Perceptions of ethical standards in political parties vary significantly across different educational backgrounds.  Individuals with higher education, particularly college degrees, show a notable skepticism towards the ethical standards of both the Republican and Democratic parties [1]. In fact, nearly a third of college graduates believe that neither party upholds 'high ethical standards' [4]. This view contrasts with those who have less education; fewer individuals with some college experience or a high school degree or less education share this sentiment of neither party possessing high ethical standards [10].  This is further illustrated when examining how different education levels perceive whether parties are described by "high ethical standards" in general, as depicted in bar charts. ![This bar chart shows that among different education levels, college graduates are most likely to say neither party has high ethical standards.](image2)

Political affiliation also plays a crucial role in shaping perceptions of ethical standards.  While majorities within both Republican and Democratic parties tend to believe their own party has high ethical standards [3], independents are considerably more likely to say that neither party does [5].  Specifically, about a third of independents hold this view, a proportion that is higher than that of both Republicans and Democrats [5].  Looking at the broader public opinion, a significant portion believes that 'high ethical standards' describe only one party or neither party, rather than both [6]. Overall, public views on the ethical standards of the Republican and Democratic parties are quite similar, with roughly equal shares believing each party possesses such standards [8].  These differing opinions across political groups can also be observed in broader evaluations of political parties, highlighting the partisan divide in political perceptions. ![This bar chart compares opinions across different political groups, showing varying percentages for different perceptions.](image4)

In conclusion, perceptions of ethical standards in political parties are notably influenced by both educational attainment and political affiliation, with higher education and independent status associated with greater skepticism towards the ethical standards of both major parties.

While smartphones are becoming increasingly common, their adoption among seniors is notably lower compared to the general population [1].  In fact, only a small fraction of older adults, specifically $18\%$, are smartphone users, which is significantly less than the national average of $55\%$ [1, 6]. Interestingly, when comparing different devices, tablets and e-readers appear to resonate more with seniors than smartphones.

It is observed that tablets and e-book readers are equally owned by $18\%$ of older adults, and when combined, $27\%$ of seniors own at least one of these devices [5, 10]. This is in contrast to the $18\%$ smartphone ownership among the same demographic [5].  This suggests a preference or greater adoption of tablets and e-readers over smartphones within the senior community [3, 5].  Visually, this difference is clear when comparing device ownership between all adults and seniors, where tablet or e-reader ownership surpasses smartphone ownership only in the 65 and older group. ![Bar chart comparing smartphone and tablet/e-reader ownership between all adults and seniors, highlighting higher tablet/e-reader ownership among seniors.](image5)

In conclusion, tablets or e-readers are more prevalent among seniors compared to smartphones.

Hispanic Democrats express generally favorable views on the Democratic Party, though with moderate enthusiasm.  While a significant $87\%$ agree that the Democratic Party cares about Hispanics at least to some extent,  this is nuanced, as only $41\%$ feel it describes their views "very or extremely well," with a larger $46\%$ saying "somewhat well" [3].  In contrast, Hispanic Republicans hold a much different perspective, as shown in survey results ![Hispanic Republicans are significantly less inclined to believe that the Democratic Party cares about Hispanics compared to Hispanic Democrats.](image2).  Indeed, a considerable $63\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners believe the Democratic Party does not care about Hispanics "too well" or "at all well" [image2].  Even when considering that around a third ($36\%$) of Latino Republicans and GOP leaners think the Democratic Party cares at least "somewhat well" [8], this is still a significantly less positive view compared to Hispanic Democrats.  Hispanic Democrats and Republicans differ substantially in their opinion on whether the Democratic Party genuinely cares about Hispanics.

There is a significant level of discomfort among Americans regarding the use of automated programs, with a majority finding their application unacceptable [1]. This skepticism arises from worries that these systems might not be fair or accurate, and may encroach on personal privacy [4, 7].  For example, a large portion of the public, $68\%$, expresses disapproval towards companies utilizing automated personal finance scores [10].

![This image highlights that a large percentage of people find automated personal finance scores to be unfair or not very fair.](image2)

These concerns are echoed in specific worries about personal finance scores, where privacy violations emerge as a primary issue [9]. Many believe that these scores are unfair and fail to accurately represent individuals [6, 8].  Specifically, when considering why people find automated personal finance scores unacceptable, a significant $26\%$ cite privacy violations, $20\%$ argue that online data doesn't accurately reflect a person, and $15\%$ point to the potential for unfairness or discrimination [10].

![This image illustrates the main reasons why a majority of U.S. adults find the use of automated personal finance scores unacceptable, with privacy violation being the top concern.](image5)

In conclusion, the primary concerns of U.S. adults regarding the use of automated personal finance scores by companies are centered around privacy violations, inaccuracy in representing individuals, and inherent unfairness or discrimination.

Reports indicate that health is a growing worry among Arab youth, specifically mentioning an increase in concerns regarding obesity and lifestyle diseases [9]. This is visually supported by survey data from 2013 to 2014, where concerns about obesity amongst other health issues are compared ![This bar chart shows the percentage of concern about obesity increased from 12% in 2013 to 26% in 2014, indicating a significant rise in worry about this health issue.](image1).  The data clearly demonstrates a notable increase in concern about obesity from 2013 to 2014.

Internet and broadband usage among seniors is significantly influenced by age, showing a clear downward trend as age increases [5].  While younger seniors, particularly those in their mid to late 60s, exhibit substantial online engagement with around 74% going online and 65% having broadband at home [10], this adoption rate begins to diminish notably around the age of 75 [1, 7].

![The bar chart illustrates a decrease in both internet access and broadband connection among older individuals as they age, highlighting the digital divide within the senior demographic.](image4)

This age-related decline becomes more pronounced in older age brackets; for instance, among those 80 and older, just about 37% use the internet, and a mere 21% have broadband connections at home [8].  This contrasts sharply with younger seniors, indicating a digital divide within the senior population itself.  Overall, as depicted in the trend from 2000 to 2013, internet usage among the 65+ group has increased, but still lags behind the general adult population [image3].

![The line graph illustrates that while internet adoption rates have grown for both the general adult population and seniors over time, seniors consistently show lower adoption rates compared to all adults.](image3)

Even among seniors who are internet users, the frequency of going online tends to decrease with age, as a smaller percentage of the 65+ group goes online daily compared to younger age groups [image5].

![This bar graph illustrates that older age groups, specifically those 65 and above, have a lower percentage of individuals who use the internet daily or almost daily compared to younger demographics.](image5)

In summary, internet and broadband usage among seniors decreases as age increases, especially after age 75.

In STEM fields, it's observed that certain racial and ethnic groups are not proportionally represented when compared to the overall employment landscape [1].  Looking at the distribution, we can see these differences clearly.

![A bar chart showing racial/ethnic percentages in "All employed" and "STEM jobs", highlighting Asian overrepresentation.](image1)

Asians, in particular, stand out as being overrepresented in STEM occupations across various clusters, especially in computer-related fields and among those with college degrees [3, 4].  This pattern is further emphasized when considering the broader STEM workforce, where both Asians and whites are overrepresented, while blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented in comparison to their overall workforce participation [8, 9]. Therefore, Asians are the most overrepresented racial/ethnic group in STEM jobs compared to their representation in all employment categories.

To ensure the surveys were conducted effectively, a substantial number of personnel were involved in fieldwork across different waves.  For Wave I, the survey employed 52 individuals in the field, while Wave II utilized 50 fieldwork personnel, as detailed in the survey characteristics. ![Wave I employed 52 and Wave II employed 50 fieldwork personnel](image1).  In total, 102 fieldwork personnel were deployed for Wave I and Wave II combined.

Opinions regarding the necessity of government regulation to protect public interest are varied across different political affiliations [1, 8].  Looking at the opinions on whether "Govt. reg. is necessary to protect the public interest" versus "Govt. reg. of business does more harm than good", we see a split among different groups.  ![This chart shows opinions on government regulation, with Democrats mostly seeing it as necessary, while Republicans mostly see it as harmful, and Independents are divided.](image4).  Specifically, Democrats are more inclined to believe in government regulation for public interest, with 65% affirming its necessity, while a significant majority of Republicans, at 61%, think it does more harm than good. Independents are more divided, with 48% viewing regulation as necessary and 43% considering it harmful [image4].  This division highlights the differing philosophies on the role and impact of government intervention in business and public life.  Political affiliations hold contrasting views on whether government regulation is essential for safeguarding public interests.

Black adults demonstrate a higher level of attentiveness to campaign news compared to other racial groups, with a notable 30% of Black individuals reporting they follow campaign news very closely [1].  This trend is further illustrated in a visual representation of survey data, highlighting the varying degrees of engagement across different demographics.  ![Bar chart showing that Black adults follow the subject most closely compared to other racial groups.](image5) According to the bar chart, Black adults exhibit the highest level of attentiveness among racial groups concerning the subject at hand.  In summary, Black adults are identified as the racial group that follows the 2018 midterms most closely, as depicted in the bar chart.

Latinos generally hold differing views based on their political affiliations regarding the Republican Party's efforts to court their vote.  While a notable portion of Latino Republicans, specifically $40\%$, perceive that "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos’ votes," this sentiment is not as strongly shared among their moderate and liberal counterparts within the Republican party [1].  In stark contrast, a significant majority of Latino Democrats, around $70\%$ of liberals and $61\%$ of conservatives and moderates, disagree with the notion that Republicans are working diligently for Latino votes [1].  This divergence in opinion is visually represented, highlighting the partisan divide.  Democrats and those leaning Democratic overwhelmingly believe Republicans do not work hard to earn Latino votes, with $64\%$ expressing this view [image2].

Conversely, among Republicans and Republican-leaning Latinos, a smaller percentage, $27\%$, share the sentiment that Republicans do not work hard for their votes, while a substantial $34\%$ believe Republicans work extremely or very well in this regard [image2].  Overall, across the Latino population, only about one-in-five, or $19\%$, strongly agree that Republicans are making a significant effort to earn their votes [7].  Even within the Republican party, this view is not universal, with $40\%$ of Latino Republicans thinking Republicans work hard for their votes, compared to a mere $13\%$ of Latino Democrats who share this belief [7]. The data underscores a clear partisan divide in perceptions of Republican outreach to the Latino community.  Latino Republicans are considerably more likely than Latino Democrats to think Republicans work hard to earn Latino votes.

Indonesia has a significant mobile internet user base, with a large percentage accessing the internet through mobile devices [1]. This mobile-centric internet landscape is further emphasized by the popularity of Opera Mini for browsing, as seen in various data plans offered by Indonesian providers that focus on unlimited access through Opera Mini ![Promotional material for unlimited browsing using Opera Mini.](image5).  Given this context, mobile websites play a crucial role in online access.  Among the leading mobile websites accessed in Indonesia are major global platforms.  The ranking includes Google, Facebook, and YouTube, alongside content and blogging platforms like Blogspot and Wordpress, and local news sources such as Detik ![The table lists a ranking of Mobile Websites including Google, Facebook, Blogspot, Wordpress, Youtube, Detik, Yahoo, Twitter, Wikipedia, 4shared.](image2). These sites represent a mix of search, social media, content creation, and news that cater to the diverse needs of Indonesian mobile internet users.  Therefore, based on the mobile website ranking, the top 5 mobile websites in Indonesia are Google, Facebook, Blogspot, Wordpress, and Youtube.

Survey data inherently includes margins of error, especially when broken down into subgroups.  The specifics of these margins are detailed across various demographics to ensure accuracy in representing public opinion. For instance, examining the different political affiliations reveals how the survey's precision varies.

![The table displays data on unweighted sample size and margin of error for different political groups in a survey, showing that Moderate/Liberal Republicans have the largest margin of error.](image2)

The survey meticulously calculates these margins of error for each subgroup, reflecting the sample size and variability within those groups.  This careful consideration of statistical accuracy is crucial for interpreting the nuances of public opinion across different segments of the population.

Moderate/Liberal Republicans are the group with the largest margin of error in the survey data.

Voters experienced a range of emotions in response to Donald Trump's election [2, 10]. While some reactions were positive, a notable portion of voters expressed negative sentiments [5].  Notably, many voters felt uneasy about the election outcome [10].  This sentiment is visually represented in the bar chart, where "Uneasy" is shown as a prominent emotion experienced by voters, slightly exceeding "Hopeful" in prevalence ![The bar chart shows that 'Uneasy' has the highest value at 53, closely followed by 'Hopeful' at 51. Other emotions like 'Sad', 'Scared', 'Angry', and 'Proud' have lower values.](image5).  In fact, over half of the voters reported feeling uneasy [8]. Alongside unease, hope was also a significant emotion, with a similar percentage of voters expressing hopefulness [8].  Other emotions such as sadness, fear, anger, and pride were also present, albeit to a lesser extent than unease and hope [8].  Overall, voters primarily felt uneasy and hopeful about Trump's election, in accordance with the bar chart.

Vietnamese smartphone users exhibit a range of online behaviors, with certain activities being particularly popular on a weekly basis.  Among these, using social networks stands out as the most prevalent activity, engaging 59% of users. Following closely is the use of search engines, with 56% of users utilizing them weekly. Watching online videos also captures significant attention, with 54% of users indulging in this form of entertainment weekly. This preference for social networking, searching, and video consumption is clearly illustrated in a bar chart that visualizes the percentage of people participating in various online activities ![This bar chart shows the percentage of people engaging in various online activities, highlighting social networks, search engines and watching online videos as the top three.](image5). Therefore, the top three online activities performed by Vietnamese smartphone users weekly are using social networks, search engines, and watching online videos.

Initially, public opinion was largely positive regarding public health officials, with a significant $79\%$ approval rating in March [9]. However, this positive view has since diminished to $63\%$ [9].  Notably, this decline is largely attributed to a shift in Republican sentiment [4].  Republicans' positive ratings of public health officials have substantially decreased from $84\%$ to $53\%$ between March and August [1, 2, 8].

![Line graphs showing the change in approval ratings for public health officials, local officials, state officials and Donald Trump from March to August, broken down by political affiliation.](image3)

This represents a 31-point drop among Republicans, showcasing a considerable change in their perception [1, 2].  In stark contrast, Democrats' views have remained relatively stable, with around $74\%$ approval in March and $72\%$ currently [1, 2].  The partisan divide is evident when comparing current ratings: $72\%$ of Democrats versus $53\%$ of Republicans approve of public health officials' handling of the coronavirus outbreak [6].

![A chart showing the level of confidence in hospitals, public health officials, local officials, state officials and Donald Trump from Democrats and Republicans.](image4)

The data clearly indicates a significant decrease in approval for public health officials among Republicans, while Democrats' approval remained relatively consistent from March to August.

Hispanics have consistently shown greater optimism regarding their financial future when compared to the general public, particularly when looking at the period from 2004 to 2015 [10].  This trend is visually represented in survey data tracking favorable opinions over time, where the gap between Hispanic optimism and that of the general public widens notably by 2015. ![This line graph shows Hispanic favorable opinions starting higher in 2004 and increasing to a greater extent by 2015 compared to the general public, indicating a widening optimism gap.](image2).  Looking back to before the recession, it's evident that Hispanics currently hold more positive views about their financial situations than they did in 2004, a time when about a third rated their condition as excellent or good [5]. In contrast, the general public's financial sentiment is less favorable now than it was in 2004, when approximately half held a positive view [5]. The rise in financial optimism among Hispanics has been particularly pronounced since 2011 [6], and this increase in positive expectations from 2008 to 2015 is significantly larger for Hispanics than for the general population. ![This bar chart illustrates that between 2008 and 2015, the increase in the percentage expecting financial improvement was greater for Hispanics (+14) compared to the general population (+6).](image1). In conclusion, Hispanic financial expectations have not only been consistently higher than the general public's but also have shown a more significant increase between 2004 and 2015.

Older adults who use the internet overwhelmingly recognize its importance, with 79% agreeing that those without internet access are at a disadvantage due to missed information [1, 6]. This viewpoint contrasts with non-users, among whom only about half (48%) share this belief [7].  The differing perspectives are visually represented in the agreement levels concerning the statement "People without internet access are at a real disadvantage because of all the information they might be missing" ![The bar chart illustrates that internet users are much more likely to agree that lacking internet access is a disadvantage than non-users.](image3).  Notably, a considerable portion of non-internet users, 35%, actively disagree with the notion that they are missing out on important information [4, 10].  This divergence highlights a significant difference in how each group perceives the impact of internet accessibility on information access and potential disadvantages. In conclusion, internet users are considerably more inclined to perceive the lack of internet access as a disadvantage compared to non-users.

Americans hold varied perspectives regarding China's future influence on the global stage in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic [4].  Notably, half of the surveyed Americans anticipate a decline in China's international influence after the pandemic [3, 9].  This view is captured in survey results indicating that 50% of Americans believe China will wield less influence, as depicted in this chart. ![This image shows that the majority of Americans think China will have less influence](image4)  In contrast, fewer Americans, approximately one-in-five, foresee an increase in China's global power, while about a third believe its standing will remain largely unchanged [4].  However, these perceptions are not uniform across the American populace; significant partisan divides exist, with Republicans being more inclined than Democrats to predict a reduction in China's global clout [1].  Broadly speaking, negative sentiments towards China have been on the rise among Americans [3].  In conclusion, a considerable proportion of Americans perceive that the pandemic will lead to a reduction in China's influence in global affairs, with opinions differing along political lines.

Public sentiment regarding the nation's direction has shifted notably over the years, with a pronounced decrease in satisfaction.  As depicted in the graph, the percentage of individuals dissatisfied with the state of the country has generally risen, while the satisfied percentage has declined over time ![The percentage of dissatisfied individuals increased from 54% to 70% and the percentage of satisfied individuals decreased from 41% to 26% between 1990 and 2019](image4).  Currently, a significant majority, approximately seven-in-ten Americans, voice their discontent with the current trajectory of the nation, contrasting sharply with the mere 26% who express satisfaction [5].  This level of satisfaction remains low, as for over a decade, satisfaction has not exceeded roughly a third of the population, and today it registers at just 26% [2].  Moreover, recent data indicates a further downturn, with public dissatisfaction reaching its highest point in the past year, marking a 9 percentage point increase since September [4], and Republican satisfaction hitting its lowest mark in a year [10].  In conclusion, public satisfaction with the state of the nation has generally decreased from 1990 to 2019.

The assembly of Net Asset Value (NAV) for European venture funds by vintage year reveals a notable trend, particularly when distinguishing between realized and unrealized value.  As illustrated, from 1997 to 2004, European venture funds show a mix of both realized and unrealized NAV, with a noticeable portion remaining unrealized, especially in the years leading up to 2004.  ![NAV composition of European venture funds from 1997 to 2009, showing a shift to unrealized value for post-bubble vintages.](image4) This observation aligns with the fact that there is "almost no reported performance of post-bubble vintages(which effectively started only 2004/2005)" [1].  Post-bubble vintages, specifically from 2005 to 2009, are marked as 100% unrealized NAV, suggesting a phase where investments made after the bubble burst were yet to yield realized returns. This could be due to the "misleading published historical industry data for European VC" and limited visibility on fund performance [6, 9].  Despite the delay in realization, it's indicated that "these funds are significantly better performing" [1], pointing towards a future potential for NAV realization from these vintages.

The trend depicted is a shift towards a greater proportion of unrealized NAV in European venture funds for vintages post-2004, reflecting the delayed realization of returns from investments made after the burst of the financial bubble.

Following Trump's election, there was a prevalent skepticism among voters regarding its potential impact on race relations, with a considerable percentage anticipating a decline [10].  Specifically, nearly half of all voters feared that race relations would worsen, while only a quarter believed they would improve [8].  However, this pessimism was not uniformly distributed across voter groups.  A notable divergence existed in the outlooks of Trump and Clinton voters concerning race relations post-election [1].

![This image shows that Trump voters were optimistic that race relations would improve or stay the same, while Clinton voters overwhelmingly believed race relations would worsen under Trump's presidency.](image2)

Notably, Trump voters showed a distinct optimism; half of them anticipated improvements in race relations and over a third believed there would be no change [1].  In stark contrast, Clinton voters overwhelmingly expected race relations to deteriorate, with a large majority predicting worsening conditions and a negligible fraction foreseeing any improvement [9].  This divergence highlights a significant polarization in expectations based on voter preference.  In conclusion, Trump voters were considerably more optimistic than Clinton voters regarding the future of race relations following Trump's election.

It is generally believed that social media does not accurately reflect society's views [7]. In fact, a large majority of U.S. adults, specifically 74%, hold this belief. Conversely, only about a quarter, or 25%, believe that social media content accurately represents societal feelings on important matters [3].  ![This pie chart shows the percentage of people who think social media accurately reflects society](image2).  Therefore, approximately one-quarter of U.S. adults believe social media provides an accurate depiction of societal sentiments on significant issues.

European venture capital demonstrates a higher median multiple of cash invested when compared to the USA, indicating a potentially more efficient return on investment in the European market.  Specifically, the median multiple of cash invested in European ventures stands at 7.2, significantly outperforming the USA's median of 4.5, which suggests a greater return for every dollar invested in European ventures relative to their US counterparts ![Europe has a higher median multiple of cash invested at 7.2 compared to the USA's 4.5.](image3).  This observation aligns with the broader trend of European VC "driving the best exit multiples globally" [6] and proportionally "producing higher exit multiples" [9] when compared to the US.

Therefore, the median multiple of cash invested is higher in Europe than in the USA.

Many individuals anticipate a decrease in China's global influence following the coronavirus outbreak [3, 7].  The public opinion on this matter varies across different demographics, especially age groups, as depicted in survey results.

![The bar chart shows the percentage of different age groups believing China's influence will increase, remain the same, or decrease.](image2)

Analyzing the age breakdown, older adults are less inclined to believe in the increase of China's global influence. Specifically, the age group of 65 and older expresses the least belief that China's global influence will grow after the coronavirus outbreak.

Streaming has quickly risen to become the leading format in the music industry [7, 6].  As illustrated by comparing music distribution formats between 2014 and 2015, streaming's share of the market significantly increased, while the shares of physical and digital albums both decreased ![Streaming significantly increased its share of the music market from 2014 to 2015](image5).  This shift is further supported by data showing an overall decrease in total album sales and track equivalent albums alongside a notable increase in streaming equivalent albums during the same period ![Total album sales and track equivalent albums decreased from 2014 to 2015 while streaming equivalent albums increased](image2).  Therefore, physical and digital albums are reducing their business share due to streaming.

Conservative Republicans have expressed a sharp increase in their critical views of the government’s performance [2].  This shift is evident in their evaluations of governmental efforts to combat terrorism, which have become more unfavorable since the beginning of 2015.  Notably, only 27% of Republicans currently believe the government is performing well in this area, a significant decrease from 63% earlier in the year [4].  ![This line graph illustrates trends over time for Republicans, indicating their changing perspectives on perceived governmental efforts.](image3)  Furthermore, a growing percentage of Republicans, now at 71%, feel that anti-terrorism policies are insufficient to adequately protect the nation [3].  Overall, American evaluations of the government's endeavors to mitigate terrorist threats are currently at a low point [6].  In conclusion, Republican views on government efforts to reduce terrorist threats have become increasingly negative over time.

Since 2018, there has been a notable increase in negative sentiments toward China among Americans [7, 4]. This shift is evident when examining the feeling thermometer data, where the percentage of Americans feeling "cold" towards China (ratings 0-49) rose from $46\%$ in 2018 to $67\%$ in 2021 [6]. This trend is visually represented, illustrating the increase in negative views over time  ![The graph shows the increasing negative views of China from 2005 to 2021.](image1).  Notably, the proportion of Americans expressing "very cold" feelings, specifically rating China below 25, has approximately doubled from $23\%$ in 2018 to $47\%$ in 2021 [5]. This sentiment is distributed across various demographics, as shown in the percentages of "very cold" feelings among different groups  ![The bar chart shows the percentage of people who feel very cold and somewhat cold towards China across different demographic groups.](image4).  Interestingly, while negative feelings have grown across both Republican and Democrat affiliations, the partisan divide has also widened [1].  A substantial rise in "very cold" feelings is observed among Republicans, increasing by 31 points since 2018, compared to a 21-point increase among Democrats [1]. This partisan divergence in sentiment change is further detailed in the provided charts, highlighting the shifts within each political group from 2018 to 2021  ![The bar chart shows the change in warm or cold feelings towards China among different political affiliations from 2018 to 2021.](image5). Overall, perceptions of China have become significantly more negative across the U.S. political spectrum from 2018 to 2021, with a more pronounced increase among Republicans.

Based on a survey about laptop usage, it was found that a combined percentage of respondents access internet via laptop with some regularity ![Laptop usage frequency, showing 7% daily and 7% few times a week, 4% few times a month, and 82% never](image1). Specifically, 7% of respondents reported using laptops every day, and another 7% used them a few times a week. Therefore, the total percentage of respondents accessing the internet "few times a week or more" is the sum of these two categories.

In this survey, 14 percent of respondents access internet few times a week or more, based on laptop usage frequency as a proxy.

Americans have mixed views on their financial situations, with about half feeling financially secure [2], while perceptions of income relative to the cost of living vary significantly across different demographics [4].  For example, a considerable percentage of individuals with lower incomes feel their financial situation is worsening.  ![This bar chart shows that 69% of people with income less than $30K believe their income is falling behind.](image3)  Specifically, among adults with family incomes below $30,000, 69% report that their income is falling behind the cost of living [9].  Therefore, 69% of individuals with a family income below $30K believe their income is falling behind the cost of living.

Driven by access and technology, listening time is indeed on the rise [8].  Notably, streaming has rapidly become the dominant force in the music industry [6].  In 2014, streaming already accounted for a significant 20% share of the business, marking its growing influence ![Streaming accounted for 20% share in 2014.](image1).  The average weekly hours dedicated to listening to music also saw a substantial increase. In 2013, the average was 19 hours, which then rose to 25 hours in 2014, indicating a considerable growth in listening time ![Average weekly listening hours was 19 in 2013 and 25 in 2014.](image4). The difference in listening time in average weekly hours between 2013 and the year when streaming had a 20% share of the business is 6 hours.

Opinions on automated criminal risk scores are varied among US adults.  While some believe in their potential benefits for the justice system, a significant portion expresses reservations. Specifically, around 42% of U.S. adults find the use of automated criminal risk scores acceptable [8]. This perspective is visually represented in the opinions of U.S. adults regarding the use of automated criminal risk scores by the criminal justice system, where the "acceptable" segment is clearly delineated ![This image shows that 42% of US adults find it acceptable for the criminal justice system to use automated criminal risk scores.](image5).  Those who find it acceptable often believe it could enhance effectiveness, serve as a valuable component in decision-making, or introduce fairness and reduce bias compared to the current system [8].

According to the survey, 42% of US adults think it's acceptable for the criminal justice system to use automated criminal risk scores.

Organizations prioritize data security differently based on their size and revenue.  Notably, IT budget allocation for data security varies across different company tiers, as shown in the breakdown of budget percentages and PCI focus [image3].  Specifically, when examining the allocation of IT budgets towards data security across different tiers, it is evident that Tier 3, which represents companies with revenue under $500 million, allocates the highest percentage at 15.1% [image3]. This contrasts with larger organizations in Tier 1 (over $1 billion) and Tier 2 ($500M - $1 Billion), which allocate 13.8% and 13.3% respectively [image3].  Therefore, Tier 3, companies with revenue under $500 million, allocates the highest percentage of its IT budget to data security.

Radio listening habits show interesting variations when comparing rural and urban areas.  Specifically, the devices used to tune into radio broadcasts differ across these demographics.  Looking at the data, a notable trend emerges in device preference based on location.  In rural areas, a significant majority, 77%, rely on radio sets to listen, while 39% use mobile phones.  Conversely, urban areas present a different picture, with mobile phones being the more popular choice at 70% usage, and radio sets being used by 49% of listeners. This suggests a preference for mobile phones for radio listening in urban settings, while traditional radio sets remain dominant in rural areas. ![The infographic shows that in rural areas 77% use radio sets and 39% use mobile phones, whereas in urban areas 70% use mobile phones and 49% use radio sets.](image4)  Overall, radio sets are more frequently used in rural areas compared to urban areas, while mobile phones are more favored for radio listening in urban areas.

Therefore, news concerning the Vietnam mobile market, such as platform updates and competitive changes, are expected to appear in both Vietnam mobile news and APPOTA news.

While jobs in STEM have grown, especially in computer fields, the proportion of women in STEM roles has not significantly increased, remaining around half overall [1]. However, this broad statistic hides significant variations; for example, women are a small minority in occupations like sales and mechanical engineering, but constitute the vast majority in health-related STEM roles [1]. Despite overall STEM growth, particularly in computer occupations, women in these computer-related jobs are much more likely to report gender discrimination at work, with a striking 74% reporting such experiences compared to 16% of men in the same fields [8]. This disparity is further highlighted by the fact that women in computer jobs are considerably more likely to report pay inequities and feeling treated as incompetent due to their gender [6].

![This image illustrates that women in computer jobs experience gender-related discrimination at a rate of 74%, compared to only 16% of men.](image5)

This perception of inequity is also reflected in views about the technology industry more broadly, where women in computer jobs are more inclined to see gender discrimination as a significant issue [7].  Despite these challenges, STEM fields are generally perceived as offering better pay [2].  Considering the significant gender gap and reported discrimination within computer occupations, coupled with the general perception of high pay in STEM, it can be inferred that computer-related fields represent a STEM area with a notable gender gap in consistent equitable experiences and potentially high compensation. Ultimately, computer science related fields represent a STEM area with a large gender gap and likely high pay.

Men and women have different viewpoints on online interactions, as men are slightly more inclined to perceive negativity such as bullying and deception on social media platforms [2].  Specifically, men more frequently report seeing deceptive behavior online compared to women [5]. This difference is further highlighted when considering experiences with mean or bullying content, which men also report seeing more often than women [8].  These contrasting perceptions are visually summarized in bar graphs that directly compare men's and women's views on online behaviors, confirming these trends in a clear graphical format ![Bar graphs compare perceptions of online behavior between men and women, showing men are more likely to perceive deceptive or bullying behavior.](image2).  Despite these varying perceptions of negative interactions, social media users commonly encounter certain types of content.  Overly dramatic or exaggerated posts and content featuring accusations or arguments made without complete information are seen frequently by a large proportion of users [10].  The prevalence of these content types is further illustrated in a bar chart detailing how often users encounter various kinds of posts, emphasizing the frequency of dramatic and argumentative content in the online space ![Bar chart displays how frequently certain types of posts occur, highlighting dramatic/exaggerated and accusations without facts as most frequent.](image5).  In conclusion, men and women differ in their perceptions of online behavior, with men being more likely to perceive negativity, while both groups frequently encounter dramatic and argumentative content on social media.

Public opinion suggests a growing concern about the media's role in elections, as a majority of voters, $57\%$, expressed that news organizations wielded too much influence on the presidential election outcomes [7].  This sentiment marks a notable shift over time, reaching its peak since 2000, and is visualized in survey data across different election years ![The bar chart illustrates the trend of voters believing news organizations have "too much" influence on presidential elections from 1992 to 2016.](image1).

In 2016, this view was held by $57\%$ of voters, a significant increase from previous years and the highest recorded since 2000 [9]. In contrast, the proportion of individuals who believed the press had the 'right amount' of influence declined to its lowest point since 1992 [9].  Interestingly, even among Clinton voters, half felt the press exerted excessive influence [3, 10], a figure nearly double that of Obama voters in 2012 and 2008, and also surpassing Kerry voters in 2004 [10]. While a considerable $62\%$ of Trump voters shared this concern, it's noteworthy that even larger percentages of Romney $(69\%)$ and McCain $(77\%)$ voters felt this way after their respective election defeats [5].  Looking back to George W. Bush's reelection, only $45\%$ of Bush voters considered news organizations to have had too much influence [2, 5].

Overall, there's an increasing perception among voters that news organizations have had too much influence on presidential elections, with 2016 marking a high point in this view.

By January 2019, partisan opinions regarding Trump's economic policies had become significantly more polarized compared to October 2017 [8]. Perceptions on racial discrimination vary among US Hispanics, with a notable concern about the lack of recognition of existing racial discrimination [1]. Generally, a majority believes that global issues would worsen if the U.S. were not involved [10].  Notably, similar proportions of Republicans and Democrats share the sentiment that the absence of U.S. involvement would exacerbate world problems [8].  However, viewpoints diverge when considering whether U.S. actions are beneficial, as illustrated in survey data.  ![Republicans and Democrats are more inclined to agree that global problems would worsen without U.S. involvement, whereas Independents show a stronger tendency to believe that U.S. efforts often exacerbate issues.](image5)  Specifically, while moderate Democrats tend to acknowledge the necessity of U.S. efforts, liberal Democrats express more skepticism, with a considerable portion suggesting U.S. intervention might be detrimental [2]. As immigrant roots become more distant for self-identified Hispanics, their friend networks are less likely to be primarily Hispanic [7].  This trend is evident when comparing foreign-born Hispanics, who are most inclined to report having mainly Hispanic friends [1], to those of later generations.  The majority of first-generation Hispanic immigrants, specifically 77%, report that most of their friends share a Latino background. However, this percentage decreases significantly in subsequent generations. For second-generation Hispanics, this number drops to 55%, and by the third or higher generations, it further declines to just 37%.  ![This bar chart illustrates that as generations become more removed from immigration, the percentage of self-identified Hispanics who report having mostly Hispanic friends decreases.](image1) Even when considering self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, only a small fraction, 16%, report having mostly Hispanic friends [9]. Generational differences significantly influence the likelihood of self-identified Hispanics having Hispanic friends.

While many believe language to be a core component of Hispanic identity, data suggests otherwise, especially across generations. The progression of automotive technology is clearly moving towards more efficient and environmentally conscious solutions, starting from conventional vehicles and fuels, advancing to alternative fuels, and further to hybrid and electric technologies, ultimately reaching hydrogen technology as the future [5]. Examining the energy conversion process from source to wheel highlights a significant difference between electric vehicles (EVs) and internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs).  ![The infographic compares energy efficiency of EVs and ICEVs from source to wheel, showing EVs are more efficient.](image4).  Specifically, EVs achieve an overall energy efficiency of 23% from source to wheel, whereas ICEVs only reach 13% efficiency when considering the full energy path from source to wheel [image4]. This difference is largely due to the 'Tank-to-Wheels' efficiency, where EVs boast a 76% efficiency compared to a mere 16% for ICEVs [image4].

Electric vehicles demonstrate greater overall energy efficiency from source to wheel compared to internal combustion engine vehicles.

Experiences at work significantly diverge between men and women in computer-related roles, especially concerning gender-related discrimination. In summary, women in computer jobs are significantly more likely than men to experience gender-related discrimination.

A notable portion of the public identifies as independents, yet the vast majority of these independents lean towards either the Republican or Democratic parties [4]. Older adults often encounter specific hurdles when adopting technology, notably physical and health issues that complicate its use [4, 6, 8]. Rock music demonstrates a significantly higher catalog share in streams compared to Pop.  ![Rock's stream catalog share is at 82% while Pop's is at 58%.](image1) This is visually represented in the bar graph, where Rock's stream catalog share is notably higher than Pop's [image1]. Hispanics generally hold more favorable views towards the Democratic Party, perceiving them as more attentive to their community and its concerns [6]. This positive sentiment extends to the perception that Democrats are seen as working diligently to secure Latino votes.  For instance, a survey reveals that a substantial 81% of Latino Democrats or those leaning Democratic believe that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, with a notable 42% expressing this view "very well" ![Survey results on perceptions of party efforts to earn Latino votes among different political affiliations.](image1).  Conversely, when assessing the Republican Party's efforts, opinions diverge significantly among Latino Democrats.

While a considerable proportion of Latino Republicans, approximately 72%, feel that the Republican Party strives to earn Latino votes, with 34% holding this view "very well" ![Survey results on perceptions of party efforts to earn Latino votes among different political affiliations.](image1),  this contrasts sharply with Latino Democrats.  The data indicates that only 35% of Latino Democrats or those leaning Democratic agree that the Republican Party works hard for their vote, with a mere 13% endorsing this statement "very well" [5].  Interestingly, a segment of Latino Republicans (56%) acknowledges that the Democratic Party does put in effort to gain Latino votes [5], showcasing a nuanced perspective even across party lines.  This suggests that while partisan alignment strongly influences perceptions of effort, there is some cross-recognition of each party's attempts to engage with the Latino electorate [3].

In conclusion, Latino Democrats are significantly less likely than Latino Republicans to believe that the Republican Party works hard to earn Latino votes, while Latino Democrats are more likely to acknowledge the Democratic Party's efforts in this regard.

The greenhouse effect is a critical process involving infrared rays from the sun being trapped in the Earth's atmosphere, keeping our planet warm [9]. However, gases like carbon dioxide (CO2) and nitrous oxide (NO) are disrupting this process, leading to global warming [9, 7].  The exhaust from gasoline engines contains various components, including pollutants and gases that contribute to the greenhouse effect [5].

![The pie chart shows nitrogen at 71.5%, carbon dioxide at 13.7%, water at 13.1%, and miscellaneous gases at 0.7%. The bar chart shows carbon monoxide at 0.7%, hydrocarbons at 0.2%, nitrous oxide at 0.1%, and particulates at 0.005%.](image1)

Looking at the composition of exhaust gas from a gasoline engine, carbon dioxide constitutes 13.7% and nitrous oxide is 0.1% of the mixture [image1].  These proportions highlight the significant contribution of carbon dioxide compared to nitrous oxide in the exhaust gas [image1].

Carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide, two key gases causing the greenhouse effect, are present in gasoline engine exhaust at proportions of 13.7% and 0.1% respectively.

A proposal to establish independent redistricting commissions, composed equally of Democrats and Republicans to draw congressional maps, has garnered varied opinions across the political spectrum [2, 8].  Overall, approximately half of U.S. adults express approval for this measure [2, 6].  Specifically, 49% of adults approve, while only 13% disapprove, with a notable 38% remaining unsure about the proposal.  ![Overall public opinion on the redistricting proposal.](image4)  Examining partisan divides, Democrats show a higher inclination towards this proposal compared to Republicans [1].  A significant 59% of Democrats and those leaning Democratic approve of the idea, whereas only 8% disapprove.  In contrast, Republicans and Republican leaners display less enthusiasm, with 38% approving and 19% disapproving.  Notably, a considerable portion of Republicans, 42%, are unsure about the proposal, compared to 32% of Democrats who are unsure [10, image4].

In conclusion, Democrats are more likely to approve of the redistricting proposal compared to Republicans.

Many Americans consider lack of timely testing as a significant factor contributing to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak [5]. Specifically, approximately half of Americans, or $49\%$, identify "not enough timely testing" as a major reason for the continued spread of the virus, as illustrated in a survey about reasons for the spread of an issue ![49% of respondents think not enough timely testing is a major reason](image2).  This concern is further highlighted when considering political affiliations;  two-thirds of Democrats feel this is a major issue, compared to fewer than half as many Republicans [2].  This partisan divide is visually represented, showing that 67% of Democrats and 30% of Republicans believe not enough timely testing is a major reason for the continued outbreak ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to consider not enough timely testing as a major reason](image4).  In conclusion, around 49% of Americans believe that insufficient timely testing is a major factor in the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak.

Many Americans attribute the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak to a key factor identified in a recent survey.  It's widely believed that a significant issue is "not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines" [2]. This perspective is echoed by a large majority, with three-quarters of Americans citing it as a major reason for the ongoing situation, making it the most commonly identified major factor [3].  This viewpoint is further visualized, showing that 75% of respondents consider it a major reason  ![The bar chart indicates that 75% of people believe "Not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing" is a major reason for the continued spread](image1).  Notably, even across different political affiliations, a majority agrees on the impact of insufficient social distancing [5].  This consensus is visually represented, highlighting that while there are partisan differences on other factors, "not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing" remains a top concern for both Democrats and Republicans  ![The chart shows that "Not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing" is considered a major reason by 89% of Democrats and 57% of Republicans](image4).  Indeed, most Americans consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as the leading major cause for the prolonged COVID-19 outbreak [8].

The most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is the lack of sufficient social distancing and mask-wearing by people.

Americans have expressed increasing apprehension regarding various facets of the relationship with China, as indicated by a survey reflecting "rising concerns about China on many issues" [6].  Among these issues, cyber attacks emanating from China and China's human rights policies have notably surged in prominence as serious concerns.  Specifically, worries about cyber attacks from China are particularly pronounced, with approximately two-thirds of Americans considering them a very serious problem, marking a 7 percentage point increase since 2020 [10]. Similarly, concerns about China’s human rights policies have also escalated, with half of Americans now viewing them as a very serious issue, also reflecting a 7 percentage point rise since the previous year [9].

![Line graphs showing percentage change from 2020 to 2021 on various China-related issues, highlighting cyberattacks and human rights policies with a 7% increase.](image4)

These issues, along with others such as job losses and military power, have all seen an uptick in concern among Americans over the past year [4].  Cyber attacks from China and China's human rights policies are the issues that demonstrated the most significant increase in concern among Americans from 2020 to 2021.

Americans with Hispanic ancestry display varying levels of self-identification as Hispanic, with the likelihood of self-identification strongly linked to generational proximity to immigrant roots [9]. This trend is visually represented in bar chart ![The bar chart displays percentages of Hispanic and Non-Hispanic individuals across different generations, showing that the smallest bar, representing Non-Hispanic foreign-born individuals, is at 3%.](image5), where the smallest bar indicates that only 3% of foreign-born individuals identify as non-Hispanic. As generations become more removed from their immigrant past, self-identification as Hispanic decreases, with only 77% of the third generation identifying as Hispanic [7]. Factors such as high intermarriage rates and declining Latin American immigration contribute to this distancing from Hispanic identity over generations [4].

The smallest bar in the graph represents 3%.

Experiences with Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood diminish across generations [5]. For immigrant self-identified Hispanics, a majority (59%) were often taken to Hispanic cultural celebrations by their parents [2].  This pattern shifts in subsequent generations, as demonstrated in the frequency of participation.  ![Image4 shows the frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations among self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics across generations, categorized by 'Often', 'Sometimes', 'Rarely', and 'Never'.](image4). As depicted, the percentage of those who "often" attended celebrations decreases from foreign-born Hispanics to third or higher generations. Second-generation self-identified Hispanics show a reduced rate, with about half (49%) reporting frequent attendance at these celebrations in their childhood [7].  This decline continues into the third or higher generations, where only 35% report similar childhood experiences [7]. In stark contrast, among Americans with Latino ancestry who do not identify as Latino, a mere 9% report frequent childhood attendance at Latino cultural celebrations, while a significant 60% state it never occurred [8]. These generational shifts in childhood cultural experiences mirror broader variations in Hispanic identity and experiences [6].  The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood decreases across immigrant generations.

Women's participation in STEM roles is influenced by educational attainment [2].  Notably, the trend from 1990 to 2016, as shown in ![The percentage of women in STEM jobs generally increases with higher education levels from 1990 to 2016.](image5), indicates a rise in women's representation in STEM across all educational levels, especially for those with advanced degrees. Despite this overall increase over time, it's worth pointing out that among individuals currently employed in STEM, women's representation is actually lower in positions requiring advanced degrees [9].  Women constitute approximately half of the total STEM workforce, but their presence varies significantly depending on educational level and specific STEM fields [5].  Furthermore, the completion of STEM-related college programs is a crucial factor in determining the representation of women within the college-educated STEM workforce [7].  In conclusion, the level of education significantly impacts the representation of women in STEM jobs, with complex patterns observed across different degree levels.

The representation of women within STEM fields is not consistent across different job categories, showing considerable variation [2]. While women constitute half of the entire STEM workforce, this is largely attributed to their strong representation in health-related occupations, where they form a significant majority [3, 4].  Indeed, women account for three-quarters of all healthcare practitioners and technicians.  However, when we look at other STEM fields, particularly those in computer science and engineering, the picture is quite different [1].  For example, engineering occupations exhibit the lowest share of women, at only 14%, and computer occupations also present a lower proportion, with women making up just a quarter of the workforce [8].  This variation is visually represented in a dot plot, which clearly illustrates the distribution of women across different STEM job clusters, highlighting the higher representation in health-related jobs and the lower representation in engineering and computer jobs ![This dot plot illustrates the variation of female representation across different STEM job clusters](image3).  The range in representation is broad, spanning from a low of 7% for sales engineers to a high of 96% for speech language pathologists [9]. This variability in representation across different job clusters is also connected to the varying rates at which women pursue STEM degrees in college, which further influences the composition of the workforce [10].  Therefore, female representation in STEM jobs significantly varies depending on the specific job cluster.

Economic optimism saw a broad rise across nearly all demographics, yet the magnitude of this increase varied among different groups [1]. Notably, when we consider the change in family financial prospects, Latinos exhibited a more rapid increase in optimism compared to the general population.  The percentage of Latinos anticipating improvements in their family finances within the coming year jumped by 14 percentage points between 2008 and 2015, reaching 81% [2].

![A bar chart showing that the optimism about family finances expecting "a lot" or "some" improvement from 2008 to 2015 increased by 14% for All Hispanics, compared to a 6% increase for the General population.](image1)

This contrasts sharply with the general American public, where the corresponding rise in optimism was only 6 percentage points, culminating in 61% of Americans holding this view [2].  Indeed, a consistent trend since 2004 reveals that Latinos consistently express greater optimism about their financial futures than the broader public, and by 2015, this gap had widened to 20 percentage points [3].

![A bar chart comparing changes in financial optimism across different demographic groups of Hispanics from 2008 to 2015, showing that Hispanics with some college or more education had the largest increase of 20 percentage points.](image2)

Within the Latino community, this surge in economic optimism is not uniform across all subgroups.  Specifically, Latinos who have pursued some college education experienced a remarkable 20 percentage point increase in economic optimism since 2008. This growth is approximately double the increase observed among Latinos with a high school diploma (+9 percentage points) or less education (+11 percentage points) [6].  While many Latino subgroups demonstrated heightened financial optimism, the most significant surge was clearly observed among Latinos who had attended some college [7, 9].

Latinos with some college education demonstrated the largest increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015.
